item.title: Horrifying moment a soccer player is knocked unconscious and swallows his tongue before a quick-thinking teammate scoops it out and saves him from choking
item.description: Former Liverpool defender Martin Skrtel was left unconscious and swallowed his tongue during Slovakia's win against Thailand. Skrtel was knocked out in the 27th minute of the match.
item.content:encoded:
Former Liverpool defender Martin Skrtel was left unconscious and swallowed his tongue during Slovakia's King's Cup final victory against Thailand on Sunday.

Skrtel was knocked out in the 27th minute when the ball hit him in the face prompting him to collapse.

There was concern for the 33-year-old when he lay motionless after appearing to swallow his tongue.

Martin Skrtel was knocked out when the ball struck him in the face against Thailand

The former Liverpool defender Skrtel collapsed to the ground during the King's Cup final

There was concern after it emerged that the 33-year-old has swallowed his tongue

Team-mate Ondrej Duda had to act quickly to help the Fenerbache defender.

There was a long break in play as Skrtel received treatment from the pitchside  medical team at the Rajamangala Stadium in Thailand. 

Skrtel was taken off the pitch before managing to return to the action and play for another 45 minutes. 

Slovakia went on to beat Thailand 3-2 in the King's Cup final. 

It was reported after the game that Skrtel was okay after a follow-up check from the Slovakia team doctor.  

The medical staff at Rajamangala Stadium attended to Skrtel on the pitch before he came off

item.title: Portugal 0-3 Holland: Virgil van Dijk, Ryan Babel and Memphis Depay score to earn Ronald Koeman his first victory as manager of the Oranje
item.description: Just days after losing to a young England squad, Holland bounced back in the best way possible against the Euro 2016 champions thanks to goals from Depay, Babel and Van Dijk.
item.content:encoded:
Ronald Koeman picked up his first win as Holland manager on Monday with an emphatic 3-0 victory against Portugal, largely thanks to two Premier League misfits and Virgil van Dijk. 

Just days after losing to Gareth Southgate's young England squad, Holland bounced back in the best way possible with a dominant display against the Euro 2016 champions thanks to goals from Memphis Depay, Ryan Babel and Van Dijk.

Former Manchester United winger Depay, now enjoying life with Lyon, gave Holland a fantastic start, scoring the opening goal in the 11th minute after converting Donny van de Beek's cross.

Virgil van Dijk scored Holland's third goal of the match with a brilliant right-footed finish on the stroke of half-time

Van Dijk is congratulated by his Holland team-mates as the Oranje enjoyed the perfect evening in Geneva against Portugal

Ryan Babel headed home Holland's second goal of the night after he latched on to a deflected Matthijs de Ligt cross

Cristiano Ronaldo shows his disappointment following the former Liverpool man's goal on Tuesday night in Switzerland

Joao Cancelo (left) was shown a red card in the second half after picking up a second yellow for a tackle on Tonny Vilhena

Portugal could have pegged Holland back if Cristiano Ronaldo had been awarded a penalty following a clumsy challenge from Nathan Ake on the half hour mark.

But it was Holland who struck again just moments later, with ex-Liverpool man Babel heading home from close range after getting onto the end of a deflected Matthijs de Ligt cross.

The Dutch had their tails off and on the stroke of half-time Van Dijk, who captained Koeman's side again, added a third with a fine finish into the bottom corner.

Lyon winger Memphis Depay put Ronald Koeman's side 1-0 ahead with a strike from close range in just the 11th minute

Depay wheels off to celebrate after scoring past Portugal goalkeeper Anthony Lopes to put Holland 1-0 ahead in Geneva

Ronaldo reacts angrily as he has a penalty appeal rejected after going down under a challenge from Nathan Ake

Liverpool's £75million centre back Van Dijk gives the Real Madrid man the eyes in Switzerland on Monday night

With the game wrapped up for Holland in the first half, the second 45 was far less eventful. The only talking point was Joao Cancelo receiving his marching orders after picking up a second yellow for a tackle on Tonny Vilhena.

Ronaldo was replaced by Joao Moutinho with just over 20 minutes remaining as the game petered out, while Ajax starlet Justin Kluivert was brought on by Koeman for his international debut in the 78th minute. 

There remains a long way to go but this display — against a side that conquered the rest of Europe in France back in 2016 — will rightly give cause for optimism.

And taking to Instagram after the final whistle, Depay sought to silence Holland's critics by saying: 'It was time to cut out the background noise, our journey starts now.'

The five-time Ballon d'Or winner attempts to cross the ball into the penalty area as Dutch defender Ake closes him down

Justin Kluivert is hugged by Depay at the end of the match after coming on for his international debut in the 78th minute

It was time to cut out the background noise, our journey starts now 🤫#Oranje #YoungKings #Ivory

A post shared by Memphis Depay (@memphisdepay) on Mar 26, 2018 at 1:51pm PDT

item.title: Australia vice-captain David Warner is the most disliked player in the world's most disliked team
item.description: LAWRENCE BOOTH: It sounds like a joke now, but until recently David Warner — the most disliked player in the world’s most disliked team — was known to team-mates as ‘the Reverend’.
item.content:encoded:
It sounds like a joke now, but until recently David Warner — the most disliked player in the world's most disliked team — was known to team-mates as 'the Reverend'.

But those outside Australia's dressing-room bubble have not always regarded him as a natural man of the cloth. And, as his role in the ball-tampering scandal that has engulfed Australian cricket comes under increasing scrutiny, the nickname may have to be quietly shelved.

As wicketkeeping great Adam Gilchrist remarked after Warner's stairwell spat with South Africa's Quinton de Kock at Durban: 'The Reverend's gone — Bull's back.' 

It sounds like a joke now, but David Warner was once known to team-mates as 'the Reverend'

For a while, Warner managed to convince even himself that his 'Bull' persona — the bundle of venom who regarded no sledge as too contemptible — was a thing of the past.

After marrying Candice Falzon, a former professional ironwoman, in 2015 and becoming a father, he seemed to mellow. He stopped drinking, and his wife introduced him to John Novak, a mind coach. In turn, Novak introduced Warner to mindfulness — the western world's adaptation of Buddhism's search for inner calm.

It appeared to do the trick. Warner would deal with stick by telling himself three positive things about his critic. He adopted preacher-like poses to celebrate his centuries. In 2016, he was named Australia's Sporting Father of the Year. He scored runs for fun, especially in one-day cricket.

'I don't know where they've taken the old Davey Warner,' said a team-mate. 'But I quite like this new version.' 

Warner and captain Steve Smith are set to be banned after the recent ball-tampering scandal

The media happily bought into the transformation. Here was the definitive Aussie larrikin, who had stacked shelves at Woolworths as a teenager, paid off his parents' credit card bills, and overcome some hairy moments — including an infamous punch thrown at Joe Root in a Birmingham bar in 2013 — to rise to the Test vice-captaincy. What was not to like?

'The boys call me the Rev now because they reckon the Bull's been tamed a little bit,' he said. Emboldened, he took to the pulpit last year to lecture South Africa after their captain Faf du Plessis was caught up in a ball-tampering row in Australia.

'I just know from an Australian cricket perspective, we hold our heads high,' said Warner.

'I'd be very disappointed if one of our team members did that. The rules are in place for a reason. If you're not going to use them, why bother having them?'

The sermon has not aged well. 

Warner shook his 'Bull' nickname after marrying ex-professional ironwoman Candice Falzon

Worse, the Bull has since had other ideas. Sportsmail revealed on Monday that Warner told England players at an end-of-series drinks party how he had used a bandage on his hand to rough up the ball during the Ashes and help Australia's bowlers achieve reverse swing.

And Cricket Australia's investigation into the events that led to opening batsman Cameron Bancroft shoving an incriminating piece of sticky tape down his trousers in Cape Town, and captain Steve Smith admitting to cheating, is sure to focus on Warner's role in the fiasco. A ban seems inevitable.

Yet the signs were already there that the Reverend's halo had begun to slip. Ahead of the Ashes, Warner went full Bull, saying: 'As soon as you step on that line it's war. You try and get into a battle as quick as you can. I try and look in the opposition's eyes and try and work out, 'How can I dislike this player? How can I get on top of him?'

'You have to delve and dig deep into yourself to actually get some hatred about them to actually get up when you're out there.' 

Sportsmail revealed Warner told England players he roughed-up the ball during the Ashes

Warner was true to his word, leading the personal abuse aimed at Jonny Bairstow and generally rubbing England up the wrong way. This was the Warner of old, a character so addicted to nastiness that his abuse of a Test team-mate in an Australian domestic match once persuaded the victim not to shake his hand at the end of the game — cricket's ultimate snub.

Candice deserved all the sympathy she got when her past was used as sledging material by South African players and fans. The trouble was, no one had any sympathy for her husband.

The reason was summed up by Gilchrist. 'All his team-mates are saying, 'The Reverend's gone, Bull's back'. It's always a worry when someone is so extreme in one direction or the other. I think Davey's got to find somewhere in between that.'

If Australia's board, who stood him down from the vice- captaincy during the Cape Town Test, impose further sanctions, Warner will have plenty of time to consider his options.

Getting a decent nickname will be the least of his problems.

item.title: Anthony Joshua's incredible power against Joseph Parker's relentless stamina... how do the two heavyweights compare ahead of their huge unification showdown in Cardiff?
item.description: Anthony Joshua is days away from his heavyweight bout against Joseph Parker. Sportsmail analyses the strengths and weaknesses of the two big-hitters and looks at how they match up
item.content:encoded:
Anthony Joshua is days away from his highly-anticipated heavyweight unification bout against Joseph Parker in Cardiff. 

The Brit has been made a huge favourite to pick up a fourth belt and extend his record to 21-0 but those in the know believe this one is much closer than the bookmakers’ odds suggest. 

Here, Sportsmail analyses the strengths and weaknesses of the two big-hitters and how they match up ahead of the big fight.

Anthony Joshua and Joseph Parker will go head to head on Saturday night in Cardiff

The pair will be putting their respective belts on the line in the huge unification bout

 

Experience

The two men are at relatively similar stages of their respective careers.

Parker, a world champion with 24 fights and 24 wins, 18 of those by knockout. Joshua, a world champion with 20 fights and 20 wins, all coming by knockout. But when it comes to a comparison there is one name that sets the two fighters apart.

Joshua’s stunning victory over Wladimir Klitschko was seen as a passing of the torch moment for a division that the Ukrainian dominated for over 10 years. Parker has more rounds under his belt but has never beaten someone on the level of Klitschko nor fought on a stage like this one. When it comes to the one man both have faced, Carlos Takam, neither shone but Joshua secured a stoppage while Parker was taken all the way.

Parker is still waiting for his breakout fight, Joshua has had his. 

Joshua: 7.5/10 

Parker: 6.5/10 

Joshua earned his stripes when he knocked out Wladimir Klitschko at Wembley in 2017

Power

Anyone can knockout anyone in heavyweight boxing, let's get that straight. Parker has 18 KOs to his name so there's no doubt he has power in his hands but what can’t be ignored is the fact the Kiwi has failed to finish any of his three fights since stepping up to world level. 

Taken the distance by Hughie Fury, Razvan Cojanu, Ruiz and Takam not long before that, Parker's power is nothing special at the top end of the division. The same can't be said for his big-punching adversary, who has toppled all 20 of his opponents since turning pro. Joshua maintained that record with his controversial 10th-round stoppage of Takam in October and while he does not possess the one-punch knockout power of Deontay Wilder, there is only so many clean shots anyone standing across the ring from the Brit can handle. 

Joshua: ‪9/10 

Parker: ‪7/10 

The Briton's now iconic uppercut against Klitschko demonstrated all the power he has 

Chin 

Perhaps the biggest feather in Parker's cap. The 25-year-old has proven that he can take a punch as good as anyone. The New Zealander has never been dropped and never even been wobbled despite being caught flush on a number of occasions. Joshua, meanwhile, has long been linked with a suspect chin with tales of his sparring troubles having circulated the boxing world for years. 

Daniel Dubois and fellow British Olympian David Price have both knocked down the Brit in the gym. The 28-year-old was also rocked badly by British rival Dillian Whyte in the second round of their grudge match and sent to the canvas when Klitschko landed a straight right hand during their clash at Wembley. Whether Parker has the power to capitalise is another question. 

Parker has taken plenty of shots during his career to date but has shown he has a good chin

Joshua was surprisingly rocked by Carlos Takam in his last fight but came through the hard test

Joshua: 6.5/10

Parker: ‪9/10 

Jab 

Olympic gold medalist Joshua has been lauded for his solid fundamentals. With crisp and clean technique, the Londoner boasts an extremely effective stiff jab with a snap that keeps his opponents on the back foot allowing him to set up that devastating right. Parker also has possesses a solid jab of his own but uses it less often, spending most of his recent bout against Fury attempting to close the distance. Joshua’s significant height and reach advantage should see him come out on top in this battle. 

Joshua: ‪8/10 

Parker: ‪7/10 

Parker relies heavily on his jab but his reach is shorter than Joshua's which could be an issue

ANTHONY JOSHUA 

Nationality: United Kingdom

Age: 28

Height: 6ft 6ins (198cm)

Reach: 82ins (208cm)

Stance: Orthodox 

Heavyweight Titles: IBO, WBA, IBF

Won: 20

Lost: 0 

Drawn: 0 

Wins by Knockouts: 20 

Knockout Ratio: 100% 

Rounds: 65 

JOSEPH PARKER 

Nationality: New Zealand

Age: 26

Height: 6ft 4ins (193cm)

Reach: 76ins (193cm)

Stance:  Orthodox

Heavyweight Titles: WBO

Won: 24

Lost: 0 

Drawn: 0  

Wins by Knockouts: 18

Knockout Ratio:  75%

Rounds: 123 

Speed 

A man who once described himself at the ‘fastest heavyweight on the planet’, Parker boasts incredible hand speed for a heavyweight. The New Zealander has the ability to put together combinations that will trouble Joshua and the footwork which allows him to be effective going both backwards and forwards. And he’ll need it to deal with the length and size of his opponent, who prefers to throw in short bursts as he works his man toward the ropes.

Joshua: 8/10

Parker: 8.5/10 

Parker has speed on his side as he is likely to come in much lighter than his British rival

Defence

It’s a good thing Parker has a chin of steel because avoiding punches is by no means his strong suit. The WBO champion’s defence is leaky and his lack of head movement sees him get caught regularly whenever the opponent applies real pressure. In his last outing against Fury, one many argue he lost, the 26-year-old ate plenty of shots while Takam was also able to land numerous times when they met. 

Joshua, who fights in a more cautious style, has good defensive awareness with his right hand up protecting his chin while also using his lead hand to parry his opponent’s jab and measure distance. The Englishman is liable to getting dragged into a war, however, and when he does he leaves himself open to sharp counters that Parker could take advantage of. 

Joshua: 8/10 

Parker: 6/10

The New Zealander has some good defensive moves but is prone to leaving himself wide open

LATEST ODDS - RESULT

Joshua - 1/8

Parker - 6/1

Draw - 33/1 

Joshua By KO TKO or DQ - 2/7 

Parker By KO TKO or DQ - 8/1

Joshua By Decision or Technical Decision - 9/2

Parker By Decision or Technical Decision - 20/1   

Stamina

Another area where Parker should have no problem. The Kiwi has heard the final bell in four of his last six fights and has impressive conditioning has left him looking relatively comfortable doing so each time.

Musclebound Joshua has yet to go beyond the 11th round in his short pro career and has shown moments of fatigue when hunting for the finish too early.

AJ looked at one point to have punched himself when he knocked down Klitschko in the fifth round of their epic encounter and almost paid the price in the sixth.

There is no doubt Parker will be aiming to keep the fight at a fast pace and take this one to the later rounds to see how Joshua fares.

Joshua: 7.5/10

Parker: 9/10 

Stamina is a big question ahead of the fight and Joshua's weight could be a big factor

... AND THE GRAND TOTAL IS:

Joshua 46.5/50

Parker 46/50 

Those in the know say this fight will be a lot closer than most believe it will be and that theory plays out in our final numbers. Joshua edges out Parker, but by the smallest of margins despite the bookies having the home favourite well ahead. 

Parker may not be the most exciting fighter in the world but he will pose questions for Joshua; ones that his career to date have not fully answered. The British champion is known for his power but he'll be coming in 'light' at just over 17 stone for this one, according to his trainer Rob McCracken. So, will his power be diminished? If it is, does he have enough about him technically to outbox Parker? Can his motor match the Kiwi's?

The two fighters are closely matched and will provide a thrilling contest on Saturday night

On paper the fight is a tortoise against the hare scenario, but Joshua says he has learned from the mistakes he made in his laboured win against Carlos Takam so won't be rushing in.  

So many questions, all of which will be answered on Saturday night.

item.title: Ex-South Africa captain Fanie de Villiers reveals he instructed cameramen to look out for signs of ball tampering... and it took an hour and a half: 'We said go out and have a look, boys. They're using something'
item.description: De Villiers has been working for a broadcaster for the series and claimed he knew something untoward could have been going on by how early the Tourists were getting the ball to reverse swing.
item.content:encoded:
Former South Africa captain Fanie de Villiers has revealed how he helped snare the cheating Australians after instructing camera operators to look out for ball tampering, having suspected underhanded tactics.

De Villiers has been working for a broadcaster in South Africa for the Test series and claimed he knew something untoward could have been going on by how early the Tourists were getting the ball to reverse swing.

Ultimately his suspicions were proved correct when, after searching for an hour and a half, the cameras spotted Cameron Bancroft rubbing sticky yellow tape on the ball in an attempt to alter its condition.

Fanie de Villiers instructed camera operators to look out for signs of ball tampering

De Villiers said he knew something was up given how early they got the ball to reverse swing

Steve Smith (R) and Cameron Bancroft (L) admitted to deliberately tampering with the ball

'I said earlier on, that if they could get reverse swing in the 26th, 27th, 28th over then they are doing something different from what everyone else does,' de Villiers told RSN Radio on Monday.

'We actually said to our cameramen, "go out (and) have a look, boys. They're using something".

'They searched for an hour and a half until they saw something and then they started following Bancroft and they actually caught him out at the end.

Damning graphic shows how the ball reversed in Cape Town while Bancroft tampered with the ball but stopped when his actions were exposed

Cameras spotted Bancroft rubbing yellow tape on the ball before hiding it down his trousers

The umpires went over to confront Bancroft after the footage was shown on the big screen

'It's impossible for the ball to get altered like that on cricket wickets where we knew there was grass on, not a Pakistani wicket where there's cracks every centimetre.

'We're talking about a grass-covered wicket where you have to do something else to alter the shape, to alter the roughness of the ball on the one side. You have to get the one side wetter, heavier than the other side.'

A damning graphic showed how the ball reversed in Cape Town while Bancroft tampered with the ball but stopped when his actions were exposed. 

Steve Smith was given a one-match ban, fined 100 per cent of his match fee and has been temporarily stood down as captain during this series for his involvement in the scandal.

Bancroft, meanwhile, was fined 75 per cent of his fee and given three demerit points.

Smith was fined and given a one-match ban after admitting they planned the ball-tampering

Bancroft was fined 75 per cent of his match fee and slapped with three demerit points

item.title: Manchester City 'eye £75m move' for Isco in summer deal that would make Real Madrid ace club-record signing
item.description: Manchester City are reportedly ready to break their transfer record on Real Madrid midfielder Isco this summer. Isco has started 18 La Liga games and six Champions League matches this term.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester City are reportedly ready to break their transfer record on Real Madrid midfielder Isco this summer.

Isco, 25, has started 18 La Liga games and six Champions League matches this season but, according to The Sun, he fears his playing opportunities could soon become restricted under Zinedine Zidane and is ready to quit the Bernabeu.

It is claimed that City boss Pep Guardiola is willing to spend £75million on Isco, who has twice turned down City in the past but is now ready to say yes.

Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola is reportedly keen to sign Spain international Isco (above)

Isco, pictured in action for Spain against Germany on Friday, is on the books at Real Madrid

The 25-year-old has hit five goals and provided the same number of assists in La Liga this term

French centre back Aymeric Laporte is City's most expensive signing to date after joining from Athletic Bilbao for a £57m fee in January.

Although he brought in Laporte for big money, Guardiola did not get everything he wanted in January and — after missing out on Alexis Sanchez and Riyad Mahrez — the ex-Barcelona boss remains keen on strengthening his attacking midfield options.

Isco, who has hit five goals and provided the same number of assists in La Liga this season, would add depth to an area in which City are already bursting with talent.

Seven City players have scored at least seven goals in all competitions this season, with Raheem Sterling, Leroy Sane, Kevin De Bruyne and David Silva getting 20, 12, 11 and nine respectively.

Isco has been a Real player since arriving from Malaga in 2013.

He has won three Champions League titles and one La Liga crown with Real.

Guardiola is said to be an admirer and is apparently willing to spend a £75million fee for Isco

Aymeric Laporte is City's most expensive signing to date after joining for £57m in January

item.title: Australia set to kick out shamed captain Steve Smith and vice-captain David Warner... with coach Darren Lehmann also expected to step down after ball-tampering scandal
item.description: Steve Smith could be stripped of the Australia captaincy permanently, as he and vice-captain David Warner face one-year bans for their part in the ball-tampering scandal in South Africa.
item.content:encoded:
Steve Smith could be stripped of the Australia captaincy permanently, as he and vice-captain David Warner face one-year bans for their part in the ball-tampering scandal in South Africa.

And it was reported on Monday night that coach Darren Lehmann, who had planned to see Australia through next summer’s World Cup and Ashes series in England, is on the brink of resigning.

On the day it emerged many of Australian cricket’s major sponsors were considering their involvement with the sport, the board’s chief executive James Sutherland left for Johannesburg declaring: ‘We know Australians want answers.’ 

Steve Smith and David Warner are facing lengthy bans from the Australian cricket team

The Australia captain (right) was pictured at his side's team hotel in Cape Town on Monday

Smith is set to be stripped of the captaincy after his role in the ball-tampering scandal 

Australia coach Darren Lehmann is also reportedly ready to step down from his position 

He will act on the advice of Cricket Australia’s integrity unit, who continued their inquiry into what led Smith’s team to cheat during the third Test in Cape Town.

The ICC has suspended Smith from the final Test starting on Friday. And Warner — a central figure in the Australia leadership group that hatched the plan for Cameron Bancroft to rough up one side of the ball — is set to be left out too, with year-long suspensions from Cricket Australia a likely punishment for both players. 

Though life bans are unlikely, Sutherland is under pressure from Australia’s prime minister Malcolm Turnbull to reflect the mood of the nation and take decisive action.

Lehmann’s position looks equally untenable, with John Buchanan — one of his predecessors — casting doubt on Smith’s claims that the coach didn’t know about the plan. 

‘It is unusual as the teams are walking out that the coach is unaware of what’s about to happen,’ Buchanan told the BBC.

The repercussions of the players’ decision to break the laws continues to spiral.

Warner also faces a lengthy ban for deliberately trying to alter the condition of the ball

Cricket Australia's James Sutherland declared on Monday: 'We know Australians want answers'

AUSTRALIA SCHEDULE 

June 2018: Tour of England, 5 ODIs and 1 T20

June-July: Tour of Zimbabwe, 1 Test and 3 ODIs

July: Bangladesh in Australia, 2 Tests and 3 ODIs

October: Tour of Pakistan, 5 ODIs and 1 T20

October-November: South Africa in Australia, 5 ODIs and 3 T20s

November-January 2019: India in Australia, 4 Tests

Qantas Airways, cereal brand Sanitarium, brewer Lion, kit firm Asics and Toyota were among sponsors who indicated their involvement was in jeopardy. 

A Sanitarium spokesman said: ‘The actions taken by the team don’t align with our values — (we do) not condone cheating in sport.’

Their concerns were echoed by Lion, who said: ‘Like the rest of Australia, we’re deeply concerned. This is not what you’d expect from anyone in sport.’

Qantas said in a statement: ‘This is deeply disappointing and not what anyone expects from our national team. We are in discussions with Cricket Australia as this issue unfolds.’

Tim Paine, the acting captain, admitted: ‘It’s been a horrible 24 hours. The enormity of what has happened is starting to sink in.’ 

Rookie opener Cameron Bancroft found himself at the centre of the storm on Saturday 

Bancroft was seen running his hand over the ball, before removing a yellow object from his pocket and placing it down the front of his trousers

Bancroft and Smith admitted their guilt in a dramatic press-conference at the end of day three 

Calls for Smith to be permanently stripped of the captaincy have grown in the cricket world

item.title: Welcome to Miami... where former F1 star Eddie Irvine has put his stunning seven-bedroom beach home up for sale for £21m (including dock for a 130-FOOT yacht!)
item.description: On the racetrack he was known as Fast Eddie. Now former F1 driver Eddie Irvine is planning to make a very speedy £10.7million profit on a stunning waterfront mansion.
item.content:encoded:
On the racetrack he was known as Fast Eddie. Now former F1 driver Eddie Irvine is planning to make a very speedy £10.7million profit on a stunning waterfront mansion he has just put up for sale in Miami Beach.

Irvine, 52, wants £21million for the 10,448 sq ft home on ultra-exclusive Hibiscus Island after spending £10.3m on the land and construction.

The house, called Casa Ischia, boasts a dock big enough to handle a 130ft yacht, seven bedrooms, seven bathrooms, a movie theatre, wine cellar and even a lift to move between the two floors.

Former F1 driver Eddie Irvine is planning to make a £10million profit on his stunning waterfront mansion in Miami Beach

Irvine, 52, wants £21million for the 10,448 sq ft home with extraordinary views of the Miami skyline across the water

'Fast Eddie' is selling his home on ultra-exclusive Hibiscus Island after spending £10.3million on the land and construction

Irvine finished the house last December and stays there frequently to enjoy the stunning views of Biscayne Bay and downtown Miami. The mansion sits behind security gates and Hibiscus Island is one of the Miami Beach’s most celebrated gated communities. 

Irvine, who raced for Jordan, Ferrari and Jaguar and won four Grands Prix, turned to full-time property developing when his motorsport career finished in 2002.

His latest home has sliding glass doors all along one side and boasts two outdoor kitchens plus a pool, two outdoor spas and a beach area with a fire pit. A 783sq ft roof terrace sits atop the two-storey mansion.

Property records reveal Irvine bought the plot in 2012 for £3.71m. He spent about £6.59m on architects, materials and labour, his estate agent said.

The house, Casa Ischia, boasts a dock big enough to handle a 130ft yacht, seven bedrooms, seven bathrooms and a cinema

Irvine finished the house last December and stays there frequently to enjoy the stunning views of Biscayne Bay

The mansion sits on Hibiscus Island, and is in one of the Miami Beach’s most celebrated gated communities

Irvine, who raced for Jordan, Ferrari and Jaguar, turned to property developing when his motorsport career finished in 2002

Property records reveal Irvine bought the plot in 2012 for £3.71m, before he spent about £6.59m to build the mansion

The mansion is the latest in a series of lucrative property deals for the retired driver, who also owns a Dublin pub

Three years ago he sold a 6,612 sq ft mansion in Miami Beach for £7.5million, after renting it out to DJ David Guetta

The mansion is the latest in a series of lucrative property deals for the retired driver, who also owns a Dublin pub. Three years ago he sold a 6,612 sq ft mansion in Miami Beach for £7.5million, after renting it out to international DJ David Guetta.

Irvine also has a private island in the Bahamas which he bought in 2010, and where he built an eco-friendly hexagonal wooden structure. He cheated death there four years later when a shark attacked him while he was diving.

At the time he said: ‘I turned to face it, not easy to do, and hit it with my spear. It turned away but came back as I reversed out of his territory. It was dusk - so I guess I deserved it a bit.’ 

His latest home has sliding glass doors all along one side and boasts two outdoor kitchens plus a pool and two outdoor spas

The incredible house also boasts a beach area with a fire pit. A 783sq ft roof terrace sits atop the two-storey mansion

If you have £20million to spare, you too can live like a former F1 driver, and enjoy these incredible views every day

Irvine in his F1 heyday with Ferrari (left) - he won four Grands Prix in his nine year career - and in 2016 (right)

item.title: Wales 0-1 Uruguay: Edinson Cavani strikes to deny Ryan Giggs China Cup triumph and condemn new boss to first defeat in charge of national side
item.description: LAURIE WHITWELL AT THE GUANGXI SPORTS CENTRE: Cavani cocked his trademark celebration and hopes Ryan Giggs had for starting his Wales reign with a trophy were shot down.
item.content:encoded:
Edinson Cavani cocked his trademark sniper celebration and the hopes Ryan Giggs had for starting his Wales reign with a trophy were shot down.

Cavani marked his 100th cap by striking early in the second half as Uruguay sliced through a lapsed defence and showed the strides Wales need to make when the competitive action begins for Giggs.

Gareth Bale will need to play better too if Wales are to reach Euro 2020 although Giggs defended his talisman by arguing Oscar Tabarez's side worked in packs to limit his threat. 

Uruguay's victorious players with the trophy after a post-match on-field presentation

Luis Suarez (right) poses with the China Cup alongside Giorgian De Arrascaeta after the game

Edinson Cavani poses in the dressing room after securing victory for Uruguay on Monday

Edinson Cavani makes no mistake from close range after Christian Rodriguez's square pass

The Uruguayan side embrace in a team huddle on their way to winning the China Cup

Edinson Cavani celebrates in typical style after giving Uruguay the lead against Wales

This was a friendly tournament but the seriousness Giggs took the China Cup final could be seen in his animated demeanour as the seconds counted down, with Bale trying to pick a way through and Ashley Williams pushed up front as a makeshift striker.

It must be said the South Americans approached the contest with commitment too, with Cavani only replaced at the very end and Luis Suarez staying on for the duration. 

As a proper examination against an opponent of genuine international pedigree, it was worthwhile.

Wales players headed to Hong Kong straight after the final whistle and will fly back home on Tuesday as minds switch to club matters. 

Gareth Bale aims a shot at goal during the first-half as Diego Laxalt watches on

Wales striker Sam Vokes rises highest to win a header in front of Uruguay's Diego Godin

Wales captain Ashley Williams chases after Uruguay striker Luis Suarez in the second-half

'We won't play against much better teams than that in terms of experience, talent, and hard work,' Giggs said. 

MATCH FACTS 

Wales (3-4-2-1):Hennessey 7; Chester 6 (Lockyer 75’), Williams 6, Davies 7 (Hedges 90’); Gunter 6.5 (Matthews 79’), Allen 7, King 7, John 6 (Roberts 60’ 6.5); Bale 6, Wilson 6.5 (Evans 72’ 6); Vokes 6.5 (Bodin 67’ 6)

Subs not used: Maxwell, Bradshaw, Watkins, Mepham, Woodburn, Crowe

Booked: Allen

Manager: Ryan Giggs 6 

Uruguay: Muslera 7; Varela 7, Giminez 5 (Coates 8’ 6.5), Godin 7.5, Laxalt 7; Bentancur 7 (G Silva 78’), Nadez (Stuani 85’), Vecino 7, Rodriguez 7.5 (Torreira 70’ 6); Cavani 8 (Gomez 90’), Suarez 7 

Subs not used: Campana, Sanchez, De Arrascaeta, Pereira, Ramirez, Silva

Goals: Cavani 49

Manager: Oscar Tabarez 7

Man of the Match: Edinson Cavani

Referee: Salman Ahmad Falahi 

Att: 41,016

'It was a great learning curve for the players and a great test, which I thought the stood up to. What I want from my team is to go to the end and I thought we did.

'When Gareth gets the ball of course he is going to have players around him, they recognise the quality he's got and make it difficult for him. But I thought he was a threat all night.'

Bale added: 'We could have got something out of the game but it wasn't meant to be. We'll keep learning, there's a lot of positives to take from the tournament.

'When the major games come around in the qualifiers we'll be ready. It's been important having the new manager in and everybody settling down, getting to know his ways. I think it'll stand us in good stead for the future.'

At times it had the feel of the Euro 2016 semi-final against Portugal when Wales simply came up against a technically superior collective.

Twice Suarez hit the post when he should have scored and when he did get the ball in the net he was flagged offside in a very tight call.

But Wales had their moments too, notably when Fernando Muslera had to push wide a glancing Bale header, and the Uruguayan's certainly benefitted from officiating that caused Giggs to show he can dish out a touchline tongue-lashing when the mood takes him. 

Gareth Bale traps the ball as opposition player Laxalt looks for a way to claim possession

Uruguay midfielder Nahitan Nandez falls to ground after a late challenge from Joe Allen

Midfielder Andy King plays a sideways pass as Nandez tracks after the ball on Monday

It was a highly curious detail that Joe Allen was the only player to receive a caution from the Qatari referee.

Yet Wales could also be their own worst enemies, letting Uruguay in without the requisite resistance and they were very nearly behind inside two minutes when Cristian Rodriguez escaped down the right and pulled the ball back for Suarez, who had checked his run to find space in the box. But his finish smacked the post.

Wales were lucky again when Ashley Williams failed to get a pass-back to Wayne Hennessey and put Suarez clear. Hennessey reacted quickly to push the ball wide and Suarez rushed to hit the post again.

James Chester then failed to cut out a Suarez pass to Cavani and Hennessey was required to palm over the subsequent rocket shot. 

Wales were playing good stuff in patches and Andy King twice tested Muslera from long range and Sam Vokes had two decent chances.

But Giggs's side buckled five minutes after the break. Diego Godin's ball from midfield caught out Chester too easily and Rodriguez was through on the left. 

Ryan Giggs watches on from the dugout in his second game in charge of the national team

Real Madrid and Barcelona rivals Bale and Suarez embrace before kick-off on Monday

He had time to pick his cross for Cavani, whose run Williams had failed to track and the finish was a simple tap-in.

Soon after Cavani could have doubled the lead but miscued when found by Guillermo Varela.

Wales tried hard for an equaliser, pinning Uruguay back, but did not get the rub or summon enough skill. Another effort by King was deflected narrowly wide and when Lee Evans tried from distance Muslera once again saved.

item.title: Premier League transfer fees may be crazy but the original big spenders were Italian clubs in the 90s - from £13m Gianluigi Lentini to £35m Hernan Crespo (and Christian Vieri's nine clubs in nine years!)
item.description: AMITAI WINEHOUSE: If some of the transfer fees thrown around this summer made eyes water and fists shake, at least they did not incur the wrath of god, unlike Gianluigi Lentini.
item.content:encoded:
All this week Sportsmail will be celebrating Italian football in the 1990s, in the build-up to BT Sport's new documentary on the glory days of Serie A. AMITAI WINEHOUSE details the crazy spending that fuelled Italian football's glory days before the inevitable crash...

 

If some of the transfer fees thrown around the Premier League this summer made eyes water and fists shake, at least they did not incur the wrath of god.

In 1992, the year the Premier League began, Gianluigi Lentini, a winger with 16 goals to his name over 111 appearances for Torino, broke the world transfer fee with his £13million move to AC Milan.

Media across the country, across the world, went wild at this ever-growing market, Lentini being the apparent cap. Little did they know.

AC Milan paid £13m for Gianluigi Lentini (right), a fee that even the Vatican disapproved of

Jean-Pierre Papin (left) and Gianluca Vialli both broke the world transfer record in 1992

The Archbishop of Canterbury did not comment on Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain's £35m move to Liverpool. There were no missives from the chief rabbi when Chelsea paid £70m for Alvaro Morata. The Dalai Lama kept out of the debate on Alexandre Lacazette's £46.5m switch to Arsenal. But the Vatican even felt moved to comment on Lentini's transfer, calling the fee 'an offence to the dignity of work'.

Prices in the Italian game were spiralling. In 1992, the transfer record was broken three times, twice by AC Milan either side of Gianluca Vialli's £12m move to Juventus, with Lentini the last. Milan were the first team to break the £10m threshold when they bought Jean-Pierre Papin that summer. The Premier League may have launched that year, but the eyes of the world were on Italy.

In fact, between 1990 and 2000, the world-record transfer fee was broken 10 times. On all but three of those occasions, the buying club played in Serie A. The last one, Hernan Crespo's move to Lazio from Parma for £35.5m, was both the peak and the moment before the fall of the Italian game – the Argentinian's move is the last time a club from the country has broken the record.

It caused a reporter from the BBC to ask the question: 'Has the world gone mad?'

Back to Lentini and 1992, though. Deities aside, at least the move initially seemed to work on the pitch. He was a key cog in Fabio Capello's side as Milan captured the Serie A title and reached the final of the Champions League, where they surprisingly lost to Marseille.

That would be Lentini's final hurrah as a player. In 1993 he was involved in a serious car accident and while he recovered, he was never the same player again. Too much was expected of a man who was dogged by memory loss and blurred vision.

Marcel Desailly summed it up: 'You could see the skills, how he was before the accident and after the accident, the balance was completely different'. Who knows how that £13m fee, exorbitant in retrospect, would have been viewed these days if he had not made the decision to drive back from a pre-season tournament in Genoa in August 1993?

But Lentini was just one symbol of a period in which the Italian game ruled both the pitch and the transfer market.

It was not even those headline signings that stand out to this day. Take Christian Vieri, for example.

The Bolognese striker was a good striker. But between 1991, when he made his debut for Torino, and 1997, he did not score more than 12 league goals in any campaign.

That did not stop him being at the centre of the market. Every year over an eight-year period, he switched clubs. Torino to Pisa. Pisa to Ravenna. Venezia to Atalanta. Atalanta to Juventus. 'Like Brigitte Nielsen', said Juventus owner Gianni Agnelli, 'he's not on the market.'

Wrong. Juventus sold him to Atletico Madrid, where he finally marked himself out as an elite goalscorer, with 24 goals in 24 La Liga games. But even then he did not settle, joining the nouveau riche of Lazio for £25m. 

Christian Vieri summed up the spending madness - here he signs for Atletico Madrid in 1997

Vieri played for nine clubs in nine years, including Juventus (left) and Lazio

The Italian striker poses at Inter Milan with another huge buy - £19m striker Ronaldo

Ronaldo's transfer proved Inter had enough cash to buy any player they fancied

That was not the end, as Inter Milan made a world-record bid of £32m, signed him and finally gave him a home. Once again, the Vatican weighed in on the fee. 'It is an offence to the poor,' wrote their official newspaper.

Sergio Cragnotti, Lazio's owner, was equally annoyed: 'I made a great economic sacrifice last year to take him to Rome. I did not expect such an attitude'.

Elio Di Cristofalo, a 25-year-old fan, was unable to get his head around the deal and threw himself under a train, leaving a note that read: 'Addio… I don't even know why I am still alive. Lazio have sold Vieri for £32m. All that money for a footballer, but money is not everything in life.'

ITALY'S WORLD-RECORD TRANSFER FEES AFTER 1990

£8million - Roberto Baggio, Fiorentina to Juventus (1990)

£10m - Jean-Pierre Papin, Marseille to AC Milan (1990)

£12m - Gianluca Vialli, Sampdoria to Juventus (1990)

£13m - Gianluigi Lentini, Torino to AC Milan (1990)

£19.5m - Ronaldo, Barcelona to Inter Milan (1996)

£32m - Christian Vieri, Lazio to Inter Milan (1999)

£35.5m - Hernan Crespo, Parma to Lazio (2000)

That sad tale aside, whatever clubs did, they simply could not seem to pin him down.

Until Inter. It was the first club he would stay with for more than a season, with Vieri eventually spending six years at the San Siro.

Not that Vieri had an incredible impact on the fortunes of the Milan club. The goals came – 103 in 143 league games – but Inter did not win Serie A again until after Vieri left.

Part of the Vieri project for Inter was the intention to partner him up with another world-record-breaking signing, Ronaldo. The Brazilian's arrival at the San Siro from Barcelona for £19.5m in 1997 just symbolised where Italian football was at this juncture – whoever was good, they took.

The pair never really worked together due to a series of injury problems. That was not the only challenge for Inter at that point.

Lazio may have lost Vieri in 1999 but they gained something far greater within a year – only the second scudetto in their entire history.

Cragnotti's arrival as owner in 1992 had changed the face of the club. He was responsible for Paul Gascoigne's signing, which had a big part to play in the United Kingdom's fascination with the Italian top flight.

Sven Goran Eriksson was the manager and built a brilliant attacking football side. He also had access to incredible resources, bringing in the likes of Marcelo Salas (£16m) and Juan Sebastian Veron (£18m).

In the summer of 1998 alone, he spent eight-figure fees on Vieri, Salas, Sinisa Mihajlovic, Dejan Stankovic and Ivan de la Pena. Sky blue shirts aside, the comparisons with a modern day Manchester City are obvious.

And even after they won the title, they were not sated. Crespo was snapped up from Parma in a world-record £35.5m deal.

Hernan Crespo shakes hands with Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti after signing for £35m

A year later, in 2001, Zinedine Zidane left Juventus for Real Madrid in a move that marked the end of the big Italian spending

In the end, the spending worked for Lazio. Over Eriksson's four years at the club, they won seven trophies. In their entire history to the point of the Swede's arrival in 1997, Lazio had captured just three pieces of silverware. 'It was very good because in Italy, if you win the league and you are not Milan, Inter or Juventus, it is a very big thing,' Eriksson recalled.

Lazio really marked the end of Italy's peak spending years. There were notable moves after that point. Gianluigi Buffon's £33m transfer to Juventus from Parma in 2001 was the highest fee paid for a goalkeeper until Ederson joined Manchester City this summer.

But it was probably symbolic when Real Madrid smashed the world transfer record that same year to pluck Zinedine Zidane from Juventus for £46.6m. The previous Italian dominance of the market was over. The real wealth now lay elsewhere.

Still, they'll always have the 1990s. And at least now the Vatican are not too busy on transfer deadline day.

CHRISTIAN VIERI - CV 

Torino (1990-93) 

AC Pisa (1992-3) - Loan

Ravenna (1993-94) - Undisclosed

Venezia 1907 (1994-95) - Undisclosed

Atalanta (1995-96) -  Undisclosed

Juventus (1996-97) - £2.2m

Atletico Madrid (1997-98) -  £12.5m

Lazio (1998-99) - £21.8m 

Inter Milan (1999-2005) - £32m

AC Milan (2005) - Free

Monaco (2006) - Free

Sampdoria (2006) - Free

Fiorentina (2007) - Free 

Atalanta (2008-09) - Free

item.title: There is only so far England can go at the World Cup without a playmaker
item.description: MARTIN SAMUEL - CHIEF SPORTS WRITER: Henderson may even be England’s captain at the World Cup. And, if he is, he will fulfil his role with the usual diligence and selflessness.
item.content:encoded:
This is not Jordan Henderson’s fault, but the moment when Gareth Southgate’s England plan may finally come to fruition is when he is no longer such an integral member of the side.

Henderson did well against Holland last week. He may even be England’s captain at the World Cup. And, if he is, he will fulfil his role with the usual diligence and selflessness. He will work hard, he will hold his position, he will use the ball to the best of his abilities; but it will not be enough.

To get out of the group, yes. England can overcome Tunisia and Panama just as they are and then the result against Belgium is largely immaterial.

Jordan Henderson will use the ball to the best of his abilities; but it will not be enough

Their knock-out round opponents will come from Group H and there is little to choose between Poland, Senegal, Colombia and Japan. England may well be happy in that company, too.

Yet in the quarter-finals it is different. If all goes to form, England will probably be matched with Germany or Brazil, at which point the limitations in midfield, in particular, are going to show.

There is only so far a team can travel without a gifted footballer at the heart of the team, a player who can keep possession and dictate the pace and flow of the game. England do not have that man. Henderson is not a fit and nor are his contemporaries.

Jack Wilshere is the nearest but is not at the level of, say, Toni Kroos and, even if he were, it is very hard for a manager to scheme his strategy around a player who could get injured crossing the tarmac to board the plane. Making Wilshere critical to England’s World Cup is a risk Southgate cannot afford to take.

So there is, in all probability, a limit to England’s ambitions right now. While Henderson is still the pivot of England’s midfield there is only going to be so far this team can go before games are taken away from them.

Making Jack Wilshere critical to England’s World Cup is a risk the boss cannot afford to take

It would need a stunning plan, and extraordinary shifts at the back and from the forwards, to overcome the absence of a playmaker. Henderson is doing all he can, but even on his best days the flaws are visible.

He made 91 passes against Holland, but 76 were sideways or backwards and only 15 moved the ball forward. Of those 15, just 10 were successful. Meaning Henderson’s accuracy suffers the more expansive he tries to become — and this was in a non-competitive game when he probably had more time on the ball.

Eric Dier, who could well be Henderson’s partner in the biggest games if Southgate plays safe against the stronger nations, is no more inventive and the attack-minded options, such as Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, who started the move that ended in Jesse Lingard’s goal in Amsterdam, are still not the type of individuals who dominate play.

Adam Lallana could not be relied upon to hold his position, Jake Livermore is willing but very average, and it appears Southgate was unimpressed with Danny Drinkwater’s decision to stay at Chelsea when called up to the squad towards the end of last year.

Of the younger options, Harry Winks has played six minutes of Premier League football for Tottenham since December 16, while Ruben Loftus-Cheek played a minute for Crystal Palace in their last match at Huddersfield, his comeback after an injury sustained in December.

He did well against Germany in November, but can hardly be saddled with being England’s Andres Iniesta in time for June, having missed the handful of opportunities to play international football since. Southgate may have to go with what he knows.

Gareth Southgate may have to go with what he knows and should be cut a little slack

And therefore, should be cut a little slack. For the first time since the days of Terry Venables and Glenn Hoddle, an England manager is trying to take the team in a new, and ambitious, direction.

Sven Goran Eriksson got England organised but, like Roy Hodgson, the football was functional. Fabio Capello had England looking good in qualifying, but lost his nerve and his way at the tournament in South Africa.

Steve McClaren came with big plans to change England’s system of play, making it more flexible, but one bad night in Zagreb frightened him off.

Southgate has had his scares, too, but is determined that England will evolve. And remember, in central midfield, Venables had Paul Gascoigne, Hoddle had Paul Scholes — if Southgate could choose from options like that, his problems would be solved. Instead, he has to find other routes to goal.

His forwards try to move the ball quickly, his defenders play out from the back. He used Kyle Walker and Kieran Trippier inventively against Holland, and the experiment worked, meaning more new ideas will be entertained with less scepticism. 

Undoubtedly, there is progress. If England are going through a relatively barren scoring spell — three goals in five games — that is because between the defensive and forward units is a patch of rough terrain.

Undoubtedly, there is progress but England are going through a relatively barren scoring spell 

No wonder England’s manager is so anxious to use the flanks, or to find ways for Henderson to get the ball in to the front players soonest.

Of course, lose to Tunisia and Panama and optimistic talk appears shallow. No matter the limitations of his squad, Southgate should be able to steer this team from Group G, even if they end up playing second fiddle to Belgium. Do that, however, and whatever happens next — even defeat — must be tempered by an acceptance of the ambition of his project.

Right now, this is a waiting game. Southgate is improving what he can but in other areas must make do until the player that makes the whole system fall into place comes along. He needs a playmaker. Until he gets one, England can never quite go forward as they should.

 

Danny Rose’s final ball was poor on Friday. He seemed to think the pitch at the Johan Cruyff Arena was 50 yards wider than it was.

If this continues, Manchester United’s Ashley Young has to be a better option, certainly in the matches in which the onus will be on England to attack.

The flanks are too important to this team to waste good positions.

Danny Rose seemed to think the pitch at the Johan Cruyff Arena was 50 yards wider than it was

 

Antonio Conte was right in saying it is not his concern whether Gary Cahill makes the World Cup squad. 

His job is to do what is best for Chelsea, not indulge Cahill’s personal ambitions. Anyway, if Cahill was playing well enough to be in the England squad, he would most likely be in Chelsea’s team, too.

If he is not, it suggests Southgate has better options elsewhere.

 

Apparently, Jose Mourinho’s bullying of Luke Shaw - and feel free to place mental air quotes around that statement - may affect Manchester United’s pursuit of Gareth Bale this summer. 

Let’s wait and see, shall we? If Bale is no longer required at Real Madrid and finds his elite Premier League options limited to Old Trafford alone, one imagines the agency that represents both the Welshman and Shaw, may be able to hold its nose, drag the reluctantly deal over the line, and take one for the team. They’re troopers like that. 

Real Madrid and Wales forward Gareth Bale has been linked with a move to Manchester United 

 

It's so glib to sneer at Manchester United for joining women's revolution 

Tracey Crouch, another in a long line of over-promoted Ministers for Sport, took to the Commons floor and welcomed the news with a sneer.

 ‘May I just actually take this opportunity to congratulate Manchester United Football Club, who have finally dragged themselves into the 21st century and announced that they will be having a women’s football team,’ she said.

It was pretty much the standard, unthinking reaction. Better late than never, was the consensus; or, about time too.

There is, however, another way of looking at it. That Manchester United Women was an idea whose time had come; a perfect example of the organic growth the women’s game needs if it is to become lastingly successful.

Too much of the debate around women’s football is spent in dead ends: wage parity with men’s teams that generate revenue in tens, sometimes hundreds, of millions. Prime-time broadcast slots for games with crowds measured in the hundreds.

Manchester United are set to take the historic step of forming a professional women's team

This is genuine, attainable, growth. Manchester United feel they are missing out. They have seen the rising popularity and interest in women’s football and think they need to be part of that.

Equally, there is a pragmatic concern. Once the two-tier Women’s Super League is up and running next season, any club wishing to join will have to start down the pyramid. 

This is the last chance for a club with good facilities and a ready-made professional structure to get in on the ground floor. Manchester United have applied to join the second tier: organic growth there, too. They know it will take time to build a club who can compete with the best in the country.

Manchester United need to walk before they can run. The club must develop in their own time, at their own speed.

So this is a very good thing for women’s football, a sign that the game cannot be ignored, but also that like all sports it must be allowed to progress and mature.

The news deserved more thought than it got from the Minister for Sport, a sentence that could have been written many times across many decades.

 

Root has to be much smarter 

A lot of blame is falling on white-ball cricket for making England increasingly weak in the Test arena, but game management remains a simple matter of intelligence. 

When Joe Root was struck on the right index finger by a ball from Trent Boult in the final over of the fourth day in Auckland, the smart move would have been to temporarily retire, seeking treatment. 

By the time his injury was inspected on the pitch, there was time for no more than the two balls left of that day’s play. Allow Craig Overton to see them out, head back to the hutch and re-emerge the following morning, fresh and rested. 

Joe Root was struck on the finger but decided to carry on and was dismissed next ball

Instead, Root stayed put and was dismissed next ball, England’s hopes of saving the match going with him. 

There was a decent bit of tail-end resistance on the last day, but it was always likely to be in vain without the captain. Had Root been available, who knows? New Zealand needed three wickets with just over 30 overs remaining. 

Make that four wickets and an unlikely, undeserved escape could have been on — particularly if one of the players still at the crease was the captain. 

This is nothing to do with the one-day game sapping technique, resilience or strategic thought. It was a purely rotten call. If Root is to achieve anything as England captain, he has to be smarter than this. 

 

One of the things Gareth Southgate should call a moratorium on before the World Cup is the ceaseless charting of his players’ appearances at club level. 

Not form, because form matters — but when they play, if they play, how many minutes they play, and whether this means they are overcooked or under-prepared. England players are either one or the other. 

It was once feared Marcus Rashford could burn out, now we worry he is lacking game time

They’re never just right, like the Goldilocks of international football — this one’s playing too much, this one’s not playing enough — and it just stacks up excuses for failure. One moment, it was feared Marcus Rashford could be burned out, now we worry he is lacking game time. 

Similarly, if it really matters whether Joe Hart is in West Ham’s team, then we might as well let England be run by a committee of 20 Premier League managers, because Southgate’s preferences are irrelevant. It is what it is: just get on with it. 

 

Last chance for Lee to salvage Masters dream 

Not including the special exemptions that are more to do with exploring new markets than merit — Shubhankar Sharma, a 21-year-old from India is this year’s lucky beneficiary —there are 18 ways to qualify for next month’s US Masters.

Lee Westwood has, as yet, not made it through one of them. He is one of just a trio of players to record three top-three Masters finishes in this decade, and has also been in the top 10 twice.

A year ago, he was one shot short of a score that would have equated to his 15th straight Masters qualification. Yet now he is 90th in the world and his last chance of a berth is at the Houston Open this week. He needs to win it.

There are 18 ways to qualify for The Masters and Lee Westwood must win at the Houston Open

So, while Sandy Lyle and Ian Woosnam will always be able to play as former champions, Martin Kaymer qualifies as part of a five-year exemption for US Open winners and the same for Jimmy Walker, world No 95 but victor in the 2016 PGA Championship, Westwood may be on the outside looking in. 

That does not mean he will never return to Augusta, but it rather pricks the idea that a great athlete’s time will come given patience.

Tottenham, with a crucial Premier League fixture at Chelsea on Sunday followed by an FA Cup semi-final on April 22, should take note. They start making it happen, or the good stuff will eventually pass them by.

 

Mark Jenkins, chief executive of West Brom, is appalled by the parlous state of the club’s finances. 

He says there is no more money for wages. That’ll be why those players were so keen to start up that mini-cabbing business in Spain then.
item.dc:abstract: MARTIN SAMUEL - CHIEF SPORTS WRITER: This is not Jordan Henderson’s fault, but the moment when Gareth Southgate’s England plan may finally come to fruition is when he is no longer such an integral member of the side. Henderson did well against Holland last week. He may even be England’s captain at the World Cup. And, if he is, he will fulfil his role with the usual diligence and selflessness. He will work hard, he will hold his position, he will use the ball to the best of his abilities; but it will not be enough. To get out of the group, yes. England can overcome Tunisia and Panama just as they are and then the result against Belgium is largely immaterial.

item.title: West Brom chief Mark Jenkins shocked by state of club's finances and admits: 'There is NO more money for wages'
item.description: West Brom chief executive Mark Jenkins admits the club have 'no more money for wages' and is shocked at the state of the Baggies. Albion are 10 points adrift of the Premier League safety line.
item.content:encoded:
West Brom chief executive Mark Jenkins admits the club have 'no more money for wages' and is shocked at the state of the Baggies.

Albion are 10 points adrift of the Premier League safety line with seven games left and are expected to be relegated.

Accounts filed up to June 2017 show pre-tax profits leap to £39.7million from £1m, only for Jenkins to warn about the future.

West Brom chief executive Mark Jenkins (right) has been left 'shocked' by the club's accounts

Jenkins, who was CEO under former owner Jeremy Peace, returned to the club to replace the sacked Martin Goodman when he was fired along with chairman John Williams in February.

He has painted a bleak picture at The Hawthorns and appeared to criticise the decisions of Goodman and Williams and ex-mananger Tony Pulis.

He told the club's official site: 'When I was on the outside looking in, for example, I read the reports about the club operating at the limit of its short term cost control (STCC).

'Knowing the business as I did, I thought that was a negotiating position but I've come back and can assure you that we are right at our limit on STCC. There is no more money for wages.

'We have wages, transfer fees and loan fees running at record levels and yet we find ourselves in this position.

'I'll be honest I've come back and I'm shocked at what I have found in some of the decisions that have been made.'

It was widely reported in January Albion had little cash to spend to aid their relegation fight and would have needed to sell Jonny Evans to bring in serious reinforcements.

Alan Pardew's side are set for relegation from the Premier League with a 10-point gap to safety

They are now set to lose Evans for £3million in the summer thanks to a relegation clause in his contract.

Gareth Barry's contract expires at the end of the season along with James Morrison, who is earning around £80,000-a-week.

Grzegorz Krychowiak will return to Paris St Germain in the summer after his loan ends with Albion having paid his £110,000-a-week wages in full for the season.

Claudio Yacob, Boaz Myhill and Gareth McAuley are also out of contract but Chris Brunt is expected to trigger a one-year extension in his next game.

Boss Alan Pardew is also clinging on to his job having replaced Pulis in November. Pardew has won just once in 17 Premier League games.

Jenkins, who confirmed owner Guochuan Lai remains committed, added: 'It's been painful looking in and seeing the club I and many, many other people had built up to be an established Premier League club....it has all unravelled in the 12 months or more since I've been away.'

West Brom will lose Jonny Evans in the summer for £3million because of a relegation clause

item.title: Bayern Munich got Pep Guardiola but have been turned down by Thomas Tuchel... the German coach is an ideal fit for Arsenal (despite feud with Gunners chief scout Sven Mislintat)
item.description: KIT HOLDEN: In 2013, Pep Guardiola surprised everyone by choosing Bayern Munich. Now, Thomas Tuchel has surprised everyone by turning the Bavarian giants down.
item.content:encoded:
A few years ago, it was Pep Guardiola; now it is Thomas Tuchel. 

A young football coach, known for his tactical innovation, has decided to take a gap year, and now all anybody wants to know is where he will go next.

In 2013, Guardiola surprised everyone by choosing Bayern Munich. Now, Thomas Tuchel has surprised everyone by turning them down. 

German tactician Thomas Tuchel is eyeing a return to management after a sabbatical year out

Despite drawing comparisons to Pep Guardiola, Tuchel rejected the chance to manage Bayern

The pair went head to head in the Bundesliga and soon may both be in the Premier League

For Bayern CEO Karl-Heinz Rummenigge, Tuchel was always the first choice to succeed caretaker coach Jupp Heynckes, and had finally persuaded president Uli Hoeness of his cause, before both men were left blushing when Tuchel reportedly turned them down this weekend.

It now seems certain that Tuchel will seek his fortune elsewhere in Europe. The question remains where. 

After Kicker reported on Sunday that he was bound for Arsenal, Sportbuzzer and Bild later claimed that Paris Saint-Germain were leading the race. Chelsea, too, are still in the running, with Antonio Conte set to leave in the summer.

Though he is still a long way off Guardiola’s greatness, there is little doubt that any of Europe’s top clubs would welcome Tuchel. 

On first glance, he appears to be the perfect modern coach. As cerebral as Guardiola, he also has the explosiveness of Jurgen Klopp. His style of play, a blend of patient possession and razor sharp turnovers. 

Off the pitch, too, he can slide seamlessly between slightly irritable, tracksuited German into elegant, style-conscious man of the world.

Most of all, though, Tuchel is a fine tactician. In between leaving Mainz and taking over at Dortmund, he famously met Guardiola for lunch at Munich’s Odeonsplatz. 

The two men, so the story goes, spent hours moving salt and pepper grinders around as they energetically discussed tactics.

Any club, then, would be glad to have him. The question which he must be asking himself is, where does he fit best? The answer, in many ways, is Arsenal. 

Tuchel is reportedly keen to coach abroad, and has been touted as Arsene Wenger's successor

Tuchel’s approach to football is not so far away from Arsene Wenger’s, and he would inherit a squad which, with a few additions and tweaks here and there, would be largely be ready to go. 

Tuchel famously transformed Henrikh Mkhitaryan at Dortmund, while Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang was the Bundesliga top-scorer in Tuchel’s second season.

Perhaps even more importantly, Tuchel would have freedom at Arsenal. If there is one big blemish on his reputation, it is that he has left both Mainz and Dortmund under a cloud. 

Despite leading Mainz into Europe and winning the German Cup with Dortmund, he is unlikely to ever be invited back, having fallen out dramatically with the hierarchy at both clubs. 

Tuchel, unlike Klopp, cannot play the role of company man, and he would almost certainly end up clashing in similar fashion with the bosses at Chelsea or PSG. 

Unlike Jurgen Klopp, who he succeeded at Mainz and Dortmund, Tuchel is not a company man

Arsenal, on the other hand, with their slightly less hands-on board, could offer him space to run the show, as they have done with Wenger for so long. There remains, however, one major reason why Tuchel would not go to Arsenal. 

Just a few months ago, Arsenal spent several million pounds luring Borussia Dortmund super scout Sven Mislintat to the Emirates. One of Mislintat’s biggest reasons for leaving his home club was the fallout from his clash with Tuchel. 

A power battle which centred around the failed signing of Atletico Madrid’s Oliver Torres and ended with Tuchel banning Mislintat from the training ground, Tuchel’s ongoing feud with Mislintat was a key element of his fall from grace at Dortmund.

The bad blood between Tuchel and the super scout is the most convincing argument against a move to Arsenal. 

Unai Emery and Conte, though, are also set to leave their respective positions this summer, and Tuchel could well end up at either PSG or Chelsea. If he does, then we should probably expect things to unfold in the following manner. 

His bad blood with Arsenal chief scout Sven Mislintat is the biggest obstacle to any move

Mislintat was banished from the training ground by Tuchel after a failed signing at Dortmund

Tuchel will arrive on a wave of excitement, build an enthralling football team and probably enjoy success which had eluded his predecessors. 

Yet within a few years, internal clashes with his employers and colleagues will become too much, and he will leave under a cloud, probably to take another gap year. 

He is, after all, the perfect modern football coach.

item.title: Dani Alves insists Philippe Coutinho is a 'player at the same level as Neymar' ahead of Brazil's clash with Germany
item.description: In Berlin on Tuesday evening, Brazil come face-to-face with Germany for the first time since they were humiliated by a 7-1 scoreline in the 2014 World Cup semi-final.
item.content:encoded:
Brazil captain Dani Alves has tipped Philippe Coutinho to inspire Brazil to a morale-boosting victory against Germany on Tuesday night and claimed the Barcelona playmaker is now on the same level as Neymar.

In Berlin on Tuesday evening, Brazil come face-to-face with Germany for the first time since they were humiliated by a 7-1 scoreline in the 2014 World Cup semi-final. 

It is only a friendly match but Brazil are stirred by haunting memories of a brutal defeat at their own World Cup in Belo Horizonte and the prospect of ending a German 22-match unbeaten record that extends back to the 2016 European Championships.

Dani Alves has sung the praises of Philippe Coutinho ahead of Brazil's game with Germany

PSG forward Neymar, the world's most expensive player, is absent through injury and Coutinho, who signed for Barcelona from Liverpool in January, will start from the left of a front-three alongside Chelsea winger Willian and Manchester City forward Gabriel Jesus.

PSG right-back Dani Alves, who is Neymar's team-mate for club and country and will captain Brazil tonight, said: 'I believe Coutinho is a player at the same level as Neymar, he has an incredible influence over our play and on our team. I felt this when he was at Liverpool and now at Barcelona. 

'He has really come on and learned well and improved his decision-making. It is a genuine pleasure to play alongside a player at that level and with that profile. We are very privileged to have these players.'

Brazil right back Alves claims that Coutinho 'is a player at the same level as Neymar'

Germany coach Joachim Low, who guided his side to the famous victory over Brazil, said: 'The 7-1 plays a bigger role in Brazil than for us. For us, it was a step to win the World Cup. We caught Brazil on a bad day.'  

Meanwhile, coach Tite says the scars of the defeat remain and this friendly against Germany forces his players to confront their demons.

He told Kicker magazine: 'This has a huge psychological meaning - no one needs to fool themselves about that. The 7-1 from the World Cup is like a ghost. It won't just be a sporting challenge, but a huge emotional challenge too.'   

Dani Alves added: 'We cannot change the past, so we should make the future.'

item.title: Jurgen Klopp roars with laughter as club photographer shows him picture of young fan dressed as Liverpool boss
item.description: A young Liverpool supporter called Jay imitated a thumbs up pose, dressed in Klopp's trademark cap and tracksuit top, wore glasses and even had stubble drawn on to his face.
item.content:encoded:
Jurgen Klopp roared with laughter after being shown a picture of a fan dressed up in his likeness.

A young Liverpool supporter called Jay imitated a thumbs up pose, dressed in Klopp's trademark cap and tracksuit top, wore glasses and even had stubble drawn on to his face.

He was going to school as his hero for Sport Relief day and Jay chose the charismatic Reds boss.

Young Liverpool supporter Jay imitated his hero as he dressed up as Jurgen Klopp

Klopp was shown a picture of his young fan by the club photographer and loved it

And Klopp appeared to love what he saw as the club's photographer showed him the picture on his phone.

The pair fell about laughing, suggesting Jay's imitation had hit the nail on the head.

It seemed the amusing snap provided an uplifting moment during Liverpool training on a sunny Monday afternoon at Melwood.  

The German studied his image and the lengths Jay had gone to in pretending to be him

No doubt Klopp appreciated the drawn on stubble as an added touch from the youngster

The German was overseeing members of his squad not currently on international duty.

The likes of Danny Ings, Alberto Moreno and Joel Matip were all looking to press home their claims for first-team action with most of the first team away.

Liverpool have a tough run of fixtures coming up starting with a trip to Crystal Palace this weekend. The Reds then have the Merseyside derby sandwiched in between their Champions League quarter-final against Manchester City.

James Milner (left), Nathaniel Clyne (centre) and Alberto Moreno trained at Melwood

item.title: Max Verstappen blasts 'boring and completely worthless' Australian Grand Prix, claiming he would have switched off had he been an F1 fan
item.description: Max Verstappen hit out at Sunday's Australian Grand Prix as being a waste of time to supporters following a race featuring little overtaking action at Albert Park.
item.content:encoded:
Max Verstappen hit out at Sunday's Australian Grand Prix as being a waste of time for supporters following a race featuring little overtaking action at Albert Park.

The Dutchman endured a frustrating afternoon stuck behind Fernando Alonso and despite possessing a much superior car could find no way past the fifth-placed McLaren.

It was not just the Red Bull driver who struggled to make an overtake, as many drivers up and down the grid struggled in Melbourne, including Lewis Hamilton who was pipped to victory by Sebastian Vettel.

Max Verstappen shares a discussion with former F1 driver and TV pundit Mark Webber 

Verstappen spent much of the race stuck behind the McLaren of Fernando Alonso

When asked how he felt fans saw the race, Verstappen told motorsport.com: 'Completely worthless. I would have turned off the TV.

'[It was] very boring. You do your best to try something, and I was in DRS range all the time, but there is nothing you can do.'

It was not just a McLaren rear wing Verstappen was stuck behind. The Dutchman spent almost the entire afternoon stuck in traffic having been overtaken by the Haas of Kevin Magnussen at the start.

The Dutchman had earlier been left frustrated trying to pass the Haas of Kevin Magnussen

After frustration built inside the Red Bull cockpit, Verstappen ended up spinning at turn one

A spin at turn one put the Dutchman further back before he eventually finished sixth.  

'[The Haas cars] were a second slower than the Ferraris. They were just lucky that they came in front of us,' Verstappen added.

'And here you can't overtake. Look at Hamilton and Vettel. And the same story with Alonso. They were also much slower, but you can't pass them. You try, but it doesn't make any difference.

'Even if you are one-and-a-half seconds faster, it's still not possible to overtake.'
item.dc:abstract: Max Verstappen hit out at Sunday's Australian Grand Prix as being a waste of time to supporters following a race featuring little overtaking action at Albert Park. The Dutchman endured a frustrating afternoon stuck behind Fernando Alonso and despite possessing a much superior car could find no way past the fifth placed McLaren. It was not just the Red Bull driver who struggled to make an overtake, as many drivers up and down the grid struggled in Melbourne including Lewis Hamilton who was pipped to victory by Sebastian Vettel.
