item.title: The incredible story of Gigi Meroni: Italy's answer to George Best who at just 24 was killed after being hit by a car driven by adoring teenage Torino fan – who then became club president!
item.description: Those who saw him play and those who simply saw the grainy footage do not hesitate to describe Gigi Meroni as a football genius. With a Beatles haircut, they called him Italy’s George Best.
item.content:encoded:
Those who saw him play and those who simply saw the grainy footage do not hesitate to describe Gigi Meroni as a football genius. 

With his socks down and a Beatles haircut they called him Italy's George Best.

He was a dashing winger and an antidote to the turgid tactical system of catenaccio and yet this was only a fraction of his appeal.

Gigi Meroni was a dashing winger in the Sixties who was Italy's answer to George Best

Italian star Meroni (right) was an antidote to the turgid tactical system of catenaccio

He was a splash of colour, who refused to conform in an austere post-war society 

Meroni was also a cultural icon, a splash of colour from the Swinging Sixties in an otherwise austere post-war society and fiercely Catholic nation.

He refused to conform, sparking one scandal by living with his married girlfriend and another by refusing to cut his hair before the World Cup in 1966.

As many tutted their disapproval, he casually poked fun at his critics by taking a hen for a stroll on a lead near Lake Como and trying to get the creature into a bathing suit.

Meroni was the original rebel of Italian football, long before Mario Balotelli or Antonio Cassano.

He would have turned 75 last month but was dead at 24, killed in October 1967 when struck by a car as he crossed a street in Turin with team-mate Fabrizio Poletti.

They had beaten Sampdoria 4-2 that day and had stopped for a drink on the way back to the Meroni's loft apartment.

He was the original rebel of Italian football, long before Mario Balotteli or Antonio Cassano

The dazzling Torino winger once took a hen on a stroll on a lead near Lake Como

They were crossing the broad Corso Re Umberto when they paused in the centre, aware of a car moving quickly towards them on the second carriageway.

They took a step back, into the path of a 124 Fiat Coupe. Meroni was sent flying through the air and was hit again, by a vehicle travelling in the opposite direction and dragged along the road.

He died later in hospital with both legs and his pelvis broken and injuries to his chest and head.

The Fiat was driven by Attilio Romero, a teenage Torino fan who adored Meroni and lived only a few doors away.

Romero's home was adorned with flags of his favourite team and posters of his hero. There was even said to be a picture of Meroni taped to the rear window of the car.

More than 50 years have passed but the memory refuses to fade.

'I can remember everything,' says Romero. 'I was near my house, on a large avenue and I was going to overtake a car on my right.

However, the star's life was cut short – he was killed at the age of 24 when struck by a car

Thousands of adoring supporters turned out for the funeral of the Torino winger

The car was driven by Attilio Romero, who went on to become president of the Italian club

'In the middle of the roadway there were two pedestrians crossing the road. When I am close, one of them takes a step backwards, takes the impact and is thrown onto the other side where he is hit by another car.

'I pull over and I stop. Then I realise the pedestrian lying on the asphalt is my idol.

'Then the sirens, the ambulances, the hospital, the surgery and the death of Meroni in the night. His life was over and mine was a bit too.'

Only hours before, Romero had been cheering on Torino and fighting with another fan who dared to criticise Meroni.

Weeks earlier, he had been on a protest march to the home of Torino president Orfeo Pianelli and the mansion of Gianni Agnelli, the president of Juventus, who had agreed a deal to move the star across the city for 750million lire.

Some claim Fiat workers, many of whom supported Torino although the company owned Juventus, were prepared to strike in protest at the transfer.

Meroni's death brought Turin to a halt. More than 20,000 turned out for the funeral. One fan later attempted to break into his tomb, apparently refusing to believe the truth.

Romero, who idolised Meroni, insisted that his own life was over after hitting the Italian

Romero described Meroni as a 'free and eccentric spirit in a traditionalist city'

The former winger draws a design for a dinner jacket as he relaxes at his home in Torino

'I do not know how much my life was changed,' Romero told Sportsmail. 'Certainly for 50 years I have lived with a memory that is a mix of pain, disbelief, inexplicability, and then gradually sadness, regrets and unanswered questions.

'Even affection for an extraordinary human being who became my absolute idol and my victim, and the victim of me, involuntarily guilty in a story in which we were the two tragic protagonists.

'Meroni had a natural aesthetic originality, in clothing, in hair, in his free and spontaneous ways of relating to people, he was also a good artist, a quality painter, and his lifestyle was in line with this anti-conformism.

'He was a free and eccentric spirit in a traditionalist city.

'From the football point of view, Meroni was a champion, an Italian George Best, socks lowered, excellent dribbling, fast, technically very gifted. As quick as the wind. A pleasure for the eyes.

'If he played today, he would be a football genius just like then. The class is timeless.'

Meroni's proposed transfer to Juventus was called off when he told Torino he was happy to stay.

Meroni (centre) won only six Italy caps due to a fractious relationship with Edmondo Fabbri

The Italian idol, who was born in Como in 1943, paints a self portrait in his studio at home 

At Torino, they called him 'crimson butterfly', in reference to the deep red colour of their shirts

He was born in Como, where he started his career before moving to Genoa, where he was once banned for five games for skipping a drug test where team-mates tested positive.

At the age of 21 he was sold to Torino, then coached by Nereo Rocco, who had led AC Milan to the European Cup and had vowed to restore the glories of the Grande Torino team lost in the Superga air disaster.

His signing was proof of this ambition but the closest they came was to finish third in 1965 and, two years later, Rocco was back at Milan.

Meroni won only six caps for Italy, often attributed to a fractious relationship with manager Edmondo Fabbri, a disciplinarian who frowned upon his outlandish behaviour and seemed especially troubled by his hairstyle.

'I hope I might play well, even with long hair,' shrugged Meroni, who was recalled to the squad for the 1966 World Cup, although would play in only one match, against the USSR.

He avoided the humiliating defeat against North Korea at Middlesbrough but found he was scapegoated by some who decided he was a bad influence and blamed his refusal to get on with Fabbri as a reason Italy did not have one of their best players in the team.

At Torino, they called him the 'Farfalla Granata', the 'crimson butterfly' in reference to the deep red colour of Torino's shirts.

It became the title of the most famous book about Meroni, written by Nando dalla Chiesa, which was turned into a film five years ago.

His legend has thrived. His image can often be seen and they sing his name at Torino, a club still unable to live up to or let go of the ghosts of its glorious past.

The first fixture after his death was the derby against Juventus. Flowers were dropped into the stadium from an aeroplane and placed on the right wing, the crowd chanted Gigi's name and Torino won 4-0.

The winger is pictured driving his convertible while his son sits on the passenger seat

The Italian icon floats while bathing in the sea as he enjoys a break from his football duties

Meroni enjoys some quality downtime with his son while sitting on a deckchair on holiday

Three were scored by Nestor Combin, Meroni's close friend, who had been suffering a fever on the day before the game before making a miraculous recovery, and the fourth by the player wearing the No 7 shirt.

Since 2007, there has been a monument in his honour at the spot where he was killed in Corso Re Umberto.

Romero, by a strange twist befitting a compelling tragedy, would go on to become president of Torino at the turn of the century until the club were declared bankrupt, in 2005.

Now, at 69, he says: 'The anguish of 50 years ago has been gradually blurred by sadness and in a silent astonishment for a story that will never have an explanation.

'I don't believe a lot in destiny, rather in chance, but there are two clues to suggest the first hypothesis.

'The commander of the plane that crashed into Superga in 1949 with the Grande Torino team aboard was called Luigi Meroni.

'Also, my father told me, a few days before the accident he had a dream that I was driving my car when I hit an animal, a bull, which is the symbol of Torino Calcio.

'Here we enter the field of the inexplicable and then I stop'. 

Meroni's legend has thrived, his image can often be seen and they sing his name at Torino

item.title: David Warner has 'gone rogue, swilling champagne in hotel bar and removed himself from team WhatsApp group' in the heat of Australia's ball-tampering shame as players travel to Johannesburg
item.description: The revelations are the latest in a series to emerge during an extraordinary few days as the disgraced Australia side arrived at Cape Town International airport under a police escort.
item.content:encoded:
Australia vice-captain David Warner has caused further outrage by partying in the team hotel in Cape Town in the aftermath of the ball-tampering scandal.

The revelations are the latest in a series to emerge during an extraordinary few days as the disgraced Australia side arrived at Cape Town International airport under a police escort.

Warner, captain Steve Smith, under-pressure coach Darren Lehmann and Cameron Bancroft were all pictured in the departure lounge ahead of travelling to Johannesburg for the fourth Test against South Africa on Friday. 

David Warner, pictured at the airport in Cape Town, could be left out of the fourth Test as a result of his role in the incident

Steve Smith also arrived at the airport ahead of travelling to Johannesburg for the final Test despite being banned

Coach Darren Lehmann arrived at Cape Town International airport under a police escort as they traveled to Johannesburg

Cameron Bancroft, at the centre of the ball-tampering storm, is pictured in front of fast bowler Mitchell Starc

Warner has 'gone rogue' according to reports in Australia after the ball-tampering saga that has engulfed the side

Warner has emerged as the central figure in an episode that has embarrassed Australian cricket and brought widespread condemnation, as revealed by Sportsmail. 

Fox Sports Australia claim the disgraced batsman, set to be left out of the team for the final Test, has outraged team-mates by 'swilling champagne in the bar of the team hotel with non-cricket mates'.

Several of them, described as 'furious' want him 'removed' from the hotel on the Cape Town waterfront.

They also report that Warner removed himself from a WhatsApp group between the players and has 'gone rogue' after the story broke over the weekend.

Captain Steve Smith admitted that Australia deliberately attempted to change the condition of the ball during play on the third day of the third Test.

Smith is questioned by a reporter as he makes his way through Cape Town International airport on Tuesday morning

Disgraced captain Steve Smith was pictured leaving the team hotel on Tuesday morning ahead of the fourth Test

Steve Smith (right) was pictured at Australia's team hotel in Cape Town on Monday looking relaxed in shorts and T-shirt

The Australia captain checks his phone in the hotel with pressure growing over his future as captain of the Test side

Cameron Bancroft was caught by TV cameras rubbing sticky yellow tape on the ball, with Smith admitting afterwards it was a premeditated move by 'the leadership group'.

Australia were thrashed by 322 runs and find themselves 2-1 down in the four-match series ahead of the final Test, starting on Friday. 

Smith and Warner are both facing lengthy bans from the team with Cricket Australia chiefs in South Africa leading an investigation into the incident.

Smith was handed a one-match suspension by the ICC and is set to be stripped of the captaincy.

Chief executive James Sutherland landed in South Africa on Tuesday morning and will hear the outcome of a probe into Saturday's incident from team performance head Pat Howard and integrity chief Iain Roy after the pair spent Monday in Cape Town interviewing the players.

Vice-captain Warner has outraged team-mates by his antics in the Cape Town waterfront hotel since the third Test ended

Team-mates of Warner, pictured alongside wife Candice in January 2017, reportedly want him out of the hotel

Australia admitted to deliberately attempting to change the condition of the ball on the third day of the third Test

Cameron Bancroft was seen running his hand over the ball, before removing a yellow object from his pocket and placing it down the front of his trousers

Cricket Australia will announce the punishments on Tuesday at a news conference in Johannesburg, where the team will arrive earlier in the day to prepare for the fourth Test.

The position of coach Darren Lehmann also hangs in the balance despite Smith's denial of any involvement by the coach.  

Earlier in the day Matt Renshaw was drafted into the squad for the fourth Test and could be the first of many call-ups as the controversy continues.

Warner has emerged as the central figure in Australia's ball-tampering controversy following events of the Cape Town Test

It revolves around the strapping Warner wears on the thumb and index finger which is used to rough up one side of the ball

Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said on Tuesday he had spoken to Cricket Australia chairman David Peever and demanded swift action on the ball-tampering incident, which he described as a 'shocking affront to Australia' and a 'terrible disgrace'.

He also spoke out against the practice of 'sledging' opponents, something Lehmann and his team have defended as part of the game and which had already contributed to a souring of relations with South Africa in this series.

'I think there has to be the strongest action taken against this practice of sledging,' Turnbull told reporters in Canberra.

'It has got right out of control, it should have no place in the game, I want to be very clear about this. The game of cricket should be one that once again is held up as a role model.

'I think that some of the sledging, as some of the shocking conduct that we have seen, is also part of the process of review and reflection that is going to be undertaken.'

Smith and Warner are facing lengthy bans for their respective roles in the scandal that has rocked world cricket

item.title: The glory days of Gazzetta Football Italia: Forget the Premier League, in the 1990s the only show in town starred Gazza, a snake, James Richardson and the primeval roar of 'Golazzo!' (Or was it 'Go Lazio?')
item.description: CHRIS CUTMORE: 1992. A whole new ball game. Football, alive and kicking. But anyone listening to the battle cries of the school playground would know that we weren’t watching the Premier League.
item.content:encoded:
All this week Sportsmail will be celebrating Italian football in the 1990s, in the build-up to BT Sport's new documentary on the glory days of Serie A. Our tribute starts with CHRIS CUTMORE'S homage to Gazzetta Football Italia - the show that helped Britain fall in love with Italian football...

In the 1990s, Serie A was the best league in the world, featuring the likes of Ruud Gullit

 

1992. A whole new ball game. Football, alive and kicking. But anyone listening to the battle cries of the school playground would know that we weren't watching the Premier League.

The team on everyone's lips was not Liverpool, Manchester United, Tottenham or Chelsea, or even one from these shores. It was not even the biggest team in Rome. Back then every ball, or so it seemed, booted between jumpers for goalposts provoked the same celebration: 'Gooooooooooo Lazio!'

It was all thanks to Channel 4's Football Italia, and its sister show, Gazzetta Football Italia. Its title sequence – and particularly the climactic primal scream of 'Golazzo!' - left such an impression that confused schoolchildren up and down the country could not stop shouting Lazio's name.

Channel 4's Italian football broadcasts started with an iconic title sequence

The glamorous locations and superstar players enthralled English football fans in the 90s

The formation of the Premier League and its poaching by Sky meant a generation were starved of live, top-level English football. 

Everyone knew one kid who had Sky, but their resulting arrogance tended to mean you wouldn't want to go round their house to watch it. 

Match of the Day highlights were the only access to the new Premier League, while terrestrial TV was left to show live Football League matches. Super Sunday meant Port Vale vs Grimsby.

A canny Channel 4 executive spotted the gap in the market and snapped up the TV rights to Serie A for peanuts. The shows used all the momentum of Italia 90 like a skateboarder grabbing the back of a bus and became a big hit: three million tuned in for the first live match — a 3-3 draw between Sampdoria and Lazio. We were hooked.

The title sequence started with pumping music and shouted Italian football phrases 

A rumble of drums, a blaring horn, a crowd cheering. This is how it started. A football (black and white panelled, like they should always be) shoots through the air, trailing vapour, towards a giant Channel 4 emblem. The ball strikes hard and bruises it red, white and green.

A strangled synth riff kicks in, followed by a thumping house beat and wails of electric guitar — Definitive Two's 'I'm Stronger Now' (the 7' version, released on Deconstruction in 1992, if you're interested). 

Blurred images of whirling footballers flash past, but not before a much more important shot of a bald referee and linesman. Exotic, indecipherable words jump out from the screen: Milan in testa, tifosi, il divino codino, Gazza.

Then the verbal assault. 'CAMPIONATO! DI CALCIO! ITALIANO!'

And, finally, the scream: 'GOOOOOOOOLAZZO!'

It ended with a roar of 'Golazzo!' - Italian for 'great goal' and a phrase that became iconic

Turns out we all had it all wrong. This was not an undisguised ode to Lazio, but a bellowed version of a terrace roar that translates, as one Italian speaker said recently, as: 'Triffic goal'. (The producers of the title sequence had it wrong too; their subtitle read: 'Gol accio.')

'Go Lazio' would, however, have made a lot of sense. It was just two years after Italia 90, the tournament that proved football was more than just tiny shorts and street fighting. It had made superstars of Paul Gascoigne and Pavarotti, and one of the two had just signed for a Serie A club. Yes, Gazza. And yes, for Lazio.

Gascoigne was even signed up to be the host for Gazzetta Football Italia, the magazine show that rounded up all the latest goals, news and transfer stories from the week before the live match on Sunday's Football Italia. 

The 'Gazzetta' element was a play on both Gazza's name and the pink-paged Italian sports newspaper that became iconic thanks to the show: La Gazzetta dello Sport.

Gazza's starring role, unsurprisingly, did not last long. As Dino Zoff, the legendary goalkeeper who was the England midfielder's coach at Lazio, put it: 'He ate ice cream for breakfast, drank beer for lunch and when injured blew up like a whale.'  

Paul Gascoigne was intended to be the presenter of Gazzetta Football Italia after joining Lazio

Gazza celebrates his greatest moment in Italy, a last-minute goal in the Rome derby

In other words, he was barely fit to play football let alone present a show about it. Although he probably could have gotten away with it on Men and Motors. 

Despite his questionable off-field habits, Italy and England were still in love with Gazza. His first game for Lazio saw him score an injury-time equaliser in the Rome derby, the stuff of fantasy, except in Gazza's world. 

His fans back in England lapped up the chance to follow his exploits in the best league in the world.

And his brief presenting career yielded some notable highlights: a tour around a zoo, featuring a terrified Gazza's close encounter with a python, and a lion nearly biting his fingers off; plus a glorious exchange that contained the phrase: 'I know that story about you and the goat.'

Gazza was no longer the frontman, but that accidentally opened the door to an Italian-speaking producer who stumbled into the glare of the camera. James Richardson took over the role and before you could say 'eroe popolare' became a cult hero. Or cultured hero perhaps.

Always playing up to the camera, Gazza here uses a hose in a creative manner

Gazza did not last long in the role, but he still featured heavily, such as in this skit with a snake

Cool, cheeky and dressed like he was auditioning for a part in a remake of Dirty Rotten Scoundrels, Richardson's wit, knowing glances to camera and playful mickey-taking sat somewhere on the spectrum between Des Lynam and Baddiel and Skinner, the other masters of 90s football presenting. 

Take, for example, his teasing of Gianluca Vialli about bald men being sexier, or a line about Daniele Massaro's transfer from AC Milan to Shimizu S-Pulse - 'Sounds like a Japanese reggae band...' This was when football could be presented with a smirk, a nod and a wink, rather than earnest bluster and blistering barnacles.

Always close to a giant pastry, cappuccino or the biggest gelato anyone had ever clapped eyes on, Richardson leafed through the pink pages of Gazzetta and told us about the latest madcap events in Italy: where Roberto Baggio was heading next; a row between Fabio Capello and pretty much everyone; armed robbers holding up Roma's ticket office during a match and getting away with £250,000; Luther Blissett being accused of witchcraft. Only in Italy. 

James Richardson (right) became the host - here he is seen with Juventus' Gianluca Vialli

Richardson leafing through the latest big football stories in the Gazzetta dello Sport paper

Gazza would join Richardson for a memorable sequence where he joked about his own failings

Its cocktail of goals, controversies, managerial meltdowns and transfer rumours was pretty much the template for what coverage of the Premier League is now, but years ahead of its time. And while ardent fans of the English top flight were watching Brian Deane, Andy Ritchie and Dean Holdsworth, Football Italia viewers had Gianfranco Zola, Gabriel Batistuta and Ronaldo.

The AC Milan team of Marco van Basten, Ruud Gullit, Frank Rijkaard, Franco Baresi, Paolo Maldini, Zvonimir Boban et al might still claim to be the best ever seen on the Continent. They were certainly the coolest, God-like in devilish red and black stripes. Even Richardson's pronunciation of 'Meelan' added an extra layer of romance.

Serie A was home to nearly every superstar of the era, snapped up by super-rich owners and clubs ready to flash huge wads of cash thanks to a bonanza in TV broadcasting rights stakes (sound familiar?).

Italy even had a whole type of player never seen in English football: a free-spirited, super-talented playmaker, given license to roam free — or stay put as was often the case — in the hope that just a few moments of their magic would decide a game. They were called 'fantasista'.

Roberto Mancini, Juan Sebastian Veron, Rui Costa, Alessandro Del Piero, Francesco Totti and, of course, the divine-ponytailed demigod of No 10s, Baggio all fitted the mould.

Even the supporting cast was box office: Beppe Signori and his thunderous left foot, the folically-challenged Popeye Attilio Lombardo, Sinisa Mihajlovic, a defender whose left foot conjured greater goals than most forwards, with the exception of the ludicrously talented but forever frustrating Alvaro Recoba. Other names were forever etched into impressionable minds: Daniel Fonseca, Fabrizio Ravanelli, Moreno Torricelli.

Ronaldo and Roberto Baggio (pictured here in 1997) were two of the superstars of the era 

Gabriel Batistuta - 'Batigol' - was another superstar striker, for Fiorentina and Roma

The league was so strong that seven teams could realistically challenge for the title most seasons: Milan and Juventus always top of the pile, followed by a combination of Inter, Fiorentina, Lazio, Roma and a Parma team that ranks as one of the greatest anywhere in Europe to have never won a league title. (Buffon, Cannavaro, Thuram, Sensini, Dino Baggio, Veron, Crespo, Chiesa, Fiore. Staggering).

In addition to Gazza, there was a further sprinkling of top-class English talent to be proud of: Paul Ince at Inter, David Platt at Bari, Juventus and Sampdoria, where Des Walker also had an, albeit less successful, spell.

Platt was the biggest hit. 'I want to be an Italian. To speak Italian, live like an Italian, eat like an Italian,' he said, an admirable attitude although marred somewhat during a Gazzetta feature in which he cooked spaghetti at home, yet was seen adding powdered garlic to his mushrooms. Not exactly the way Mama used to make it.

David Platt, one of England's best footballing exports to Italy, cooks at home for the show

Platt and many other players took part in quirky and often hilarious interviews

Gazetta's light-hearted skits were a remarkable accomplishment in retrospect. Platt dressing up as the Terminator, Lombardo dancing the Lambarda, Vialli wearing a wig and Gazza suggesting some sort of sexual peccadillo involving kitchen utensils.

The cherry on the cake was the fabulous sing-song commentary of Peter Brackley, and Kenneth Wolstenholme describing last week's thriller between Foggia and Atalanta before a gentle ribbing by Richardson: 'Kenneth's round up was so exciting I had to go and change my trousers.'

It was so good even Elvis Costello memorably dropped in to watch the Derby della Lanterna - Genoa vs Sampdoria – cracking an incomprehensible joke about 'Gianluca Vialli' translating into English as 'Peter Beardsley'. 

Of course Richardson cut off his pop idol's punditry by saying: 'Unfortunately Elvis, you're very much a man Out of Time.' 

Even Elvis Costello dropped in as a special guest for one Derby della Lanterna

In an era of no cheap flights when a foreign holiday meant a queasy ferry trip to Normandy, Football Italia was a window into an unattainably glamorous world where football was played not on mud but grass, would you believe it, and with such passion that goals provoked that unforgettable celebratory cry.

And while we're on that subject, Richardson revealed a further twist years later. 'As for the theme tune, even though I assumed it was 'GOLAZO' they were using a Jose Altafini bit of commentary,' he told The I last year. 'The composer did confirm, years later, that he was basically saying 'Go Lazio'. I assumed through the 10 years that there was no way he could possibly be doing that!'

Turns out us schoolkids were right all along then. Go Lazio.
item.dc:abstract: CHRIS CUTMORE: 1992. A whole new ball game. Football, alive and kicking. But anyone listening to the battle cries of the school playground would know that we weren’t watching the Premier League. The team on everyone’s lips was not Liverpool, Manchester United, Tottenham or Chelsea, or even one from these shores. It was not even the biggest team in Rome. Back then every ball, or so it seemed, booted between jumpers for goalposts provoked the same celebration: ‘Gooooooooooo Lazio!’ It was all thanks to Channel 4’s Football Italia, and its sister show, Gazzetta Football Italia. Its title sequence – and particularly the climactic primal scream of ‘Golazzo!’- left such an impression that confused schoolchildren up and down the country could not stop shouting Lazio’s name.

item.title: Australia's baggy green is tainted by captain Steve Smith's snarl
item.description: NASSER HUSSAIN: It is often said that the captain of the Australian cricket team is the second-most important job in the country after the Prime Minister. It's why an entire nation is so outraged.
item.content:encoded:
It is often said that the captain of the Australian cricket team is the second-most important job in the country after the Prime Minister. It's why an entire nation is so outraged by Steve Smith admitting he tried to cheat.

In England, you are very aware as a cricketer that you operate in the shadow of football. But when you arrive in Australia, things are different. I've always said that an Ashes tour is about more than taking on a team — it's taking on an entire country. And at the head of it all is the captain, the man who dictates the team's culture. Australians take the position very seriously.

And while they expect the captain to ensure their team play hard, they also expect them to play fair. That's why this hurts so much. All the Aussie captains of recent years have done their best to impose their stamp on the team. When Allan Border took over in the 1980s, they were a mediocre side, but he set about making them incredibly tough. 

Steve Smith admitted his side tampered with the ball during the third Test against South Africa

Border was good friends with Graham Gooch from their time at Essex, but when he captained Australia in England in 1989, he walked past Gooch as if he didn't exist. He was fed up with being a good loser — and Border is now held in the highest regard.

His successor Mark Taylor is someone I have a great deal of respect for. He didn't ease up on what Border did, but turned the Australians into winners. His tactical acumen was second to none. And then came Steve Waugh.

His challenge was to take the team to the next level, which wasn't easy. So he made a big thing about the culture of the baggy green cap. He made sure his players knew about the history they were buying into, and the fact that they were just passing through. There were times when I found it all a bit much. 

The Australian captain (right) addresses the media alongside opener Cameron Bancroft

I felt as if Waugh was lecturing other sides about how the Australian way was the best, and how they were mentally tougher than everyone else.

I wanted to turn round and say: 'Hang on, you're in charge of possibly the best side in history. You've got Hayden, Langer, Ponting, Waugh, Gilchrist, Warne and McGrath. It has nothing to do with mental toughness!'

Once, Waugh and a couple of his team-mates turned up to Wimbledon wearing their baggy greens. I have to say it all felt a bit sickly. But Waugh did the job. His side went on a record run, and raised the bar.

I never had much to do with Ricky Ponting when we were up against each other, but what I do know from working with him in commentary boxes is that he is someone I would want with me in the trenches. 

Former captain Allan Border set about making his Australia side incredibly tough in the 1980s

Border's successor Mark Taylor (right) turned the Australians into winners while captain

Every Australian captain feels obliged to leave his mark on the team, because that's what the public expect. And it's why, I think, Steve Smith's side have taken the route they have taken. Along with coach Darren Lehmann and vice-captain David Warner, Smith probably decided the Australian side were in danger of regressing to the time in the mid-1980s when they lost more often than they won. So he decided to reinstate some of the snarl, a bit like Border did so successfully.

I don't have a problem with that, but in Smith's case it's all gone too far. They've operated in such a bubble that they've lost sight of what's right and wrong.

Previous Australian sides have come close to the line. Border was in charge when Merv Hughes abused everyone, and there were nasty moments with Shane Warne and Glenn McGrath.

But those sides didn't get themselves into a tangle like Smith's team have. If you gave it back to them and performed well, they would show you respect. It was a two-way thing. That's been lost under Smith, whose players seem to think the opposition shouldn't fight back, and believe they are above the law. Their public expect better. As captain of Australia, Smith is on a pedestal. His mistake has been to forget that.

item.title: Antoine Griezmann is on his way to Barcelona… but where will they fit him in alongside Lionel Messi, Luis Suarez, Ousmane Dembele and Philippe Coutinho?
item.description: Few transfers have been so heralded before they have actually happened. The Catalans have done their best not to crow about the fact that they are convinced they are getting Griezmann in the summer.
item.content:encoded:
Few transfers have been so heralded before they have actually happened as Antoine Griezmann's to Barcelona. The Catalans have done their best not to crow about the fact that they are convinced they are getting him in the summer. Atletico have done their best not to public mourn his almost inevitable departure.

Until the signing is complete there is always the possibility of a U-turn from the player but it seems unlikely either side will put out and it may well be that they would face contractual financial compensation claims if they did.

The No 7 shirt is waiting for him at the Camp Nou – Barcelona believe they are getting one of the 'best of the rest' players in the world, at his peak signing age 27 and at a very generous €100m (£87.31m) buy-out clause.

France forward Antoine Griezmann is set to join Barcelona from Atletico Madrid this summer

Griezmann, seen in training on Sunday, will cost Barca the value of his €100m buy-out clause

Former Real Sociedad star Griezmann star is expected to take the No 7 shirt at the Nou Camp

Griezmann feels he is ready for the biggest move of his career, playing alongside Lionel Messi at one of the two stadiums he has always dreamed about calling home – the other being Old Trafford.

His arrival makes three things certain. Firstly, players will need to be sold. His arrival will open the floodgates with up to five forward or midfield players departing the club if buyers can be found.

Secondly, both Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele will have to get used to not playing every game. If they thought being the club's two most expensive ever signings would grant them that right then they were wrong.

And thirdly, this is another signal towards the gradual morphing of Messi into a midfielder. There will be times when he takes up a position closer to Sergio Busquets than to centre forward Luis Suarez. Although that won't stop him arriving alongside Suarez with the ball at his feet seconds later.

Griezmann's arrival will often result in Lionel Messi, currently with Argentina, playing deeper

Philippe Coutinho (left) and Ousmane Dembele will have to get used to not playing every game

In their Monday edition El Mundo Deportivo debated the tactical variations Greizmann will make available to the coach Ernesto Valverde, who until recently shared an agent with the player.

Option No 1 would see Barca play a 4-3-3 with Ivan Rakitic, Busquets and Coutinho in midfield from right to left, and Messi, Suarez and Griezmann in attack. It's an option that leaves out Dembele.

Option two had Barcelona playing Rakitic and Busquets as a pair in central midfield and then Messi, Griezmann and Dembele or Coutinho behind Suarez. It's an option that potentially leaves out Coutinho.

And option number three, again leaving out Dembele had Barca playing a 4-3-1-2 with Rakitic, Busquets and Coutinho in midfield and Messi behind Suarez and Griezmann.

Griezmann can fit into Barcelona's team in multiple ways, including on the left side in a 4-3-3

He could also line-up slightly deeper and wider, with Messi in a No 10 role, in a 4-2-3-1 system

Another option would by for Griezmann to partner Luis Suarez up front in a 4-3-1-2 formation

A fourth option would be leaving out Griezmann. When the Frenchman arrives for €100m he is unlikely to have any more guarantees to play every game then Dembele or Coutinho.

But despite the 'overbooking' it will create for Barcelona in the attacking positions, they are convinced this is not one forward too many.

Griezmann's arrival will also give the manager greater license to rest 31-year-old Suarez and 30-year-old Messi. Neither player has looked physically on the wane this season but both would benefit from not playing every minute of every match.

Valverde backs the Frenchman's arrival 100 per cent and the dressing room has also given the thumbs up. Griezmann is an adopted South American at Atletico Madrid, often spotted sharing the Uruguayan drink 'Mate' with Diego Godin. So he will ease into the Suarez, Messi group without difficulty.

And he will also be a positive influence on Dembele if for no other reason than the common language as the 20-year-old does his best to get to grips with settling in. 

Griezmann is an adopted South American at Atletico so should bond quickly with Messi and Co

Barcelona will be able to rest Messi and Suarez more frequently once Griezmann, 27, arrives

Even Real Sociedad will be delighted because they are entitled to €20m of the €100m that Barcelona will have to pay. Atletico Madrid will be less pleased about losing their star player but the club have got over the departures of Sergio Aguero, Radamel Falcao, Diego Costa, David De Gea and Fernando Torres in the past so they are confident they can rebuild.

Bumping the player's buy-out clause up to €200m last summer (a temporary increase until the end of this season) at least prevented Griezmann leaving last year when Atletico still had the transfer ban and would not have been able to replace him.

The other potential losers from his arrival will be Denis Suarez, Rafinha, Paco Alcacer, Aleix Vidal, Arda Turan and Andre Gomes, who will all now very much be available at the right price.

Turan and Rafinha are currently out on loan and will not return. Denis Suarez interested Napoli last season but did not want to leave. Vidal, Gomes and Alcacer could stay but Alcacer and Vidal in particular could expect to play less than ever.

Diego Costa will be another 'victim' of his arrival. 'He spent all summer telling me to come here; he can't leave me now,' he said last week.

Costa better than anybody knows that Atletico Madrid is a club that a player often ends up leaving for a more lucrative opportunity elsewhere, even if he returns at a later date.

Griezmann is expected to play for France when they take on Russia in Moscow on Tuesday

item.title: Steve Smith steps down as Rajasthan Royals captain after ball-tampering scandal... so will Australia follow suit?
item.description: Steve Smith has been stripped of the captaincy of IPL franchise Rajasthan Royals on the eve of the new campaign for his role in Australia's ball-tampering scandal in South Africa.
item.content:encoded:
Steve Smith has been stripped of the captaincy of IPL franchise Rajasthan Royals on the eve of the new campaign for his role in Australia's ball-tampering scandal in South Africa.

The Aussie captain admitted he and a 'leadership group' deliberately tried to alter the condition of the ball during the 322-run defeat in the third Test in Cape Town.

Smith was stood down as skipper by Cricket Australia for the Test match and handed a one-match ban by the ICC.

Steve Smith has been stripped of the captaincy of IPL franchise Rajasthan Royals

India batsman Ajinkya Rahane has been installed as the new skipper of the Royals

Steve Smith (right) was pictured at Australia's team hotel in Cape Town on Monday

Smith leans on a table as he makes conversation at waterfront hotel Southern Sun The Cullinan

 Smith's face and baseball cap can be seen peeking out from behind a pillar at the hotel

He was pictured in conversation with two men and checking his phone at the team hotel in Cape Town on Monday as he awaits news of his fate.

Smith was also leaning over a table, wearing T-shirt and shorts and a baseball cap at Southern Sun The Cullinan on the waterfront of the city.

But his IPL fate has already been sealed after he was relieved of his dies in charge of the Royals with the start of the new season only 12 days away, having been appointed captain just last month.

India batsman Ajinkya Rahane will lead the Royals instead. Last year Smith played for Rising Pune Supergiant. 

Zubin Bharucha, Head of Cricket, said, 'The incident in Cape Town has certainly disturbed the cricket world. 

'We have been in constant touch with the BCCI and taken their counsel. Furthermore we have been in regular contact with Steve.

The Aussie captain checks his phone as he waits to learn his fate from Cricket Australia

Luggage belonging to the Australian team is wheeled out of their hotel in Cape Town

Smith was axed as skipper after the ball-tampering controversy for the Cape Town Test

'Steve believes given the current circumstances 'it's in the best interest of the Rajasthan Royals that he steps down as Captain so the team can get ready for the start of the IPL without the ongoing distractions.' 

'He would like to extend his gratitude to the BCCI officials and all the fans in India for their constant support.'

Co-owner Manoj Badale added: 'Rajasthan Royals will do everything possible to protect the values and the integrity of the game.

'The game is bigger than any individual and we hold this thought close to our heart. 

'We agree with Steve's decision to step down as captain, and we are fortunate to have such a capable successor with Ajinkya Rahane. It is important that all cricket fans retain a balanced perspective on the situation. 

Smith admitted that Australia deliberately tried to alter the condition of the ball in Cape Town 

Cameron Bancroft was seen running his hand over the ball, before removing a yellow object from his pocket and placing it down the front of his trousers

Smith was appointed as captain last month and loses the role on the eve of the new season

'What happened in South Africa was clearly wrong, especially given that it appears to have been premeditated. That said, this will be a difficult time for Steve as well, given how much he cares about the game.'

Rajasthan Royals will launch their season with an away fixture against Sunrisers Hyderabad on April 9 followed by their first home game in Jaipur on April 11 where they will host Delhi Daredevils at Sawai Mansingh stadium. 

British prime minister Theresa May weighed into the discussion on Monday, agreeing with counterpart Malcolm Turnbull. 

An official spokesman said: 'The Prime Minister is clear that cheating has absolutely no place in cricket or indeed in any sport.

'The Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has said that cricket fans will be shocked and bitterly disappointed by the news, and the Prime Minister agrees with that.'

Smith faces an anxious wait to learn if he will hold onto the captaincy of the Australia side

John Stephenson, MCC assistant secretary, said in a statement: 'We welcome the swift action by the match officials, ICC and Cricket Australia in response to the admission of ball-tampering by senior Australia players.

'Changing the condition of the ball is prohibited under Law 41 concerning unfair play. Law 41 also places upon the captains of both sides the responsibility for ensuring that play is carried out in accordance with the spirit of the game as well as within the laws.

'The behaviour of some of the players in the current South Africa/Australia series, and other incidents in recent times in the game we all cherish, has fallen well below the standard required to inspire future generations of cricket-loving families.

'The time has come for a major shift in attitude and culture of all those with responsibility for leadership within the game, to give young players the kind of role models who will uphold standards, preserve cricket and, vitally, the spirit of cricket for future generations.'

item.title: Tottenham stars Hugo Lloris and Christian Eriksen lead the way in the highest performing players across Europe's top five leagues
item.description: Tottenham duo Hugo Lloris and Christian Eriksen are the highest rated players in their respective positions across Europe's top five leagues, according to the CIES Football Observatory.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham duo Hugo Lloris and Christian Eriksen are the highest rated players in their respective positions across Europe's top five leagues.

That is according to the CIES Football Observatory, who have ranked players from the Premier League, Serie A, Bundesliga, La Liga and Ligue 1 based on a number of criteria to find out who is performing best.

Players that have played at least 45 minutes in eight league matches are ranked on six different areas of the game: rigour, recovery, distribution, take on, chance creation and shooting.

Hugo Lloris has been ranked as the highest rated goalkeeper across Europe's top five leagues

Lloris came out on top in the goalkeeping standings with a combined score of 84.1 points.

The Spurs stopper performed better than second-placed Alisson (83.8) of Roma, who has been linked to Liverpool, and PSG's Alphonse Areola (83.7) who took third.

Manchester United star David de Gea did not even make the top 10 while there was also Premier League representation from Ederson (83.3) of Manchester City and Liverpool's Loris Karius (79.7).

Lloris was joined at the top of the standings by his team-mate Eriksen, who led the category for box-to-box midfielders with a tally of 89.9. The Dane edged Napoli captain Marek Hamsik (89.5) and City's Ilkay Gundogan (86.9). 

Liverpool's Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain (85.9) was also in the top ten alongside another Spurs player in Dele Alli (84.8) and City's star man Kevin De Bruyne (85.5). 

Spurs man Christian Eriksen led the category for box-to-box midfielders with a tally of 89.9

Elsewhere in the rankings, it is unsurprising that Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo lead the way in the winger and forward divisions respectively.

Messi has scored 35 goals in 43 games this season as he aims to fire Barcelona to the treble before the end of the domestic season and has been given a tally of 93.7. Following behind is Liverpool star and Premier League top goalscorer Mohamed Salah (89.9). 

Spurs' South Korean star Heung-Min Son (87.1) came in as fourth. He was pipped to the bronze medal by AC Milan's Turkish playmaker Hakan Calhanoglu (88.8).

Ronaldo is also in stunning form, notching 37 goals in 35 appearances, and has a ranking to match as he finished above Gonzalo Higuain and Harry Kane on 90.8 in the forward table.

Higuain (87.4) finished runner-up while Kane (87.1), currently out injured for Spurs, occupied third. Liverpool forward Roberto Firmino (82.9) placed eighth, finishing behind City assassin Sergio Aguero (86.0), who took fifth.

Lionel Messi has scored 35 goals in 43 games this season and was the top rated winger

Kalidou Koulibaly of Napoli earned the highest score in the centre back section

Serie A side Napoli were well represented in the defending categories with Kalidou Koulibaly earning the highest score in the centre back section. 

The Senegalese international scored a total of 90.4, edging Tottenham's Davinson Sanchez (88.5) into second place. Nicolas Otamendi (88.1) secured third position while Joel Matip (87.6) of Liverpool also finished in the top ten alongside predictable stars such as Gerard Pique (87.7) and Giorgio Chiellini (87.2).

Koulibaly's team-mate Mario Rui impressed in the full back category. The left-sided defender finished clear of Real Madrid's Dani Carvajal at the top on 88.2. Carvajal (86.6) had to settle for second place while City and England man Kyle Walker (85.8) also placed well in third.

Real Madrid technician Toni Kroos achieved the highest score of defensive midfielders. The German scored 92.8 to finish well clear of Spurs' Mousa Dembele (89.0) in second place. Barcelona's Ivan Rakitic (88.0) occupied third while there will be cause for celebration among Spurs fans as Eric Dier (86.4) scored higher than world class Barca man Sergio Busquets (86.3).

The CIES Football Observatory has ranked players from the Premier League, Serie A, Bundesliga, La Liga and Ligue 1 based on a number of criteria to find out who is performing best.

item.title: Arsenal welcome Alexandre Lacazette and Aaron Ramsey back after injury as squad train during international break
item.description: Alexandre Lacazette was back in full Arsenal training on Monday following a six-week absence with a knee injury as the team began preparations for Sunday's visit of Stoke City.
item.content:encoded:
Alexandre Lacazette was back in full Arsenal training on Monday following a six-week absence with a knee injury as a depleted Gunners team began preparations for Sunday's visit of Stoke City.

The Frenchman has not played for Arsenal since their 1-0 defeat by Tottenham on February 10 but is set to return for the closing stages of the season after training alongside his new strike partner Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang.

Arsene Wenger also welcomed Aaron Ramsey back to first-team training after the midfielder recovered from what Wales manager Ryan Giggs described as 'a small procedure' on a private matter.

Alexandre Lacazette returned to Arsenal training on Monday following a six-week absence

The Frenchman has successfully recovered from a knee injury sustained in early February

Lacazette should be fit to face Stoke City on Sunday after training with Arsenal on Monday

Hector Bellerin and Nacho Monreal were available to train after missing out on the latest Spain squad while Shkodran Mustafi was also present as Joachim Low opted not to select him for Germany. 

With Per Mertesacker and Petr Cech both retired from international duty, it meant Wenger had a surprising number of senior stars present for Monday's session.

The Gunners have plenty of time before their next Premier League game and, as they are cut adrift from the top four — 12 points behind with eight games left — there is little to play for domestically.

However, Arsenal will be keen to keep momentum going as their bid to win their first ever Europa League title continues next week. They welcome CSKA Moscow to the Emirates in the first leg of their quarter-final tie, which Lacazette is likely to start. 

Aaron Ramsey was also back in training following a small procedure on a private issue

Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang was present as Gabon do not play in this international break

Hector Bellerin runs in search of a pass as the Arsenal squad prepare for their next match

A Europa League win would give Arsenal the Champions League qualification they desperately want and may keep Wenger in the job for at least one more season. He faces strong questions over his future if they do not win it.

Wenger has faced heavy criticism from fans this season, but believes he has been the victim of 'age discrimination'. 

He told BeIN Sport: 'When you age, you focus on doing well for your club and ignore all the rest. The older you get, the more it becomes age discrimination.

'I accept if the results are not good enough then you have to take the consequences. But overall that perpetual thing of how long you have been at a club, how old you are, I find that a bit difficult to take.

'But all the rest I have to accept because I am in a public job and have to make results and I accept I will be judged on results.'

Arsene Wenger instructs his players as training continues at Arsenal's London Colney

Petr Cech, retired from international duty, prepares for training with some routine stretches

item.title: Monaco join race to sign Manchester United midfielder Marouane Fellaini on a free transfer this summer
item.description: Monaco have joined the list of clubs to have enquired about Manchester United midfielder Marouane Fellaini. The 30-year-old is out of contract at United and is expected to leave.
item.content:encoded:
Monaco have joined the list of clubs to have enquired about Manchester United midfielder Marouane Fellaini.

The 30-year-old is out of contract at United and is expected to leave after failing to find agreement over the new terms offered him at Old Trafford.

Besiktas have long been considered favourites to sign the Belgium international though Fellaini's camp are also understood to have been sounded out by Paris Saint-Germain, who also like his compatriot Toby Alderweireld at Tottenham, other English sides and clubs in China.

Marouane Fellaini is wanted by Monaco ahead of a potential exit from Manchester United

Monaco have sold a number of their star players and expect to lose Thomas Lemar for a considerable fee too this summer. They want to strengthen their squad and are attracted by the fact Fellaini will be a free agent.

United have been weighing up a number of new options for midfield with Michael Carrick also due to join the club's coaching staff.

Real Madrid's Toni Kroos, Sergej-Milinkovic-Savic of Lazio and Jorginho at Napoli are some of the names they have discussed.

United also want to strengthen at full-back with Luke Shaw, Matteo Darmian and Daley Blind all considering a new challenge.

Jose Mourinho has been keen to keep Fellaini beyond this summer but looks set to lose him

item.title: Cristiano Ronaldo kissed by excited pitch invader during Portugal's 3-0 defeat by Holland as fans try to get pictures with the Real Madrid star
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo was given a kiss by a pitch invader during Portugal's 3-0 defeat by Holland on Monday night. The fan ran up to Ronaldo and planted a kiss on his right cheek.
item.content:encoded:
Cristiano Ronaldo was given a kiss by a pitch invader during Portugal's 3-0 defeat by Holland on Monday night.

Portugal were already three goals down when Joao Cancelo received a second yellow card and was sent off during the friendly.

As the game was about to restart following Cancelo's dismissal, a number of fans raced onto the pitch at Stade de Geneve in Switzerland.

One excited pitch invader gave Cristiano Ronaldo a kiss during Portugal's friendly match

Ronaldo didn't look too impressed by what happened during Portugal's 3-0 defeat by Holland

A number of fans ran on the pitch in Switzerland to meet the Portugal and Real Madrid star

One supporter - clearly very fond of Ronaldo - ran up to the Real Madrid star and planted a kiss on his left cheek.

Ronaldo looked nonplussed about the man's gesture before he was substituted in the 67th minute - even then one fan tried to grab him for a photograph as he walked to the players' tunnel.

It was a disappointing night overall for Ronaldo and his Portugal team-mates.

One fan tries to grab Ronaldo for a picture as the 33-year-old walked to the players' tunnel

Expected to beat Holland, they appeared lethargic and went behind when Memphis Depay scored after 11 minutes.

Former Liverpool player Ryan Babel doubled Holland's lead not long before Virgil van Dijk applied a calm finish in first-half stoppage time.

It was a tough night for Ronaldo, who wasn't able to make an impact against Holland

item.title: Manchester United ‘beat Manchester City to the signing of Polish wonderkid Lukasz Bejger' after successful trial
item.description: Manchester United have beaten rivals Manchester City to the acquisition of Polish starlet Lukasz Bejger. The 16-year-old centre-back, who currently plays for Lech Poznan, had a trial with United
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United have beaten rivals Manchester City to the acquisition of Polish starlet Lukasz Bejger.

The 16-year-old centre-back, who currently plays for Lech Poznan, had a trial with United last year and a deal to bring him to the club was finalised in January, according to the MEN. 

Also capable of playing at right-back if required, Bejger was linked with a move to City but has instead joined United and is set to form part of their scholarship intake for next season. 

Talented defender Lukasz Bejger will join Manchester United from Lech Poznan's academy

Bejger has been capped on eight occasions by Poland at U16 level since making his debut earlier this season and has gone on to captain the side. 

Scout Piotr Sadowski, who joined United from Lech Poznan last year, is said to have played a part in the move. 

Bejger will hope that he will eventually break into Jose Mourinho's first-team at United

MANCHESTER UNITED YOUNG PLAYER OF THE YEAR AWARD WINNERS 

2016/17 - Angel Gomes

2015/16 - Marcus Rashford

2014/15 - Axel Tuanzebe

2013/14 - James Wilson

2012/13 - Ben Pearson 

United's U23 side have struggled this season and could be relegated from Premier League 2.

However, there are some very talented young players at the club such as Angel Gomes, Tahith Chong and Nishan Burkart, who will aim to eventually become important players for the senior side.

In recent years United have brought in several foreign prospects and the anticipated arrival of Berget suggests that the trend could continue this summer.

item.title: Liverpool train as they wait for international stars Mohamed Salah and Roberto Firmino to return
item.description: The majority of Liverpool players, including the likes of Mohamed Salah, Roberto Firmino and Sadio Mane, are currently on international duty, but manager Jurgen Klopp still held a training session
item.content:encoded:
The majority of Liverpool players, including the likes of Mohamed Salah, Roberto Firmino and Sadio Mane, are currently on international duty, but manager Jurgen Klopp still held a training session on Monday with the squad members that he has available.

Nathaniel Clyne, Dejan Lovren, James Milner, Alberto Moreno, Joel Matip and Danny Ings all took part in the session at the club's Melwood training ground, where they were joined by talented young midfielder Rafael Camacho.

The Reds appeared in good spirits as they maintained their fitness levels ahead of an intense upcoming schedule. 

James Milner looks to hold off the attention of Joel Matip during Liverpool's training session

Matip and Nathaniel Clyne in action as Liverpool prepare for a hectic run of games

Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp assesses the small selection of players at his disposal

Liverpool face Crystal Palace away in the Premier League on Saturday before taking on Manchester City in the Champions League quarter-finals, with the Merseyside derby against Everton sandwiched between those two meetings with Pep Guardiola's side.

Klopp will hope that his players don't suffer any further injuries on international duty as he looks to ensure that his squad is at its strongest going into a crucial period of the season.

Klopp shares a joke with the club's photographer as he takes time out during the session

Talented young midfielder Rafael Camacho was selected to train with the senior squad

Striker Danny Ings was in good spirits during the training session held at Melwood

Left-back Alberto Moreno looks to impress Klopp as he aims to get more playing time

Meanwhile, Jordan Henderson, Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain and Adam Lallana are in the England squad for the Italy game, although Joe Gomez has withdrawn because of an ankle problem.

item.title: Paraguayan team Cerro Porteno net Puskas Award contender as South American side score sublime goal that includes two outrageous backheels
item.description: Cerro Porteno, a team in Paraguay's top flight, have already scored a stunning goal worthy of winning the 2018 Puskas Award. It featured not one but two backheels before Hernan Novick fired home.
item.content:encoded:
Cerro Porteno, a team in Paraguay's top flight, have already scored a stunning goal worthy of winning the 2018 Puskas Award. 

One of the most popular clubs in the South American country, Cerro Porteno overcame Sportivo Luqueno 2-0 on Sunday, but it was their second goal scored by Hernan Novick that caught the eye most.

It featured not one but two backheels with the free flowing move earning a number of plaudits across the football landscape.

Scroll down for video

Cerro Porteno have already scored a stunning goal worthy of winning the 2018 Puskas Award

Señores @FIFAcom no busquen más, les presentamos el Premio Puskas 2018 ��#CerroSomosTodos ���� pic.twitter.com/nWI3AxlYYk

— Club Cerro Porteño (@CCP1912oficial) March 25, 2018

The move begins with a pass played out to the right hand side but it is a little too heavy and forces winger Jorge Rojas out to the edge of the box.

He takes one touch and rather than fizz a delivery across goal, he backheels it behind himself towards the onrushing Novick.

The Uruguayan is instantly challenged by a defender but rather than control the pass and look for another supporting team-mate, he audaciously backheels the ball through the defender's legs.

He is now bearing down on the goalkeeper but finishes the move with aplomb by curling it delightfully with his left foot into the far corner.

The move begins with a pass played out to the right hand side towards winger Jorge Rojas

Rather than fizz a delivery across goal, he backheels it behind towards the onrushing Novick

Novick audaciously backheels the ball through the defender's legs instead of holding it up

He then finishes the move with aplomb by curling it delightfully into the far corner

Cerro Porteno were obviously pleased with their effort and tweeted FIFA after the game informing them that they should look no further in their search for the Puskas Award winner.

The prize honours a player, male or female, judged to have scored the most aesthetically significant goal of the year and former winners include Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Neymar.

Chelsea striker Olivier Giroud is the reigning champion after the Frenchman scored an outstanding scorpion kick for Arsenal against Crystal Palace in the Premier League in 2017.

item.title: Paulinho admits Lionel Messi made him shy away from a free-kick during an international clash after Argentine star asked if he was joining Barcelona
item.description: Lionel Messi forced future team-mate Paulinho to shy away from taking a free-kick during an international friendly after he asked the Brazilian midfielder if he would be joining Barcelona in the future.
item.content:encoded:
Lionel Messi forced future team-mate Paulinho to shy away from taking a free-kick during an international friendly after he asked if the Brazilian would be joining Barcelona in the future.

Just a month before Paulinho arrived at the Nou Camp, the Brazilian team squared off against Messi's Argentina in a friendly match in Melbourne.

Brazil were awarded a free-kick in a dangerous position and, spotting Paulinho preparing to take it, Messi used the ongoing transfer speculation to his advantage.

Lionel Messi forced Paulinho to shy away from a free-kick during an international friendly

'I was preparing to take a free-kick with Willian and another player I do not remember,' the Brazilian told El Periodico.

'Suddenly, I see Messi from behind, who is approaching me little by little and he said: "Are you going to Barcelona or not?".

'What did I tell him? "If you want to take me, you can take me. I am going".

'I was so nervous that I said to Willian, "You're taking the free-kick!".'

Messi asked whether Paulinho was joining Barcelona, making the Brazilian extremely nervous

Paulinho has impressed since moving to the Nou Camp, making 41 appearances this season

Willian failed to convert the free-kick as Argentina went on to win the clash 1-0 with Gabriel Mercado scoring the winning goal.

Paulinho eventually sealed a €40million (£35m) move from China side Guangzhou Evergrande to the Nou Camp last summer.

He has since impressed for Ernesto Valverde's side, delivering a number of impressive midfield displays and scoring eight goals in 41 appearances.

item.title: Barcelona line up shock move for Luke Shaw as La Liga giants look to offer Manchester United outcast a way out
item.description: Barcelona could be prepared to hand Manchester United outcast Luke Shaw an escape from his Old Trafford hell, with the left back having endured a difficult relationship with his boss.
item.content:encoded:
Barcelona could be prepared to hand Manchester United outcast Luke Shaw an escape from his Old Trafford hell. 

The left back has endured a difficult season, with manager Jose Mourinho calling out his own player for what he believes to be a number of sub-par performances.

The most recent incident occurred during the FA Cup victory over Brighton, when the former Southampton academy product was hauled off at half-time for what the Portuguese deemed an inadequate defensive display. 

Luke Shaw's future at Manchester United is in serious doubt after Jose Mourinho's latest blast

Pundits and players have all come to the defence of the England international, and Mourinho's continual alienation of the 22-year-old has cast doubt over his future at the club.

And according to the Mirror, Barcelona are weighing up a surprise move to take him to Spain.  

The report suggests the Spanish giants see the left back as value for money and could be willing to compete with the likes of Chelsea for his signature.

Shaw may find first team opportunities as difficult to come by at the Nou Camp as he has at United.

Barcelona could be willing to offer Shaw an out and see the defender as value for money

Jordi Alba is first choice down the flank for Ernesto Valverde and has been a regular since joining from Valencia in 2012.

Lucas Digne was signed in 2016 from Paris Saint-Germain to offer some competition for the Spanish international but has failed to make his mark.

Shaw's current contract at United is up in the summer, although the club are likely to exercise an option of an extra year to ensure they do not lose him for nothing.

item.title: England players use Nerf rockets, medicine balls and resistance bands in action packed training session ahead of Tuesday friendly with Italy
item.description: England have been preparing for their second friendly of the international break with some speed and strength training - and using some unconventional methods and techniques.
item.content:encoded:
England have been preparing for their second friendly of the international break with some speed and strength training - and using some unconventional methods. 

One of the exercises involved players throwing handheld Nerf rockets - small foam missiles - for each other to chase and catch. 

Dele Alli chucked one for Jesse Lingard, who, despite possessing notable pace, was not quite able to make the catch and was sent sprawling over the St. Georges' Park turf.

England have been preparing for their second friendly of the international break

One of the exercises involved players throwing handheld Nerf rockets to improve agility

Dele Alli chucked one for Jesse Lingard, who, despite his pace was not able to make the catch

Marcus Rashford catches one of the foam rockets as England's players worked on their speed

Rashford also went to the floor after making a catch, only to be jumped on by Dele and Lingard

England face Italy on Tuesday having beaten Holland in Amsterdam in a friendly last Friday

Marcus Rashford also went to the floor after making a catch, only to be jumped on by Dele and Lingard.

Lingard was also the centre of attention when working with the resistance bands, large rubber band type aids which one player holds around the waist of another, who has to move against the weight and force of the band and their team mate. 

The Manchester United midfielder worked with club mate Marcus Rashford, although they appeared to have a minor disagreement when the band got caught around Lingard's head.  

Lingard and Rashford squabble after getting a resistance band tangled on the former's head

The bands are used to improve player strength as they fight against the rubber and the player

Liverpool and Man Utd together as Ashley Young partnered with Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain

There were also examples of club team mates working together with Tottenham colleagues Dele Alli and Danny Rose, although rivals Liverpool and Manchester United also came together as Ashley Young partnered with Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain. 

As with many England sessions, the medicine balls were also brought out.

Oxlade-Chamberlain maybe needs to bulk up a little more, an unfortunately timed picture capturing him dropping the ball. 

Oxlade-Chamberlain drops the medicine ball as England worked on their strength in training

The weighted balls are a regular feature in training and are thrown by the players

Leicester and England striker Jamie Vardy prepares to launch his medicine ball skywards

All this fitness training is keeping England sharp as they prepare for their second game in five days. They take on Italy at Wembley having beaten Holland on Friday night. 

The session was overseen by manager Gareth Southgate, who will be making his final squad selection in the World Cup in a couple of months' time. 

The Italy game provides an essential opportunity for England's fringe players to impress, although some of course be left disappointed.

All this fitness training is keeping England sharp as they prepare for the Wembley fixture

England's players know this could be the final chance to impress for a World Cup squad place

Three of England's four goalkeepers - Joe Hart, Jordan Pickford and Nick Pope - in training

Among the players sweating on their places in Gareth Southgate's party for Russia are Adam Lallana and Jack Wilshere, who have suffered injury problems this season.

Likewise, it is understood Gary Cahill and Chris Smalling - who were omitted from the latest squad - are highly unlikely to win their places back before the World Cup.

England manager Southgate wants to name his 23-man squad for the World Cup before the clash against Nigeria, first of two pre-tournament friendlies, on June 2 - which makes Italy the last-chance saloon. 

Raheem Sterling arrives for training, which took place at Tottenham's facility in Enfield

Jordan Henderson, who captained England in Holland, chats to team mate Adam Lallana

The whole session was overseen by England manager Gareth Southgate on Monday morning

item.title: Arsenal midfielder Mohamed Elneny signs new long-term deal as he aims to help put them in their 'deserved spot in Europe and the whole world'
item.description: The midfielder, who will play for Egypt during this summer's World Cup in Russia, has made 65 appearances for the Gunners since joining from Basle back in January 2016.
item.content:encoded:
Egypt midfielder Mohamed Elneny has signed a new long-term contract with Arsenal.

The 25-year-old joined from Basle in January 2016 and has since made 65 appearances for the Gunners. The length of his new deal was not disclosed.

'We're pleased to announce that Mo Elneny has signed a new long-term contract with the club,' Arsenal said.

Mohamed Elneny signed a new long-term contract at Arsenal on Monday afternoon

After penning his new deal Elneny took to Twitter, writing: 'Officially we will be together for a longer time, in order to reach what we started, and to put Arsenal in it's deserved spot in Europe and the whole world.' 

Boss Arsene Wenger said at the start of the season: 'He is a fantastic boy, we love him here. His best years are in front of him.

'It took him some time to adapt to the intensity of the games and I think he was not aggressive enough for the Premier League (initially). But now he has added that to his game.'

Elneny said on Twitter: 'We will be together for a longer time, in order to reach what we started'

Officially we will be together for a longer time, in order to reach what we started, and to put arsenal in it's deserved spot In Europe and the whole world#WeAreArsenal ♥️♥️#WeAreGunners 💪🏼💪🏼 pic.twitter.com/1Sg8JzVhmt

— Mohamed ELNeny (@ElNennY) March 26, 2018

Elneny began his senior career with El Mokawloon in Egypt's top flight before moving to Switzerland with Basle in 2013.

He was in the Egypt squad which qualified for this summer's World Cup for the first time in 28 years.

He has scored two goals for the Gunners, in his first campaign in a 3-1 loss at Barcelona, and this season in December's 6-0 win over Bate Borisov.   

The midfielder is currently away with Egypt and will play for them at this summer's World Cup

item.title: Brazilian icon Ronaldinho reveals he was just 48 hours from signing for Manchester United... and says he DID hold talks to join Blackburn Rovers
item.description: In the knowledge that David Beckham was on the brink of sealing a move away in 2003, then United boss Sir Alex Ferguson moved quickly to replace him and soften the blow.
item.content:encoded:
Ronaldinho to Manchester United was the signing the Old Trafford faithful craved back in 2003 – and the Brazilian has revealed just how close it was.

In the knowledge that David Beckham was on the brink of sealing a move away, then United boss Sir Alex Ferguson moved quickly to replace him and soften the blow.

Ronaldinho, who was at Paris Saint-Germain at the time, was at the top of the Scot's hitlist once United got wind of Barcelona's interest in Beckham.

Ronaldinho has revealed he was just 48 hours away from signing for Manchester United

Sir Alex Ferguson moved quickly to replace David Beckham, who was on his way out of United

But the England icon chose La Liga rivals Real Madrid and then Barca president Sandro Rosell quickly swooped for Ronaldinho – after the playmaker had spoken to United.

'It almost happened. It was a matter of 48 hours but Sandro Rosell had told me way before I got the offer: "If I become Barca president, will you come?" I said yes,' he told FourFourTwo.

'It was only a matter of details with United when Rosell called to say he was going to win the elections there. And I had promised to him that I'd play for Barca. It was a quick negotiation.

'I told the English I had chosen Barca. It was the right choice. Brazilians have always loved Barca. We have a history there. Off the pitch it is like nowhere else in Europe, so we are always happy playing there. I miss Barcelona a lot.'

After it was thought Beckham would move to Barcelona, he decided on a switch to Real Madrid

Then Barca president Sandro Rosell then swooped for Ronaldinho and he never looked back

He had an illustrious career at Barcelona, winning five trophies during his time there, while United unearthed their own star in Cristiano Ronaldo.

After five seasons at the Nou Camp and a further three at AC Milan, however, it was Blackburn who came calling for the Brazil international.

Ronaldinho became the subject of a somewhat ambitious bid from Blackburn in 2011, following the takeover by the Venkys, and he revealed he did hold talks with the club before deciding to return home.

'About Blackburn,' he added. 'We talked to them, but I wanted to come back home to Brazil.'

He duly moved back to join Flamengo. He also turned out for Queretaro and Fluminense before retiring in 2015.
item.dc:abstract: Ronaldinho to Manchester United was the massive signing the Old Trafford faithful craved in 2003, and the Brazilian has revealed just how close he came. In the knowledge that David Beckham was on the brink of sealing a move away in 2003, then United boss Sir Alex Ferguson moved quickly to replace him and soften the blow. Ronaldinho, who was at Paris Saint-Germain at the time, was at the top of the Scot's hitlist once United got wind of Barcelona's interest in Beckham.

item.title: Liverpool fear Joe Gomez could miss crunch Manchester City and Everton matches after picking up ankle injury
item.description: There are fears that Gomez could be ruled out for up to four weeks, which would leave him sidelined for both legs of the quarter-final against Man City as well as the Merseyside derby.
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool are sweating on the ankle injury that could rule Joe Gomez out of their Champions League clash with Manchester City.

Gomez should have been in contention to face Italy at Wembley but he was sent back to Melwood for treatment on the injury he sustained in the 10th minute of Friday's friendly against Holland, which England won 1-0.

There are fears that Gomez could be ruled out for up to four weeks, which would leave him sidelined for both legs of the quarter-final against Pep Guardiola's team, as well as the Merseyside derby against Everton at Goodison Park on April 7.

Joe Gomez sustained ankle injury in the 10th minute of Friday's friendly against Holland

Star should have been in contention to face Italy but was sent back to Liverpool for treatment

Jurgen Klopp has tended to use Gomez as a right back in big games and if the injury is as bad as some believe, it would be a significant blow for both player and manager, particularly as the 20-year-old is looking to cement his place in England's World Cup squad.

The full extent of the damage, however, will not be known until the swelling around the ankle had subsided and Liverpool can send Gomez for a scan towards the end of the week.

Gomez received his first England call-up in November and earned praise for putting a commanding display to nullify the threat of Brazil's Neymar in a 0-0 draw.

He recently admitted he is still getting used to taking on the world's best forwards and is also learning from Liverpool's Mohamed Salah, who has scored 36 goals in all competitions since arriving at Anfield at the start of the campaign.

'I'm not sure (who is better), they're both world class,' Gomez added. 'They're both incredible players and it's a pleasure for me to come up against such talent.

'It has to be a balance of respecting the ability but also understanding that he's your opponent and you can't be in awe of him, otherwise that might not do you any good. I try to learn as much as I can about each opponent and study their threats.' 

There are fears he could be ruled out for up to four weeks, meaning he'll miss crunch matches
