item.title: Nick Kyrgios sparks war of words with Fernando Verdasco after world No 20 tweets about wanting the Spanish player to lose against fellow Aussie Thanasi Kokkinakis at Miami Open: 'Verdasco is the saltiest dude'
item.description: Nick Kyrgios sparked a war of words with Fernando Verdasco on Monday night after the world No 20 tweeted the Spanish player and called him 'the saltiest dude'.
item.content:encoded:
Nick Kyrgios sparked a war of words with Fernando Verdasco on Monday night after the world No 20 tweeted the Spanish player and called him 'the saltiest dude'.

Kyrgios, who has a reputation on the tennis circuit for being outspoken, sent the tweet during Verdasco's Miami Open round of 32 match against fellow Aussie Thanasi Kokkinakis.

Kyrgios tweeted: 'I hope TK wins this match, Verdasco is the saltiest dude, must be frustrated at his past success against Aussies.'

Nick Kyrgios sparked a war of words at the Miami Open in Florida on Monday night

Kyrgios tweeted about Spanish tennis player Fernando Verdasco, calling him 'the saltiest dude'

The tweet soon gained traction on Twitter before the 22-year-old deleted his original post.

Verdasco responded after his 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 victory over Kokkinakis to reach the last-16.

'@NickKyrgios when you have the courage to put a tweet insulting another player you need to have the same to don't delete it,' Verdasco responded.  

Kyrgios sent the above tweet during Verdasco's match before he deleted a short time later 

Verdasco responded to Kyrgios and called him a coward for deleting the offending tweet

Kyrgios responded 30 minutes after Verdasco's tweet and wrote: 'I would have told it to Fernando's face, the reason I deleted my previous tweet was because I didn't want to cause unwanted attention, but I'm just gonna leave this here. 'Thanks for blocking me, I'm sure that took a lot of courage x.' 

Kyrgios is also through to the last-16 after he beat Italy's Fabio Fognini.

The pair could meet in the semi-finals should they get that far.    

Kyrgios responded 30 minutes after Verdasco tweeted him on Monday night

item.title: Eden Hazard dismisses fears surrounding Chelsea future as Belgium captain targets World Cup final: 'I do not think about it yet'
item.description: Hazard has two years remaining on his Chelsea contract and his failure to sign a new deal has fuelled speculation about a possible move away from Stamford Bridge.
item.content:encoded:
Eden Hazard has promised Belgium he will focus his mind on the dream of reaching the World Cup final before considering his club future.

Hazard has two years remaining on his Chelsea contract and his failure to sign a new deal has fuelled speculation about a possible move away from Stamford Bridge.

Real Madrid have long-standing interest and the 27-year-old, signed from Lille in 2012, is regularly linked with a return to France with Paris Saint-Germain.

Eden Hazard is not yet ready to discuss his future at Chelsea amid Belgium's World Cup hopes

Manchester City would declare an interest if he appeared ready to move but Belgium's captain has other priorities.

Hazard said: 'I am going to finish the Premier League competition first and then play the World Cup and then I will leave on holiday. Then we will see what happens next. I do not think about it yet.

'I have another two years contract with Chelsea where I am very happy.'

The Blues star has two years left on his contract but has been linked with a move away

HAZARD'S SEASON 

Premier League

Games: 26

Goals: 11

Assists: 3

Champions League

Games: 8

Goals: 3

Assists: 4

The Premier League champions are about to yield the title to Manchester City but are in the FA Cup semi-finals and competing to finish in the top four and qualify for the Champions League next season.

Hazard dismissed the idea that he did not like playing as a centre forward in Antonio Conte's team, when asked about it on international duty, claiming he would play anywhere.

But Conte is expected to leave Chelsea in the summer and it makes sense for Hazard to know the identity of his successor before taking any decision.

His next contract will be his last before he turns 30 and therefore likely to be his last big pay-day.

Hazard has been named as Belgium's captain for the upcoming World Cup in Russia

Hazard said on Monday that he is focused on finishing Chelsea's season and the tournament

As for Chelsea's stuttering form, Hazard commented: 'We are in a delicate period and it is good that we won (in the FA Cup quarter-final) against Leicester. We want to reach the top four.

'We played two good matches against Barcelona but due to small mistakes we conceded goals, and football is decided on details.

'This is no different for the Red Devils. We have to be concentrated from the first to the last minute.'

Belgium play a friendly against Saudi Arabia in Brussels on Tuesday as they prepare for the World Cup where they have been drawn against England in Group G.

Roberto Martinez has selected Hazard to captain the team in Russia and they are conscious of expectations on this talented generation to make an impact at a major tournament before it is too late.

Manager Roberto Martinez backed Hazard's hopes of reaching a World Cup final

'Four years ago was the first World Cup for most of our players,' said Hazard. 'Now we have experience. We know what to do to be ready and we have one target, which is to reach the final.'

Martinez is well aware of the gruelling aspect of the Premier League where many of his players are based and has given his senior players time off to rest since they met last week.

Only one friendly has been arranged when he could have squeezed in two and the former Everton, Swansea and Wigan boss is taking care to keep his players as fresh as possible.

'When we have time off we need to take it,' said Hazard. 'We want to be ready for the last two months with Chelsea and the World Cup.'

Hazard insisted he will not be discussing his Stamford Bridge future until after the tournament

item.title: Russian raid on UK doping data is foiled after cyber attack put medical records and drug-testing history of Britain's leading sports stars at risk
item.description: On Monday night the agency insisted that the attack, possibly by the same Russian hackers who accessed the data of other doping agencies in the past two years, had failed.
item.content:encoded:
The personal medical records and drug-testing history of Britain’s leading sports stars were at risk last weekend after a cyber attack on UK Anti-Doping.

On Monday night the agency insisted that the attack, possibly by the same Russian hackers who accessed the data of other doping agencies in the past two years, had failed.

Staff were called to a UKAD meeting in London on Monday but sent home after the agency was forced to shut down its servers. It is understood the hack did not affect the ADAMS system athletes use to update their whereabouts.

On Monday night UK Anti-Doping insisted a cyber attack affecting their systems had failed

A UKAD spokesman said: ‘Over the weekend (we were) made aware of a cyber attack affecting our systems. No data has been lost or compromised.

‘No core activity, including our testing programme, has been impacted. We are satisfied that we have appropriate levels of cyber-security in place, and we continually review our systems and measures to ensure they are of a very high standard.’

While UKAD’s defences proved adequate this time, the Fancy Bears hackers in Russia have shown it is possible to access such data — in some cases to the detriment of British athletes.

Sir Bradley Wiggins is probably the biggest casualty after the Fancy Bears revealed his corticosteroid use in 2016.

The Fancy Bears revealed the corticosteroid use of Sir Bradley Wiggins (pictured) in 2016

item.title: Ex-Australia captain Steve Waugh 'deeply troubled' by ball-tampering scandal and accuses current players of 'failing our culture'
item.description: Steve Smith has been banned for one match and faces being stripped of the captaincy after admitting to deliberately attempting to alter the condition of the ball in the third Test against South Africa.
item.content:encoded:
Australian cricketing legend Steve Waugh admits he is 'deeply troubled' by the ball-tampering scandal that has engulfed his nation.

Steve Smith has been banned for one match and faces being stripped of the captaincy after admitting to deliberately attempting to alter the condition of the ball in the third Test against South Africa.

Australia were thrashed by 322 runs in Cape Town to go 2-1 down in the four-match series ahead of the final Test in Johannesburg.

Steve Waugh admits he is 'deeply troubled' by Australia's ball-tampering scandal

Steve Smith and David Warner are facing lengthy bans for their role in the controversy 

And former captain Waugh has added his voice to the growing condemnation that has met Australia's actions at the weekend.

Cameron Bancroft was caught rubbing sticky yellow tape on the ball, with Smith admitting afterwards it was a premeditated move by 'the leadership group'.

Waugh has called the incident a 'serious error of judgement' that has 'failed our culture.

He wrote in a statement on Facebook: 'Like many I’m deeply troubled by the events in Cape Town this last week, and acknowledge the thousands of messages I have received, mostly from heartbroken cricket followers worldwide.

Waugh slammed Australia's failing cricket culture and called it a 'serious error of judgement'

Australia admitted to deliberately attempting to alter the condition of the ball in Cape Town

'The Australian Cricket team has always believed it could win in any situation against any opposition, by playing combative, skillful and fair cricket, driven by our pride in the fabled Baggy Green.

'I have no doubt the current Australian team continues to believe in this mantra, however some have now failed our culture, making a serious error of judgement in the Cape Town Test Match.

'In 2003, we modified the Spirit of Cricket document originally created by the MCC, to empower our players to set their own standards and commit to play the Australian way.

'We must urgently revisit this document, re-bind our players to it and ensure the Spirit in which we play is safe-guarded for the future of the sport, and to continue to inspire the dreams of every young kid picking up a bat and ball and for every fan who lives and breathes the game.'

Waugh was in charge when Australia won a record 16 consecutive Test matches and lifted the World Cup in 1999.

Smith has been banned for the fourth Test against South Africa in Johannesburg on Friday

STEVE WAUGH STATEMENT 

Like many I’m deeply troubled by the events in Cape Town this last week, and acknowledge the thousands of messages I have received, mostly from heartbroken cricket followers worldwide.

The Australian Cricket team has always believed it could win in any situation against any opposition, by playing combative, skillful and fair cricket, driven by our pride in the fabled Baggy Green.

I have no doubt the current Australian team continues to believe in this mantra, however some have now failed our culture, making a serious error of judgement in the Cape Town Test Match.

In 2003, we modified the Spirit of Cricket document originally created by the MCC, to empower our players to set their own standards and commit to play the Australian way.

We must urgently revisit this document, re-bind our players to it and ensure the Spirit in which we play is safe-guarded for the future of the sport, and to continue to inspire the dreams of every young kid picking up a bat and ball and for every fan who lives and breathes the game.

A focused and balanced perspective is needed in the condemnation on those involved in this, with a clear and critical consideration to the social impact and mental health of all players.

I will support all positive action to ensure an outcome for the betterment of the game, regaining the trust and faith of every fan of cricket.

item.title: Accused former Newcastle striker Peter Beardsley on Wembley VIP list for England vs Italy friendly
item.description: CHARLES SALE - SPORTS AGENDA: The FA face the awkward issue of former England striker Peter Beardsley being a feted guest in the VIP Wembley Suite for the match against Italy.
item.content:encoded:
The FA face the awkward issue of former England striker Peter Beardsley being a feted guest in the VIP Wembley Suite for the match against Italy while he is still under investigation over claims of bullying and racism.

Newcastle Under 23 coach Beardsley has been suspended since the accusations made by Yasin Ben El-Mhanni — and supported by five written submissions from team-mates — in January.

The 57-year-old is also alleged to have made a racist comment to two African academy players at Newcastle. He strongly denies all the claims.

Peter Beardsley will be a guest in the VIP Wembley Suite for England's match against Italy

Beardsley was a celebrated member of the England World Cup squad who reached the semi-finals of Italia 90. He has been invited to Wembley to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Sir Bobby Robson Foundation — the cancer charity set up by the much-loved former England and Newcastle manager, who died in 2009.

The FA do not feel they can take any stance on Beardsley over his participation in a coaching course at St George’s Park and his Wembley invitation until the Newcastle inquiry is complete.

An FA spokeswoman said: ‘We are aware that Newcastle are conducting an investigation into allegations made against Peter Beardsley, but his availability to attend a coaching course at SGP is not affected at this time.’

Newcastle coach Beardsley has been suspended after allegations of racism and bullying

 

Danny Mills is the second member of the BBC Radio 5 Live commentary team after Alan Green to decide against travelling to Russia for the World Cup. 

Pundit Mills, who won 19 England caps, has opted instead to cover the tournament for Malaysian TV from the comfort of a studio in Kuala Lumpur. 

Chris Waddle will effectively take Mills’s place with Radio 5 Live. Green announced in 2016 that he would not be going to Russia because of safety fears.

Former footballer Danny Mills (right) has decided against travelling to the World Cup in Russia

 

Tottenham’s Enfield training ground has permanently replaced Arsenal’s as the FA’s preferred England training base when the squad are staying at the Grove Hotel in Watford, despite Spurs’ site being 20 minutes’ drive beyond London Colney.

Building work at Arsenal was originally given as the reason for the switch after Euro 2016. 

But FA insiders claim England have been made far more welcome by Spurs, while there were problems with individuals at Arsenal over access, especially on media days, and the use of particular pitches.

Tottenham's Enfield training ground is now the FA's preferred England training base

 

You would have got long odds on a live England football match against Holland attracting 3million fewer viewers than the 8.4m who tuned in for England’s Six Nations win over Wales in February. 

ITV, who showed the Holland match on Friday evening, put the disparity down to the football being a friendly and the rugby having an ideal 4.45pm slot on a Saturday. Rugby union also succeeds in dressing up its ‘friendly’ autumn internationals as Tests, while England football friendlies are disparaged as a waste of time.

 

Wayne deserves better

Time is running out before the World Cup for Wayne Rooney to be suitably honoured in front of a Wembley crowd for his century of England caps. Only the game against Nigeria will be staged there after Tuesday’s match against Italy. 

It will be more than two years since Rooney’s last England appearance if the ceremony is delayed until next season. And the Everton man deserves a proper accolade because he is the nation’s record scorer with 53 goals and the second most-capped player (119) after goalkeeper Peter Shilton.

Wayne Rooney deserves a proper accolade because he is the nation's record scorer

 

The FA make great play of having spotters in the crowd and CCTV trained on England fans at away matches. So hopefully they will pinpoint and ban members of the official England Supporters Travel Club, whose chants in the Johan Cruyff Arena last Friday included ‘F*** the IRA’ and ‘No surrender’ during the national anthem, as well as ‘There’ll be no sheep-s******* in Moscow’ and ‘There’ll be no Fenian b******* in Moscow’.

item.title: Neymar continues rehab from foot injury as Paris Saint-Germain superstar sits out Brazil friendlies
item.description: The Paris Saint-Germain star has been nursing a fracture in his foot and has been forced to sit out PSG's last four games as well as the ongoing international break.
item.content:encoded:
As Brazil ran riot over World Cup hosts Russia on Friday night, Neymar would have been sitting at home watching on enviously.

The Paris Saint-Germain star has been nursing a fracture in his foot and has been forced to sit out PSG's last four games as well as the ongoing international break.

And after watching his countrymen win in Moscow, it was back to the physio table on Monday as he posted an update on his recent injury.

Neymar endures treatment on his right foot after sustaining a fracture earlier this month

The 26-year-old has been ruled out of action for up to three months with the injury

WHY ULTRASOUND? 

Ultrasound can be used to help reduce local swelling and chronic inflammation and promote bone fracture healing.

The 26-year-old, posting on his Instagram story, exposed his heavily-tattooed leg as he showed footage of the doctor rubbing a gel into his wounded foot using ultrasound.

This is used to reduce swelling and inflammation to the wounded area and is said to be more sensitive and beneficial than just using x-rays as a form of analysis.

Even without their star man, Brazil had enough talent in their ranks to overcome their hosts 3-0 courtesy of goals from Joao Miranda, Philippe Coutinho and Paulinho. 

The Brazilian forward listened to Drake song God's Plan as he received the treatment

Neymar posted an update on his Instagram story as he received treatment on Monday

Despite this though, Brazil will want Neymar back, fit and ready to play come their opening World Cup game on June 17 when they face Switzerland in Rostov. 

Neymar, however, has been ruled out for up to three months which — should his injury run its expected course — would see him return just two weeks before the start of the tournament.

Brazil continue their World Cup preparations on Tuesday night when they face holders Germany in Berlin, looking to avenge the 7-1 defeat they suffered on home soil four years ago. 

Neymar is due to return from his injury less than two weeks before the World Cup starts

item.title: David Warner 'not allowed to play' in fourth Test against South Africa with Australia vice-captain and Steve Smith set to be axed for a 'stretch of time'
item.description: David Warner is set to be axed for the final Test of Australia's fiery series in South Africa in the wake of the ball-tampering scandal in Cape Town, according to reports Down Under.
item.content:encoded:
David Warner is set to be axed for the final Test of Australia's fiery series in South Africa in the wake of the ball-tampering scandal in Cape Town.

Captain Steve Smith has already been banned for the fourth Test in Johannesburg after admitting to deliberately attempting to change the condition of the ball.

And Warner is set to join him on the sidelines after the pair were temporarily stripped of the captaincy and vice-captaincy during the controversial third Test, according to reports in Australia.

Steve Smith and David Warner could be axed from the Australia team for a 'stretch of time'

Cameron Bancroft was caught rubbing sticky yellow tape on the ball in the third Test

The Canberra Times report: 'Fairfax Media has been told that Smith and Warner in particular can expect to be sidelined for "a stretch of time".'

AUSTRALIA SCHEDULE 

June 2018: Tour of England, 5 ODIs and 1 T20

June-July: Tour of Zimbabwe, 1 Test and 3 ODIs

July: Bangladesh in Australia, 2 Tests and 3 ODIs

October: Tour of Pakistan, 5 ODIs and 1 T20

October-November: South Africa in Australia, 5 ODIs and 3 T20s

November-January 2019: India in Australia, 4 Tests

They claim that Warner is emerging as the central character in the ball-tampering scandal, as revealed by Sportsmail on Sunday.

Australia tour England in June for five one-day internationals and a T20 match before facing Zimbabwe and Bangladesh later this summer.

Smith admitted on Saturday that Australia's 'leadership group' concocted the plan, which was exposed when Cameron Bancroft was caught rubbing sticky yellow tape on the ball.

Cricket Australia chief James Sutherland is on his way to South Africa to deal with the escalating crisis and will join the organisation's head of integrity, Iain Roy, and the executive general manager of team performance, Pat Howard, who arrived in Cape Town on Monday morning.

David Warner has emerged as a central character in the ball-tampering controversy

Bancroft was seen running his hand over the ball, before removing a yellow object from his pocket and placing it down the front of his trousers

Cricket Australia chief James Sutherland is flying out to South Africa to investigate the scandal

'Iain will immediately conduct his inquiries around the specifics of the ball tampering incident,' Sutherland said.

'I am travelling to Johannesburg this evening and will arrive Tuesday morning local time to meet Iain to understand the findings of the investigation to that point, and to determine recommended outcomes.

'We know Australians want answers and we will keep you updated on our findings and next steps, as a matter of urgency.'

Captain Steve Smith has already been banned for the fourth Test in Johannesburg after admitting to deliberately attempting to change the condition of the ball. And Warner is set to join him on the sidelines after the pair were temporarily stripped of the captaincy and vice-captaincy during the controversial third Test, according to reports in Australia.

item.title: Nasser Hussain's player ratings: Joe Root needs to take responsibility for England's bowling attack and it is time for Moeen Ali to be dropped
item.description: NASSER HUSSAIN: Moeen Ali's bowling was innocuous yet again. I think it’s time for a change now – which could mean a Test debut for Somerset’s Jack Leach at Christchurch.
item.content:encoded:
England's miserable winter of Test cricket continued on Monday as they were thrashed by an innings and 49 runs by New Zealand.

Having been skittled for 58 on the first day, England did well to push the contest to the final session of the fifth day, though almost two days were lost to rain in Auckland.

Sportsmail's NASSER HUSSAIN rates and slates both sides' performance in the first Test... 

 

Alastair Cook failed twice and needed to play more ahead of the first Test in Auckland

Alastair Cook 2 

Failed twice. Some will say he was unlucky in the second innings to be caught down the leg side, but when he’s out of rhythm his head falls over to the off side and he becomes vulnerable to those deliveries. 

He’s the kind of player who needs to get into a groove, but two weeks before he came out to New Zealand he was lambing on his farm. He needed to play more before an important Test series.

Mark Stoneman 5

He’s made a few starts now in Test cricket, but hasn’t made more than 56. That was a disappointing way to go in the second innings: he must have known Neil Wagner would bounce him, and there were men out for the shot. 

He needs to convert one of his starts in the second Test at Christchurch. If not, he’ll be looking over his shoulder.

Joe Root 6

He made a gutsy half-century in the second innings, but his dismissal in the last over of the fourth evening left the door open for New Zealand. 

And he was one of many to play a loose shot on that horrific first morning – an expansive drive against the swinging ball wasn’t a great option. He should also take some responsibility for England’s attack. 

He said before the game that his team needed to do things differently after the Ashes, then went in with four right-arm seamers of roughly the same pace.

Joe Root has to take responsibility for selecting four seamers of roughly the same pace

Dawid Malan 4 

He basically got out to a couple of prods. He’s been playing the ball late, which is the right thing to do, but he wasn’t moving his feet, so it looked as if he was playing French cricket. 

He’s looking a bit vulnerable outside off stump, like he did in England last summer.

Ben Stokes 6

Another bloke who suffered from a lack of preparation, though for different reasons. But to expect him to go out at No 5 against Trent Boult and Tim Southee was a big ask. 

He played well second time round, but then got out just before the dinner break. 

Perhaps the problems he was having with his back meant he felt he had to take on Wagner’s short stuff, but it was a wide ball and he could easily have left it alone.

Jonny Bairstow 5

He kept well, but had a couple of soft dismissals. He was out driving on the up in the first innings, then pulled a long hop straight to midwicket in the second – not long after pulling a long hop to mid-on and being dropped.

Jonny Bairstow kept well but was guilty of a couple of soft dismissals with the bat

Moeen Ali's bowling was innocuous and he did not look like he was watching the ball either

Moeen Ali 4

His bowling was innocuous yet again, as it has been all winter, and I think it’s time for a change now – which could mean a Test debut for Somerset’s Jack Leach at Christchurch. 

He missed a full-toss in the first innings, and I’m not sure he’s watching the ball properly – maybe because he’s worried about the short delivery.

NEW ZEALAND RATED

Jeet Raval 2, Tom Latham 4, Kane Williamson 9.5, Ross Taylor 4, Henry Nicholls 9.5, BJ Watling 6, Colin de Grandhomme 5, Todd Astle 7, Tim Southee 9, Trent Boult 9.5, Neil Wagner 8 

Chris Woakes 6

That was a good effort with the bat on the last day, but his bowling has been a concern this winter. 

In a way, he mirrors England’s problem: he was excellent in the one-day series, when batsmen come after him, but toothless in the Tests, when they can just wait for the bad ball. He needs to find nip and pace with the Kookaburra.

Craig Overton 6

His first-innings runs meant England avoided being bowled out for 30, but his bowling just looks a bit samey – he’s the fourth right-arm seamer in the team, and probably the slowest. 

He’s symptomatic of England’s lack of X-factor in their attack, which is why they may look to Mark Wood for Christchurch.

Craig Overton is symptomatic of England's lack of X-factor in their seam attack

Stuart Broad 7

Despite the work he’s put in, I’m not convinced he’s moving the ball away from the right-hander. 

His wrist still looks to be in more or less the same position to me. It was nice for him to get to 400 Test wickets, and he might have had a couple more but for dropped catches.

Jimmy Anderson 7

He bowled pretty well, even though he’s not a big fan of pink-ball cricket when the lights aren’t on. He’s going to be around for a while yet, but he needs others to back him up. 

It worries me that even with four England greats in this side – Cook, Root, Broad and Anderson – they have lost nine of their last 10 Tests away from home. They need to start planning for the future.

item.title: West Ham co-owner David Sullivan in new controversy after court rules he used club to avoid £700,000 tax bill
item.description: West Ham have suffered further distractions off the field following the news that co-owner David Sullivan avoided paying £700,000 in taxes through the Premier League club.
item.content:encoded:
West Ham have suffered further distractions off the field following the news that co-owner David Sullivan avoided paying £700,000 in taxes through the Premier League club.

The 69-year-old has been told to repay the sum,The Times reported, and it comes at a time when Sullivan was already hitting headlines for wrong reasons.

The West Ham chief, who it is understood intends to appeal the ruling, was hit in the face by a coin amid angry protests at the London Stadium as the relegation-threatened club lost 3-0 to Burnley.

West Ham chief David Sullivan has been ordered to repay £700,000 in tax after a court ruling

Supporters are unhappy at what they feel have been 'false promises' from those in charge of the Hammers, while their new home in Stratford continues to cause problems.

Sullivan in particular has taken most of the frustration from fans but he is still set to attend their Premier League relegation six-pointer against Southampton this Saturday.

Yet this speculation over tax avoidance has come at an inconvenient time.

Sullivan has been subjected to abuse and criticism from West Ham fans at recent matches

Sullivan used his company Conegate Ltd to purchase £2million in West Ham shares in 2010

It appears there have been issues with the way Sullivan used his company Conegate Ltd to purchase £2million in West Ham shares in 2010.

The first-tier tax tribunal heard that on the same day, they were then sold back to the club for £1, diminishing Conegate's tax bill.

Sportsmail has contacted West Ham for comment but is yet to receive a response.

item.title: Jorge Sampaoli claims the World Cup is a ‘revolver to Lionel Messi’s head’ and the pressure put on him means he cannot enjoy playing for Argentina
item.description: Argentina manager Jorge Sampaoli has claimed the World Cup is like 'a revolver' to Lionel Messi's head and the pressure of winning the tournament means he cannot enjoy playing for his country.
item.content:encoded:
Argentina manager Jorge Sampaoli has claimed the World Cup is like 'a revolver' to Lionel Messi's head and the pressure of winning the tournament means he cannot enjoy playing for his country.

Messi has won countless trophies at club level and numerous individual awards but is yet to taste any major success at senior international level.

He has lost in three Copa America finals and came closest to winning the World Cup in Brazil four years ago when Argentina were beaten 1-0 by Germany in extra time in the final.   

Jorge Sampaoli has claimed the World Cup is like 'a revolver' to Lionel Messi's head

Sampaoli has written a book, due to be released in April, and in extracts published in 'Viva', the Argentinian boss believes Messi suffers under the enormous pressure placed on him on the world stage.

'Messi has a revolver put to his head called the World Cup and if he doesn't win it, he's shot and killed,' Sampaoli wrote.  

'As a result, he can't enjoy his talent. What I find is that the negativity surrounding international football damages Messi.

'At this moment, I feel that I'm coaching the best player in history. This is a guy who has stayed as the best in the world for 10 years.'

Sampaoli claims the pressure of winning the World Cup means he cannot enjoy playing

Messi has won countless trophies at club level but is yet to taste major international success

He has lost in three Copa America finals and came close to winning the World Cup in 2014

Messi will have another opportunity to lift the elusive World Cup trophy in Russia this summer, with Argentina's attacking talents making them one of the favorites for the tournament once again.

Their star man is also in red hot form going into the event having scored 35 goals in 43 games this season as he aims to fire Barcelona to the treble before the end of the domestic season.

Argentina have been drawn in Group D and will play Iceland, Croatia and Nigeria in Russia.

item.title: Anthony Joshua has breathed excitement back into the heavyweight division... as well as restoring dignity to this hard old game!
item.description: JEFF POWELL: AJ pondered before agreeing to shake hands with Joseph Parker at the start of another big fight week leading to another world heavyweight championship bonanza.
item.content:encoded:
Anthony Joshua pondered for several pregnant seconds before agreeing to shake hands with Joseph Parker at the start of another big fight week leading to another stadium extravaganza, another world heavyweight championship bonanza.

Respect has been the Joshua persona since he won his first alpha-belt two years ago.

The preference for courtesy rather than calumny then became ingrained in him by his admiration for Wladimir Klitschko.

Anthony Joshua takes on Joseph Parker in a heavyweight unification bout on Saturday night

AJ and New Zealand's WBO champion collide at the 80,000 Principality Stadium in Cardiff

Far from detracting from the spectacle at Wembley, the mutual appreciation between the legendary veteran and the new kid on the block delivered an epic contest in the highest sporting traditions.

It did so in defiance of boxing's boorish tendency towards trash talk. It stayed that way for Joshua's next fight, against Carlos Takam.

By such decency, come Saturday in the Principality, Joshua will have filled national stadiums to their 80,000-plus capacities three times in succession.

This young man called AJ has not only breathed excitement back into the heavyweight division but has also restored dignity to this hard old game. So much so that sponsors and advertisers who used to shy away from prize-fighting are opening their boardroom doors wide to admit his broad shoulders.

Now Joshua's conversion from gang life to role model is being tested by insults from the team behind Parker, a rival world champion whose WBO belt he wants to add to his IBF, WBA and fringe IBO collection.

There was mutual appreciation between Joshua and Wladimir Klitschko when they fought 

Joshua has restored dignity to boxing with his respect for his heavyweight opponents

The mean streets were calling Joshua back as the two of them sat across a studio table from each other for Sky's Gloves Are Off prelude to this Saturday's head-on collision in Cardiff.

Eddie Hearn, as all promoters do, kind of wanted AJ to crack in the hope that a verbal explosion might generate even more pay-per-view sales.

Johnny Nelson, the former world champion who refereed the broadcast, did his best to stir a witches' cauldron of controversy.

To his immense credit, Joshua held his temper. There were flashes of anger in his eyes but he repeatedly paused long enough to measure his words. He refused to be provoked.

The effect was actually more menacing than an ugly descent into lurid threats. The pent-up tension in a natural-born fighting man glowered at Parker through those silences.

Joshua insists he cannot afford to lose to Parker as 'too many people are relying on me'

AJ was ready for battle, a week early. His rival, if not exactly cowed, became more and more congenial as the programme went on.

'I will have to punish you,' was as far as Joshua would go towards banging the box office drum. Even that guarded rejoinder came with this explanation: 'Because I cannot afford to lose. Too many people are relying on me now so I simply can't allow you to beat me.' Parker responded in kind with regard to the importance of the first heavyweight title fight ever to take place between two undefeated world champions on British soil.

As Joshua studied him intently, Nelson asked if they were prepared for that hand-shake.

Time stood still as Joshua looked deep into Parker's Kiwi heart.

His only word came as a question to the man whose handlers had described him as a muscle-bound, chinless wonder: 'Respect?' Parker reached for the proffered hand: 'Yes, respect.' Round one to Anthony Joshua.

 

Joshua v Parker will be televised live on Sky Sports Box Office on Saturday night.

item.title: Tiger Woods biography reviewed: The tell-all tale that lays bare his life... as a journalist I wanted to praise it but as a sports lover I wanted to chuck it away
item.description: DEREK LAWRENSON - WORLD OF GOLF: Our 19-year-old son came home from university and startled his mother by announcing he was going to hit 250 balls each day on the practice ground.
item.content:encoded:
A few days ago, our 19-year-old son came home from university and promptly startled his mother by announcing he was going to hit 250 balls each day on the practice ground.

Given he had attained a five handicap while barely hitting 250 practice balls in total, she wondered what on earth had prompted such a change.

'Tiger Woods,' he said. 'Watching him has just inspired me. I've never seen a sportsman play with such intensity. He's incredible.' 

Tiger Woods' tale is admirably told in the new biography published by Simon and Schuster

I thought of that while reading a mammoth new biography on Tiger, entitled Tiger Woods, that reaches the bookshelves on Tuesday and which the publisher, Simon and Schuster, hopes will be seen as the definitive work. It's certainly an admirable piece of reporting, with over 400 new interviews carried out.

Even someone like myself who knows the Tiger story backwards can learn plenty of new details, thanks to the diligence of the joint authors, Jeff Benedict and Armen Keteyian.

They even tracked down Tiger's first love, Dina Gravell, and report the heartless way they parted (yep, the heartlessness came from Tiger).

They provide convincing evidence to show the well-documented story that Tiger was tied up aged five at his kindergarten and racially abused by older boys was, in fact, baloney made up by his father, Earl, to fuel the legend. 

It consists of revelations that the most educated Woods fans would be stunned to discover

The book begins with a revelation that stops you in your tracks, and the news that the father of arguably the most famous sportsman of the last 20 years is actually buried in a small, unmarked grave in Kansas — the quiet revenge of his long-suffering wife Tida (Tiger's mother), the joint authors infer.

So begins a rattling read, taking us through the most dramatic rise and fall of perhaps any sportsman in history. If you thought Tiger wasn't a nice man, here you'll learn the full, gory details.

Earl comes out of it even worse, portrayed as a borderline sadist and a man who lived out his final days surrounded by pornographic videos and sex toys. 

The biography reveals that Woods' father, Earl (right), is buried in an unmarked grave in Kansas

Yet the book comes out at a time when the American sporting world is showing by the week that it has moved on from all that, and that might just be a problem for the authors.

As we prepare for his return to the Masters, and what might prove to be the greatest sports comeback of all, do people want to read a book that's high on the tawdriness of Tiger's life, but pretty low on the poetry?

'I ask that one day you will find room in your hearts to forgive me,' Tiger said, in a statement he read out at the height of his scandal, and it seems resoundingly clear the answer is that they have. 

The record crowds attending his Tour comeback suggest he has been forgiven

Record crowds have flocked to each of the five tournaments of his comeback this year, which in turn have been watched by record audiences on television. And now we have the most eagerly anticipated Masters in recent memory.

Superbly written as it is, this book wouldn't make you want to pick up a golf club. In reaching down for Tiger's dark soul, the authors haven't balanced it with anything revelatory about all those blessed days when he played the game better than any man who ever lived, and why he inspired everyone under the age of 30 that he will take on at Augusta National; why, even at the age of 42, he's still inspiring a 19-year-old living 3,000 miles away to go to the practice ground.

The journalist in me read this book wanting to praise it to the heavens. The sports lover wanted to chuck it in the trash.

 

QUOTE OF THE WEEK

'I used to draw up cartoon characters of me as a kid as the Masters champion and then it happened. And never has a green coat ever felt so good. 'That's just the greatest golf tournament that's ever been played and now we're about to go back. I couldn't get lucky three times, could I?'

One thing's for sure: you certainly wouldn't rule out a third win for the amazing Bubba Watson, following his victory in the WGC-Match Play on Sunday. He's the perfect combination: brilliant and creative enough to stay the right side of all of Augusta's fine lines and daft enough to remain oblivious to all the hype and pressure.

Bubba Watson's brilliant and creative play leaves him in a good place heading into the Masters

 

RYDER REPEAT FOR HAZELTINE

After the US finally managed to get a win at the Ryder Cup, officialdom at the PGA of America are so excited they've announced the matches will be returning to Hazeltine in beautiful Minneapolis for the 2028 edition.

So, put that one down for a Europe win, with a team captained by the inspirational Sergio Garcia and led from the front by a then 39-year-old Northern Irishman, with a headline on Monday morning following its thrilling conclusion that reads: Rory's Revenge.

item.title: Manchester United, Liverpool and Arsenal target Stefan De Vrij 'ready to snub elite clubs and join Inter Milan'
item.description: Lazio contract rebel Stefan De Vrij is ready to reject a host of Premier League clubs and Barcelona to sign for Inter Milan on a free transfer this summer, according to reports in Italy.
item.content:encoded:
Lazio contract rebel Stefan De Vrij is ready to reject a host of Premier League clubs and Barcelona to sign for Inter Milan on a free transfer this summer, according to Gazzetta dello Sport.

The Dutchman has already confirmed he will not extend his Lazio contract beyond the end of this season and is free to sign a pre-contract agreement with any club outside of Serie A.

Manchester United, Arsenal, Liverpool and Manchester City have all been credited with an interest in De Vrij, but he is ready to reject them all after verbally committing himself to Inter Milan.

Stefan de Vrij pictured playing for Holland in their 1-0 defeat by England on Friday evening

Under Bosman rules, De Vrij cannot sign a pre-contract deal with a club in the same division so will have to wait for his deal to officially expire on June 30, but for all intents and purposes, Gazzetta say the race for his signature is over.

It is claimed the 26-year-old will sign a five-year contract worth £70,000 per week, which will include a host of performance-related bonuses. Although modest by Premier League standards, it was enough to fend off England's big spenders.

Lazio, however, could significantly boost their chances of changing De Vrij's mind by beating Inter Milan to fourth place in Serie A, thus taking the last Champions League qualifying spot.

They sit just one point behind them in the table in fifth place although Inter could stretch that lead to four by winning their game in hand.

The 26-year-old has reportedly snubbed a host of Premier League clubs for Inter Milan

item.title: Michy Batshuayi jokes of his concerns that Usain Bolt will steal his Borussia Dortmund spot: 'I am happy for him, but I hope he doesn't take my place!'
item.description: While Chelsea loanee Michy Batshuayi was away focusing on his international duties with Belgium, the sprint king enjoyed a 'trial' with Bundesliga outfit Borussia Dortmund.
item.content:encoded:
Michy Batshuayi has joked that he hopes Usain Bolt doesn't take his place up front for Borussia Dortmund.

While the Chelsea loanee was away focusing on his international duties with Belgium, the sprint king enjoyed a 'trial' with the Bundesliga outfit.  

The 100-metre world-record holder has long desired to play for Manchester United and now that his athletics career is over, he is devoting more time to his other love, with Dortmund inviting him to join training during the domestic break.

Usain Bolt showed off his football skills as he trained with Borussia Dortmund on Friday

Michy Batshuayi watched videos of sprint king Bolt while on international duty with Belgium 

And speaking ahead of Belgium's clash with Saudi Arabia, Batshuayi revealed he was impressed by the 31-year-old's football skills.

'I watched the videos,' the striker told Belgium media on Monday.

'He did nutmegs and scored a good goal. He's a champion. He pushes himself beyond his limits every day.

'He wants to beat all the records. He's trying to establish himself in another sport, that's classy, I'm happy for him. But I hope he doesn't come and take my place!'

Batshuayi has been in fine form for Dortmund, scoring eight goals in just 11 matches

However, Batshuayi should have no worries about anyone taking his place in the Dortmund starting XI after a fine introduction to life in Germany.

Since joining on loan from Chelsea at the end of the January transfer window, the 24-year-old has netted eight times in just 11 matches in all competitions.

He will be desperate to continue his fine form as he looks to fight his way back into the Chelsea fold next season.

item.title: David Beckham reveals how he was once told by an England youth coach that he would never play for his country because he was 'too small'
item.description: Former England captain David Beckham has revealed how he was once told he was 'too small' to play for his country. Beckham is the second most-capped England player in history.
item.content:encoded:
Former England captain David Beckham has revealed how he was once told he was 'too small' to play for his country.

Beckham is the second most-capped England player of all time, having made 115 appearances for the Three Lions.

But when he was child he was told that he wouldn't have a chance of cutting it at international level because of his size.

David Beckham is England's second most-capped player with 115 appearances in total

'At about 12 years old, I was told I would never play for my country,' he said.

'And that was told to me by an England coach at the time, at a lower level.

'I was trying to get into a school, academy and they said you're too small, not strong enough and "you'll never play for your country".'

Beckham was told when he was a youngster that he was 'too small' to play for his country

'Thirty years on, I made 115 appearances for my country, captained my country, played three World Cups and a had pretty good career.

'So, my message to young people out there is, there might be difficult times, difficult moments, but believe in yourself, have fun, enjoy yourself and just love the game.'

Beckham has moved on from his career as a player and now owns a Miami-based MLS franchise.

He has big plans for his new team, which will officially become the 25th franchise of MLS and is expected to begin playing in 2020.

Beckham is currently in Indonesia to attend a charity event to raise funds for a football centre

According to reports, Beckham is planning to call on his former boss Carlo Ancelotti to guide his new team through its infancy, with the Italian still out of work following his departure from Bayern Munich.

Beckham played under Ancelotti during his short stint at Paris Saint-Germain in 2013 and is believed to be on good terms with the Italian.

Other managerial candidates include Real Madrid's Zinedine Zidane, who Beckham played alongside at the Bernabeu, and former LA Galaxy and US national team coach Bruce Arena. 

It is also understood that Beckham wants to sign Wayne Rooney and Cristiano Ronaldo.

Beckham plans to call on his former boss Carlo Ancelotti to lead his new MLS franchise

Beckham wants Wayne Rooney and Cristiano Ronaldo to lead the new team on the pitch

item.title: BUMBLE AT THE TEST: Australia have a golden chance to come up with a new set of values after this ball-tampering scandal... how many will be thought of as champions when they retire?
item.description: DAVID LLOYD IN AUCKLAND: When an elite Australian sportsman retires he is usually considered a champion for the rest of his life. How many of this team will be thought of as champions?
item.content:encoded:
The fall-out from Australia's ball-tampering during the third Test against South Africa has continued unabated.

Steve Smith faces increasing scrutiny as captain after being stood down in Cape Town and banned by the ICC for the final match of the series in Johannesburg.

All this while England crashed to an innings defeat in New Zealand. Sportsmail's DAVID LLOYD has given his views on an eventful week for the cricketing world.  

 

Australia have a golden opportunity to come up with a new set of values when the dust settles

When the dust settles in South Africa this will be a golden opportunity for Australia to come up with a new set of values. 

When an elite Australian sportsman retires he is usually considered a champion for the rest of his life. How many of this team will be thought of as champions when they pack up?

 

It should be stressed that ball tampering despite the stigma attached to it is considered a level two offence in cricket. 

If the game is serious about it must elevate it to a level four. You all know what I think the answer should be don't you? 

Red and yellow cards anyone? They are getting nearer and nearer.

How many of this team will be thought of as champions when they hang up their boots?

Despite the stigma attached to ball tampering it is considered a level two offence in cricket

 

I still cannot believe that the whole Australian team and coaching set up were comfortable with the plan hatched by Steve Smith and company. 

They all must have known what was going on. Why didn't someone stand up and say "no"? Who is the man who is going to lead Australia out of this crisis?

 

I didn't like the sight of Australian prime minister Malcolm Turnbull getting involved

I'm not a fan of prime ministers getting involved in sport. Politicians more than anyone should put their own houses in order before they start spouting off. 

So I didn't like the sight of Malcolm Turnbull having a go with all his minions standing behind him like nodding dogs. Cricket can sort this out without his help.

 

Dawid Malan will have to have a look at his two dismissals at Eden Park because they were absolutely identical. He was stuck on the crease, hesitant, neither forward nor back. 

Contrast that with New Zealand's Henry Nicholls who was very decisive. I'm not going to bang on about lack of preparations again but Malan was in the groove in Australia. 

Now he's out of it. He wasn't the only one and England's away record is a growing cause for concern.

Dawid Malan will have to look at his pair of identical dismissals in the first New Zealand Test

 

After all that went on here and in Cape Town we all needed a stiff drink on Sunday night. Trouble was, with a late finish, nowhere was open. 

Luckily my commentary colleague Simon Doull had the answer. He mentioned on air I would be singing Sweet Caroline down at Mo's Bar and Mo heard it and went and opened up especially for us! 

A good sing song was had by all – Frank Sinatra, Tom Jones and Engelbert Humperdink were all on the menu.

 

At 5.12pm on Monday suddenly nothing happened. The England batsmen dusted themselves down and called for a drink. Then Colin de Grandhomme called for a drink. 

Then New Zealand complained the ball was out of shape. So the umpires changed the ball and then called an official drinks break five minutes early. 

Get on with the game!

item.title: Watford star Abdoulaye Doucoure says it would be a 'dream' to play for Liverpool amid interest from Premier League rivals
item.description: Abdoulaye Doucoure has impressed at Vicarage Road over the past two seasons and has been a near ever-present this campaign, starting every Premier League match bar one.
item.content:encoded:
Watford midfielder Abdoulaye Doucoure has admitted it would be a 'dream' to play for Liverpool.

The 25-year-old has impressed at Vicarage Road over the past two seasons and has been a near ever-present this campaign, starting every Premier League match bar one. 

He was part of Javi Gracia's side blown away at Anfield earlier this month as they were beaten 5-0, and the former France Under-21 international insists he would love to line-up on the opposite side in the future.   

Watford midfielder Abdoulaye Doucoure has says it would be a 'dream' to play for Liverpool

Doucoure has also been linked with moves to Manchester United and Tottenham, and the holding midfielder has admitted he is looking to play Champions League football in the near future. 

'Liverpool is a club that needs no introduction,' Doucoure told the French television programme Canal Football Club. 'I was desperate to play at Anfield, I wanted to feel the atmosphere.

'For me it would be a dream to play for a club like this.

'I am grateful to Watford, I have the confidence of this club, it is the one who revealed me to the Premier League.

Doucoure has missed just 90 minutes of Premier League football all season for Watford

'If there is an offer, we will discuss to find the best solution. Everyone wants to play in the Champions League, the big competitions.'

It is not the first time Doucoure has been drawn on his future, and Gracia has admitted in the past he is unsure whether his star midfielder will be at the club beyond the summer.

'I don't know, I don't know what happens in the future, whether he will sign a new contract or stay with us a long time, I don't know,' the Spaniard said.

item.title: Gareth Southgate ready to ring the changes for England's friendly against Italy with Eric Dier, Ashley Young and Jamie Vardy pushing for starts
item.description: England manager Gareth Southgate will ring the changes for the his side's friendly against Italy with Jamie Vardy, Eric Dier and Ashley Young all pushing for starts for the clash at Wembley.
item.content:encoded:
England manager Gareth Southgate will ring the changes for the final friendly before he names his World Cup squad.

Southgate will shuffle his pack for Tuesday night's prestige friendly against Italy as he looks to give all his players an opportunity to impress before he picks his squad for Russia.

'We'll make some changes; some of these guys, it's important we see them in the games,' explained Southgate.

Gareth Southgate (centre) is expected to make a number of changes for the game against Italy

Jamie Vardy is thought to be one England player in line to start in the Wembley friendly

'Some we've brought in to still feel part of the group, or to look at them for the first time and how they train with us.

'We have to look beyond the summer as well. We're trying to build on what we've done in the last few matches.' 

Jack Butland will start at Wembley, replacing Jordan Pickford who played - and kept a clean sheet - in Friday's win over Holland.

Eric Dier, Ashley Young and Jamie Vardy are also expected to be drafted into the Southgate's starting XI for the clash against the Italians.

Dier is expected to start in the centre of midfield, though Southgate could move him into England's back-three later in proceedings.

Eric Dier is likely to play in midfield but is also an option at centre-back for England

'I don't think we will start him at centre-back,' explained Southgate on Monday.

'It's less of an option that we need to look because Eric has played there for his club and we know he can play there.

'So if we get the opportunity we will but we know it's an option we have with Eric.' Dele Alli is also pushing for a recall after starting Friday's win in Amsterdam on the bench, while Lewis Cook is hoping for an England debut at some point on Tuesday night.

Southgate is also keen for Adam Lallana, who didn't train fully last week, to play a part against the Italians. 

Fitness concerns over Harry Maguire and Joe Gomez's withdrawal from the squad with an ankle injury may open the door to James Tarkowski or Alfie Mawson to make their international debuts.

Meanwhile, Southgate is set to continue with his ploy to utilise Kyle Walker in an unfamiliar role as central defender against the Italians.

Ashley Young, pictured here during England training on Monday, is set to start v Italy

The Manchester City right-back was deployed in the unusual position against the Dutch and Southgate has intimated it is a tactic he will persist with.

'There is a benefit to building on what we did. Kyle has all the qualities to play there,' said Southgate.

'If you are playing on the side of a three the ability to defend in wide areas and use the ball as comfortably as he could, he is in areas that he is used to.

'And his athleticism not only to defend big spaces and cover the rest of the defence but also his ability to drive out.'

item.title: Patrick Kluivert indicates pride after watching son Justin win first Holland cap aged just 18 in comfortable friendly win over Portugal
item.description: Patrick Kluivert has posted an emotional video on social media after watching his son Justin earn his first cap for Holland on Monday evening in his country's 3-0 victory over Portugal
item.content:encoded:
Patrick Kluivert has posted an emotional video on social media after watching his son Justin earn his first cap for Holland on Monday evening.

Kluivert Junior was introduced as a 77th minute substitute for goalscorer Memphis Depay as the Dutch secured a comfortable 3-0 friendly victory over Portugal in Geneva.

And father Patrick decided to film the special moment before posting on Instagram with the captain: 'So proud of you my son. Hard work pays off. Love you.' 

Justin Kluivert (right) won his first cap for Holland on Monday, replacing Memphis Depay

So proud of you my son #hardworkpaysoff ❤️you @justink_ ��#holland ����

A post shared by Patrick Kluivert (@patrickkluivert9) on Mar 26, 2018 at 2:27pm PDT

Goals from Memphis Depay, Ryan Babel and Virgil van Dijk helped new Holland manager Ronald Koeman to his first win in charge against Fernando Santos' Portugal, who had defender Joao Cancelo dismissed in the second-half.

Aged just 18, this has been something of a breakthrough season for Kluivert Junior, who has scored seven times and assisted four in the Eredivisie. 

Speculation has already started to mount with regards to a potential summer transfer, with Manchester United among those linked. 

However, father Patrick, a former Barcelona player, would like to see the teenager follow in his footsteps and move to the Camp Nou one day.

Kluivert Junior has been linked with Manchester United following his superb form this season

'I'm very proud of him. He's doing very good at Ajax,' he told Omnisport.

'He's now a first XI player. If he's playing like this in the long-term, he could be one important player in the future.

'Of course, I prefer that he goes to Barcelona but in football everything can happen.

'He's an adult, he can make his own decisions but he's already said it's a dream for him to play for Barcelona. But you never know in football.'

item.title: Michael Vaughan says he is 'pretty sure' Australia tampered with the ball against England: 'Look at the amount of tape some of the fielders have worn, particularly during the Ashes series'
item.description: The former England captain's claim comes after Australia skipper Steve Smith admitted this weekend his side had tried to manipulate the ball during the third Test defeat to South Africa.
item.content:encoded:
Michael Vaughan says he is 'pretty sure' Australia were tampering with the ball during this winter's 4-0 Ashes series win over England.

The former England captain's claim comes after Australia skipper Steve Smith admitted this weekend his side had tried to manipulate the ball during the third Test defeat to South Africa.

Smith insisted it was the first time time it had happened under his captaincy, but Vaughan believes it has been going on for 'quite a while'.

Michael Vaughan says he is 'pretty sure' Australia tampered with the ball during the Ashes

It comes after Cameron Bancroft found himself at the centre of ball-tampering allegations

The opening batsman was seen running his hand over the ball, before removing a yellow object from his pocket and placing it down the front of his trousers

Vaughan told BBC Sport: 'I can't believe that this hasn't happened before. I look at the amount of tape some of the fielders have worn, particularly during the Ashes series, mid-on, mid-off. (You) don't have to name names but they know who they are.

'I'm pretty sure that it was going on during the Ashes series.

'But it wasn't the reason why England lost 4-0. They still would have lost that series.'

Joe Root, who captained England Down Under this winter, said on Monday that he saw no reason to suspect Australia of ball-tampering during the series.

The current scandal came to light on Saturday after Cameron Bancroft was caught on camera hiding sticky tape, which he had used to manipulate the ball with debris from the pitch, down his trousers.

Australia beat England 4-0 in the Ashes, but Vaughan believes it may be tainted

England captain Joe Root said he saw no reason to suspect Australia of ball-tampering

Smith admitted the ploy had been devised by the team's 'leadership group' - a body of Australia players whose identity has yet to be revealed.

Vaughan said Australia had broken an 'unwritten rule' in the game by taking an object out onto the pitch to tamper with the ball.

The former batsman, who led England to Ashes success in 2005, said: 'I played for 17 years and there wasn't a team that I played in that didn't get close to the line.

'There was many, you would say tricks, that many teams would use out in the middle.

'You'd see the ball get bounced into the rough to create reverse swing, you'd see sweets in the mouth, you'd see saliva put on the ball to try and keep that shine for longer.

'Is that right? Many will say not, but that's what has happened in the game of cricket for many, many years and will continue to happen, because it's very hard to control.

'One unwritten rule in the game is that you don't take a piece or an object out there to tamper with the ball, and I'm pretty sure the Australians and the players involved in that leadership group will face the consequences.'

He said: 'It doesn't matter what they achieve. They're going be known as a team that cheated.'

Smith has already been banned for the fourth and final Test against South Africa and been removed as captain of Indian Premier League side the Rajasthan Royals.

Bancroft has also been punished by the International Cricket Council while the Daily Telegraph has reported head coach Darren Lehmann - who Smith said was not involved in the plan - will offer his resignation.

Further sanctions could also be on the way following the incident with Cricket Australia's chief executive James Sutherland due in Johannesburg on Tuesday for crisis talks.

Vaughan does not agree with suggestions that Smith should be handed a life ban but believes the legacy of this Australia side will be forever tainted by the scandal.

He said: 'It doesn't really matter what they achieve in their careers. They're going be known as a team that cheated.'

item.title: Italy check in at Wembley as Gianluigi Buffon and Co get ready to step up their preparations for Tuesday's international friendly against England
item.description: Italy have arrived at Wembley ahead of their friendly against England. The Italians lost 2-0 to Argentina on Friday, but have named a strong squad here, with Gigi Buffon in line to feature
item.content:encoded:
Italy have arrived at Wembley ahead of their friendly against England on Tuesday evening. 

Despite defeat last time around, the Italians looked in good spirits as they took a look around the pitch at the home of English football. 

Luigi Di Biagio's men lost 2-0 to Argentina in Manchester on Friday night, but have named a strong squad for the game with the Three Lions, with the likes of Gianluigi Buffon, Marco Verratti and Manchester United's Matteo Darmian all in line to feature.

Italy take a look around Wembley ahead of Tuesday's friendly game against England

Juventus veteran Gianluigi Buffon is in line to feature against Gareth Southgate's side

Interim coach Luigi Di Biagio is looking to impress sufficiently to take the job permanently

Italy will not be at this summer's World Cup following a shock play-off defeat to Sweden, but the fixture against Gareth Southgate's men serves as the ideal opportunity for a number of individuals to stake their claims.

Interim coach Di Biagio will hope to impress sufficiently to take the job on a permanent basis after previously working with Italy's Under 21 side.

Youngsters such as AC Milan's Patrick Cutrone and Fiorentina's Federico Chiesa are also seeking to make the step up from the youth ranks as part of a new era for Italian football.

Goalkeeper Buffon (centre) touching down in London earlier with his Italy team-mates

Chelsea's Davide Zappacosta (left) and PSG's Marco Verratti are also part of the Italy squad

Strikers Ciro Immobile (left) and Andrea Belotti (right) pictured before take-off earlier

Ahead of the game, Cutrone, a 20-year-old forward, said: 'I've worked with Mister [Di Biagio] in the Under 21s and know him well. He is a great coach who demands maximum work, but that's not all, the games are prepared very skilfully.

'The disillusionment was really high in November [when Italy lost to Sweden in the play-offs] but we have to start again. ]

'England have started with the youngsters and we are beginning to do the same.'

item.title: Jack Butland handed starting role for England against Italy as goalkeepers battle for No 1 spot at World Cup 2018
item.description: Jack Butland will be given the chance to audition for England's No 1 jersey at this summer's World Cup after being given the nod to start in Tuesday's friendly with Italy.
item.content:encoded:
Jack Butland will be given the chance to audition for England's No 1 jersey at this summer's World Cup after being given the nod to start in Tuesday's friendly with Italy.

Jordan Pickford put up a strong case for himself with an impressive display against Holland last week, but he will make way for the Stoke goalkeeper for the game at Wembley Stadium.

Gareth Southgate named four shot-stoppers in his squad for this month's friendlies with West Ham's Joe Hart and Burnley star Nick Pope also available for selection and has admitted to having little idea of who is best.

Jordan Pickford, Joe Hart, Jack Butland and Nick Pope chat during England training on Monday

The Stoke goalkeeper will play from the start in England's friendly against Italy on Tuesday

'I know who it would be if we played tomorrow but I think we've still got plenty of football to be played,' he said ahead of the win in Amsterdam.

'It is a very tight call at the moment because there is four guys in the squad who have justifiable claims for different reasons.'

However, the decision to hand Butland a starting berth against the 2006 World Cup winners suggests he is leading the race for England's No 1 jersey alongside Everton star Pickford.

Butland saves a shot during England's latest training session on Monday ahead of their next tie

Butland insists all four of the goalkeepers are likely to benefit from the competition in the ranks and says the ultimate winner in this battle for the World Cup No 1 spot will go to the man who deserves it most.

'It's a good thing isn't it, having competition? I enjoy it,' said Butland.

'Training between all of us is extremely intense. Obviously, it's one we're all trying to take for ourselves but ultimately whoever deserves it, whoever the manager feels, will get it and we're all trying to do our bit to make sure it's us. 

'I think that's a great way to go into a World Cup, the fact not knowing who it is yet shows the competition is great and whoever it will be is going to be coming off a battle, which is what we want.'

Joe Hart is by far the most experienced of the four with 75 caps to his name but he has experienced something of a fall from grace in recent seasons after falling victim Pep Guardiola's axe at Manchester City. He now finds himself as a reserve goalkeeper at relegation-threatened West Ham. 

Pope, meanwhile, has thoroughly impressed in Tom Heaton's absence for Burnley this season, but has no international experience at either youth or senior level. Indeed, this current period has been his first experience with an England squad. 

Butland shares a joke with Pickford and Hart as England continue training on Monday morning

item.title: Ricky Hatton fears Tyson Fury will copy his mistake and pick too tough an opponent on his comeback: 'The damage had already been done with me, I hope it's not done with him'
item.description: Ricky Hatton was not the first fighter whose much-anticipated return to the ring ended in heartbreak. And the Hitman fears he won't be the last as he watches Tyson Fury work towards his comeback.
item.content:encoded:
Ricky Hatton was not the first fighter whose much-anticipated return to the ring ended in heartbreak. And the Hitman fears he won't be the last.

In recent months, he has watched Tyson Fury work towards his own long-awaited comeback. But the former two-weight world champion hopes the self-styled Gypsy King won't follow in his footsteps and jump in too deep, too quickly.

In November 2012, a 34-year-old Hatton returned from a three-a-half-year absence, only to be stopped by the dangerous Vyacheslav Senchenko in his first fight back.

Tyson Fury is targeting a comeback but still has a considerable amount of weight to shift

Both he and Fury, who has not fought since dethroning Wladimir Klitschko in November 2015, had to overcome self-confessed problems with drugs and depression before trying to return to former glories.

Both he and Fury had to shed masses of weight before stepping back through through the ropes. And the Hitman is concerned both he and Fury could pay for their similarly strong will.

'My comeback didn't end up in a win but I lost five stone coming back from depression and suicide and drink and drugs and the whole shabang,' he said last week.

'I picked a harder opponent than I should have done. After what I've been through, that's because I'm strong mentally and Tyson is the same.

Ricky Hatton hopes Fury's comeback will be more successful than his own was back in 2012

'But the damage had already been done with me, I just hope it's not been done with Tyson.' After surrendering the WBO, WBA and IBF titles he won against Klitschko, Fury ballooned up to 25st amid problems away from the ring.

Under new trainer Ben Davison, the self-styled Gypsy King has worked his way back into the heavyweight mix - though no date has been announced for his return.

He is targeting a shot at both Anthony Joshua and Deontay Wilder but Hatton believes he must be careful not to rush his route back to the top.

'If I had Tyson, I wouldn't pick someone he can blow over and I wouldn't pick someone like I picked, I'd go somewhere in the middle so that you're going to get a few rounds off to shake the rust off - someone durable that's on the verge of the top 10, where it'll get you just knocking on the door, he said.

Hatton was stopped by Vyacheslav Senchenko on his first fight back in three-and-a-half years

'But I don't know because he's so strong willed, I think he might pick someone like I did. Don't get me wrong, he's 29. 

'I was 34, he's younger so he might be able to get away with it... he definitely will not pick a blowover because he won't have proved anything to himself. He wants to prove he's still got it. He'll have to pick someone half decent but without picking someone before your time.' 

He added: 'I was looking great in the gym but the minute the bell went I thought: "This is a bit different!" So there's still a lot of ifs but he's been looking sensational and I'm so proud of him.' 

With Fury still yet to sign with any promoter - and with him still carrying a lot of weight to shift - there are still sceptics who fear his plan to become the self-proclaimed second-coming of Muhammad Ali and recapture his heavyweight titles will never materialise.

Fury hasn't fought since dethroning Wladimir Klitschko back in November 2015

Hatton, for one, admits he assumed Fury's latest comeback attempt would be the latest in a series of false dawns. But the Hitman has revealed just how committed his friend has been to making his return.

'When he first did it, I thought he'd do it for a couple of months and then he'd be back on the p***. I'd walk in the pub and I'd see him there and think: "Ah, s***, he fell back," he said.

'But nobody's seen him. The only place I've seen him is gyms. I know where he goes and he's been nowhere near. He's stuck at it and he said to me: "I've got the bit between my teeth. AJ's getting the limelight it should have been me!" That's how he sees it. So you think to yourself that he's going to stick to it. He will fight again.'

 

Sky Sports Box Office will exclusively show the Anthony Joshua v Joseph Parker unification fight on March 31. Available to buy now at www.sky..com/orderboxoffice

In recent months, he has watched Tyson Fury work towards his own long-awaited comeback. But the former two-weight world champion hopes the self-styled Gypsy King won't follow in his footsteps and jump in too deep, too quickly.

item.title: Pep Guardiola's quick fix has got me firing again, claims Raheem Sterling... now England star wants to be loved
item.description: MATT LAWTON: The coach might have been Pep Guardiola and the player might have cost £50m but the focus of at least one session was how for Raheem Sterling to dribble a football.
item.content:encoded:
The coach might have been Pep Guardiola and the player might have cost the best part of £50million but the focus of at least one training session was how best to dribble a football.

It was an exercise, Raheem Sterling conceded on Monday, that he was first shown ‘in the under eights’ but Guardiola clearly felt his young English player had developed some bad habits.

Sometimes good coaching is not about tactical genius but getting the simple things right. Alvin Martin credits former England coach Don Howe with transforming his career when he told him to defend on the half-turn. That, Howe told the then West Ham centre half, was how it was done with England. And, judging by the season he has so far enjoyed, Guardiola has had a similar impact on Sterling.

Raheem Sterling has developed well under Pep Guardiola at Manchester City this season

On Monday the Manchester City winger was actually sat alongside the manager of England ahead of tonight’s friendly with Italy but he was asked to explain how Guardiola had helped him recover from a difficult first year at City that concluded with a miserable experience at Euro 2016.

It was so bad Sterling even tagged himself the ‘hated one’, such was the stick he received from England fans. That said, only on Monday did he realise there was an online campaign to raise enough money to fly him home from France. ‘I didn’t see that,’ he said.

Sterling said the country will reap the rewards if the players feel the ‘love’ of the nation. ‘The players that are there, if we get behind them and give them love you wouldn’t know how much that would help them and boost their confidence.

‘If you want your country to do well, as everyone says, bring a positive light into it. Make the boys go off to the World Cup with a clear head knowing everyone’s behind them. Trust me, you’ll definitely see a better England.’

Sterling trains with England as they prepare to face Italy at Wembley on Tuesday evening

The winger (left) with England manager Gareth Southgate at a pre-Italy press conference

But what of Guardiola? What role has he played in this sporting revival? Sterling said: ‘He makes everyone do the simple stuff. You probably see a lot of us passing out from the back. How you turn out with the ball. It makes our football quicker and makes you think better. It’s what he sees and the attention to detail. If you see a two-yard pass, pass it.

‘When I used to dribble, I’d be on the wing and I’d control it with the outside of my foot. It slows the ball down. He brings you back to what you used to do with the under eights, open your body up, get the rhythm going again. It’s little details like that. When you’re playing a game you probably don’t pick up on it.

‘Little touches outside your foot, trapped under your foot, he’s telling you to get to the left back quicker, open your body out and take it with you instead of just controlling it and stopping. Little details, even though you’re thinking I already know this.’

 

 

Sterling described the Catalan as ‘a good person’. ‘Especially for young players,’ he said. ‘I feel before I was more raw; when I got the ball I wanted to take someone on, beat someone. Now I am trying to pick my moments, if it is on, if it is not, and try to get in the box as much as I can. That’s mainly where I am now.’

Southgate was already listening intently but his interest in the exchange escalated when Sterling referenced him. Asked why it has been three years since he last scored for England, Sterling jokingly blamed the man to his left.

‘It is because the gaffer takes me off early,’ he said with a smile. ‘No, it is a different environment, a different set-up. I should be scoring a lot more for England. I put a lot of pressure on myself. I’ve done that at my club. I wasn’t scoring a lot of goals there either, but that’s changed.’

He did, however, stress that ‘even at Liverpool’ many of his goals ‘came late in games’. And the fact is no other player in the Premier League has scored more goals in the last 10 minutes of a game this season. So maybe Southgate should leave Sterling on when he has hooked him in five of the seven games he has started.

Sterling (left) as a youngster at QPR and playing for England against Holland on Friday (right)

Not that Sterling is looking to shirk responsibility. He started the press conference by insisting that England had not yet benefited from his own rise in standards, stating that on the international stage there was still plenty of room for improvement.

That might well be true, however composed he looked against Holland last Friday, but it remains a significant step up from where he was two years ago. ‘I had a rough year, my first at City, a big club for a big transfer fee,’ he said. ‘There was a lot of talk, a lot of pressure. I didn’t think I was being spoken about in a fair manner.

‘As a young boy, I was 20-21, I didn’t think I was being treated right. It can affect anyone. So it was about how I bounced back, how I had to try and move on. Not let that defeat me.

‘It was disappointing when you put on the shirt and get negative feedback. But at the same time the fans want to see you perform well. They’re not doing it in a malicious way, it’s to make you know you need to step up.’

Ahead of England’s last game before he picks his squad for this summer’s World Cup, Southgate could not have seemed happier. Here, after all, was an important member of his side in good form off as well as on the pitch.

And he encouraged Sterling to take some credit, however influential Guardiola might have been. ‘If a player isn’t willing to learn, and have the mindset and determination to improve, then all of those messages are wasted,’ he said.
