item.title: Chelsea pip Tottenham to signing of Crewe Alexandra's prolific teenage striker George Nunn
item.description: Chelsea have signed Crewe Alexandra's teenage striker George Nunn. The 16-year-old has not made a first team appearance, but was also a target for London rivals Tottenham.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea have signed Crewe Alexandra's teenage striker George Nunn.

The 16-year-old has not made a first team appearance, but has been a prolific scorer at junior level and was also a target for Tottenham.

Crewe will receive about £300,000 in compensation plus add-ons from Chelsea for Nunn, who hails from Nantwich, and has made the step up to under-18 level this season.

Chelsea have beaten Tottenham to the signing of teenage Crewe striker George Nunn

Nunn will look to emulate Tammy Abraham by progressing through the Chelsea youth ranks

Nunn is expected to bolster Chelsea's already burgeoning youth ranks, with Jodie Morris' Under 18 side into the semi-finals of the UEFA Youth League where they will face Porto.

He will be hoping to follow in the footsteps of academy graduate Tammy Abraham, who was a regular scorer for the Blues' age-group sides before making the step up to senior level.

Currently on loan at Swansea, Abraham has struck seven times in 38 games so far this season, earning a call-up for the England squad in the process.

item.title: Anthony Joshua sends intimidating message to Joseph Parker ahead of Saturday's heavyweight unification fight: 'Prepare to be overwhelmed'
item.description: Anthony Joshua says Joseph Parker will be 'overwhelmed' in their unification fight in Cardiff on Saturday. Joshua is the overwhelming favourite for the fight at the Principality Stadium.
item.content:encoded:
WBA and IBF world heavyweight champion Anthony Joshua says Joseph Parker will be 'overwhelmed' in their unification fight in Cardiff on Saturday.

Undefeated Briton Joshua is the overwhelming favourite and will have home advantage in the Principality Stadium, although New Zealander Parker is also unbeaten in his 24 fights and brings with him the WBO belt.

A crowd of 80,000 is expected and Joshua says Parker will have never heard anything like the noise that will be generated.

Anthony Joshua has told Joseph Parker to expect to be 'overwhelmed' in Saturday night's fight

Parker (left) and Joshua will face off in front of an anticipated crowd of 80,000 in Cardiff

'It took me a few times to get used to it,' Joshua, who has a 20-0 record, told the BBC.

'It's an experience he hasn't faced yet. It is daunting, it is overwhelming. You have a fighter that will block out the noise, which takes a whole heap of energy.

'Then you have a fighter who rides the wave, which can leave you too excited. The fight is won or lost in training camp but the last bolt is screwed on during the spell from your changing room to the first bell.'

Three heavyweight belts will be on the line when the two undefeated fighters lock horns

Whoever wins will become a three-belt heavyweight champion and Joshua says the high stakes will create an electric atmosphere in the Welsh capital.

'This is history,' Joshua said. 'This is a unification fight with two heavyweights undefeated and it's in the UK.

'Twenty times out of 20 I've been victorious, so expect the same routine.'

Parker's promoter David Higgins said Joshua is rattled and warned that Tuesday's pre-fight news conference will start without Joshua if he arrives late, as he has done in the past.

'He's rattled and the press conference tomorrow is all part of that,' he told Sky Sports.

'We will be in control of that press conference.'

item.title: Philippe Coutinho shows off incredible new Barcelona home featuring swimming pool and Teqball table... and reveals his old house was burgled
item.description: The Barca forward gave a video crew a tour of his mansion, where he lives with his wife Aine, daughter Maria, sister and two cousins. The home features spacious rooms, pool and large garden.
item.content:encoded:
Philippe Coutinho has shown off his beautiful new home in Barcelona - and opened up about his previous house being burgled last month.

The Barca forward gave a video crew a tour of his mansion, thought to be in the Bellamar, an exclusive area of Barcelona, where he lives with his wife Aine, daughter Maria, sister and two cousins.

The home features a huge living room and kitchen, as well as a swimming pool and large garden.

Scroll down for video. 

Philippe Coutinho showed off his new home in Barcelona to a journalist and film crew

The Barcelona forward has just moved into the new house with his wife, daughter and family

The mansion features a huge living room and kitchen, as well as a garden with a pool

The garden also features a Teqball table - a curved table tennis-size board where players kick a small ball to each other, and which is regularly used by footballers to hone their skills.

Philippe and Aine also told the crew and journalist from Spanish football magazine Mundo Deportivo about their frightening experience at their old home of coming home and finding it burgled. 

Aine said: 'We left the house to have dinner, and when we returned we saw there was a door open that we had left closed.

'We called the police and they came and went through everything. Everything in the house was mixed up but we were lucky nobody was there when it happened.' 

Coutinho and his family moved to Barcelona in January when he transfered to the Nou Camp

The forward also has a Teqball table - a curved table-tennis style game played with a football

The Coutinhos moved to Barcelona in January when Philippe signed at the Nou Camp from Liverpool in a £142million deal. 

He says he is still adapting to life in Spain, having previously lived in Italy - playing for Inter Milan - and north-west England.

Coutinho said: 'I am still adapting, everything is very new. The way of working, the club, the way of playing is a bit different.'

Philippe and Aine also opened up about finding their former home burgled last month

The Catalan footballers’ Beverley Hills, Bellamar is set back into the mountains that overlook the 4-mile stretch of sandy beach at Castelldefels just south of the city. 

Bellamar, where average house prices are between €3m and €5m and half an hour's drive from the Juan Gamper training facility, is one of the most popular areas for Barcelona footballers to live.

It counts Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez among its residents. As well as Coutinho, former Barca Brazilians Neymar and Ronaldinho have also lived there.

item.title: New Zealand thrash England by an innings and 49 runs in first Test at Eden Park despite notable knocks from Ben Stokes and Chris Woakes on final day
item.description: PAUL NEWMAN AT EDEN PARK: To lose in India and Australia could be regarded as misfortune, but to now lose in New Zealand looks more than just carelessness from England.
item.content:encoded:
To lose in India and Australia could be regarded as misfortune, but to now lose in New Zealand looks more than just carelessness from England. Their Test travel sickness is becoming acute.

England's failure to bat out the last day of the first Test here leaves them with no margin for error in the last match of their longest modern winter tour. They have to win in Christchurch to arrest their worst away run since the war.

The statistics are damning. England are without a win in 12 away Tests and have lost 10 of them, five innings defeats coming in their last eight games. 

New Zealand beat England by an innings and 49 runs in the first Test at Eden Park after taking seven wickets on the final day

New Zealand bowler Todd Astle claimed three of those England wickets, including the final one to remove James Anderson

England duo Ben Stokes (right) and Chris Woakes had earlier offered some resistance with knocks of 66 and 52 respectively

The last time it was this bad was between 1938 and 1948, when the country was concerned with a rather more important skirmish going on at home and overseas that stopped play for six years.

Joe Root made all the right noises after England had failed to pull off a second great escape in Auckland in successive tours, but he must know there will be serious questions if this two-Test series is not squared.

England were much better in their second innings at Eden Park — they could hardly be worse — before being bowled out for 320 with less than 19 overs left to hold out, but too many batsmen were complicit in their own demise again.

It says something about England's lack of application that they should lose a wicket in the last over before a break in three successive sessions, starting with the captain's latest failure to turn a half-century into three figures on the fourth evening. Whatever happened to playing for the interval?

It may be harsh to single out Ben Stokes when he batted so well for his slowest half-century in Tests, but his 66 off 188 balls was ended by a brainless piece of cricket all too common in England's Test batting.

Neil Wagner had been undertaking one of his trademark long spells full of short-pitched, aggressive bowling when he rattled Stokes and tempted him into a terrible shot that saw him hole out to point three balls before the dinner break.

At that stage, with England at 300 for six, Stokes and Chris Woakes had batted throughout the middle session and England really did look like replicating their nail-biting draw here in 2013 when they ended up nine wickets down.

Alas, it was not to be and once Stokes had gone the end was nigh for England, the wholehearted Wagner ending with three victims in an excellent New Zealand display.

Worryingly, Stokes had to take painkilling tablets for soreness in his back towards the end of his innings and there will be another 'will he play, won't he play' debate ahead of the second Test in his home city. 

England resumed on 132 for three with Stokes coming in as the new batsman after Joe Root was out at the end of day four

Stokes looked immediately comfortable at the crease and dispatched his first ball for four runs at the start of the final day

Dawid Malan was Stokes' first partner in the middle and he faced 14 balls on the final day before being caught by Tom Latham

Malan, who ended on 23 off 62 balls, looked disappointed as he walked off having edged a Tim Southee delivery to Latham

Jonny Bairstow was the next batsman in for England, coming to the crease with his side on 142 for four in the 52nd over

Bairstow nearly perished for 21 but New Zealand's Trent Boult dropped a sitter of a catch to give the Yorkshireman a let-off

New Zealand were soon able to celebrate the demise of Bairstow, though, with bowler Astle (second left) a happy man

Bairstow was out for 36 off 72 after playing a pull shot at an Astle delivery and finding Kane Williamson at short midwicket

Bairstow's dismissal brought Moeen Ali into the action and he faced 43 deliveries before heading back to the pavilion for 28 

New Zealand pace bowler Boult got rid of Ali with a good-length inswinger which had the England batsman lbw at Eden Park

Ali was not originally given out but New Zealand's players were able to celebrate his departure after a well-judged review

Woakes was faced with a difficult job as he joined Stokes in the middle but he set about business very well in Auckland

Woakes and Stokes congratulated one another in the middle after bringing up their 50 partnership in testing circumstances

It is a crucial question for England because even though their talisman is good enough to play as a specialist batsman, he brings so much more to the team and creates a perfect balance when he is fit to bowl.

As it is, Root is a reluctant No 3 and Dawid Malan looks a little too high at four. Friday's second Test will also be a huge match for Mark Stoneman, who is running out of time to prove he belongs at the highest level, and also two of the most important England players — at least when they are at home.

Moeen Ali had a miserable Ashes and had another poor match here, despite the confidence-boost he should have gained from a successful return to one-day cricket.

He has taken just five wickets at a whopping 126 each in six Tests this winter and is as short of runs as he is wickets. When England were bowled out for 51 in Jamaica in 2009 they dropped Ian Bell. That proved a catalyst for their improvement under new captain Andrew Strauss.

Now, as Root continues making his way as a leader, there is a case to replace Moeen with a wild card in Lancashire's Liam Livingstone or a specialist spinner in Somerset's Jack Leach to shake things up. It has reached the point where there is very little to lose.

Similarly, Woakes might have made a battling half-century and almost taken England to safety but, while it would be unthinkable to drop him at home, his record in his principal role as a bowler overseas is getting worse.

Woakes went wicketless here and is now claiming his victims away from home at more than 60 apiece. Surely it is time to give the extra pace of Mark Wood a go. If England do not trust his fitness, there is no point in him being here. 

Stokes had done excellently to frustrate New Zealand all day but he played a rash shot just before dinner and perished for 66

Stokes, who faced 188 deliveries and hit six boundaries, looked gutted after hitting a Neil Wagner bouncer into Southee's mits

Craig Overton had to deal with some short-pitched bowling after walking out as England's No 9 at the start of the final session

However, it was leg-break bowler Astle who got rid of Overton lbw before expressing his delight with a vocal celebration

To dwell on England's shortcomings would be to deny New Zealand proper praise, for this was arguably their best all-round display under the leadership of Kane Williamson.

HOW BEN WENT FROM BRILLIANT TO BRAINLESS 

Ben Stokes spent four and a half hours grafting his way to 66 off 188 balls.

So what does he do just before the dinner break? He falls hook, line and sinker for Neil Wagner’s bouncer barrage and tries a ridiculously ambitious smash over point. 

The result was a tame catch lobbed up to Tim Southee and the game was up for England.

Boult and Tim Southee were magnificent in bowling England out for 58 on the first day, while the captain was superb with the bat and in the field. The unheralded Henry Nicholls showed England how to play the swinging ball, then Wagner came to the party on the last day.

It was all played out — Australia please note — in a fantastic spirit even when Wagner was charging in and doing his best to give Stokes the evil eye. There really is much to admire in New Zealand's cricket.

Not so much day-night Test cricket. England have played three Tests under lights now — at home last summer against West Indies, against Australia in Adelaide and now here — and evidence suggests the experiment is doomed.

The pink ball is not of a good enough quality and the players do not seem to enjoy the concept. More importantly, there is little evidence that the paying spectators do, either.

Thank goodness Friday's second Test will be played with a red ball during the day at Christchurch's magnificent Hagley Oval.

It is a setting fit for a thrilling denouement to a Test winter of underachievement from England. Now all they have to do is turn up.

Wagner made a huge breakthrough by getting rid of Woakes, caught by Henry Nicholls (right) who then hugged the bowler

Anderson made just one from five balls before being the last man out as New Zealand won the first day-night Test at Eden Park

item.title: France boss Didier Deschamps remains unfazed by Colombia defeat claiming 'I will not change my approach' as his World Cup hopefuls regroup ahead of Russia friendly
item.description: That could easily have put more onus on the result of Tuesday's game away to World Cup hosts Russia, but Deschamps insists he will continue to use the game to assess the options in his squad.
item.content:encoded:
Didier Deschamps will not allow France's shock defeat by Colombia affect his World Cup preparations.

Les Bleus let a two-goal lead slip away as they lost 3-2 to the South American side on Friday, with Juan Quintero's late penalty proving decisive.

That could easily have put more onus on the result of Tuesday's game away to World Cup hosts Russia, but Deschamps insists he will continue to use the game to assess the options in his squad.

France regrouped on Monday as they trained ahead of Tuesday night's friendly with Russia

The French were stunned on Friday night as they conceded a two-goal lead against Colombia

'I am not thinking about the defeat, we have a new match to look forward to,' he told Radio Monte Carlo. 'Now is the time to give playing time to those who have not had it, ahead of the final decisions. I will not change my approach due to Friday's result.

'As always, there will be debates over players and positions. Everyone who is there has the chance to play. I want to put as many players as possible in game situations.'

Marseille's in-form playmaker Florian Thauvin has been forced to pull out of the game with a hamstring problem, while Real Madrid defender Raphael Varane has missed training with an ankle problem.

Defender Laurent Koscielny expects a tough test from Russia and said: 'They are very compact and do not give much space to their opponents, and they have good attacking players.'

Didier Deschamps is unfazed by the defeat and it will not affect his World Cup preparations

Paul Pogba (left) prepares to challenge French colleague Ousmane Dembele for the ball

Thomas Lemar (left) and Pogba will be hoping to help France bounce back from the defeat

The French squad form an orderly line as they engage in some sprinting warm-up drills

Deschamps added: 'It is a little taste of Russia before staying there for a few long weeks, I hope.'

Russia also go into the game on the back of a defeat - 3-0 by Brazil - and coach Stanislav Cherchesov has called for his side to 'redeem themselves'.

'The defeat did not make us very happy and we held a little meeting,' Cherchesov told AFP.

'Tomorrow we have a chance to redeem ourselves. We want to show much better quality against France.'

Barcelona defender Samuel Umtiti (centre) jokes as he passes to team-mate Lemar

Umtiti will be focused on the Russia game despite the speculation surround his club future

Cherchesov will be unable to call on midfielders Daler Kuzyayev and Roman Zobin and defender Ruslan Kambolov, who have all returned to their respective clubs with injuries.

All three are expected to be fit for this summer's tournament but Kambolov's short-term absence adds to a central defensive crisis, with Viktor Vasin and Georgi Dzhikiya both having torn knee ligaments this year. Long-term options Sergei Ignashevich and twins Vasili and Aleksei Berezutskiy have all retired from international football. 

Andrei Lunev is set to start in goal against France rather than Igor Akinfeev, who excelled against Brazil.

item.title: 'Brazil today are at least two classes better than in 2014': Germany star Toni Kroos wary of response as Tite's side aim for measure of revenge in friendly after humiliating World Cup defeat
item.description: Germany are braced to face a much better Brazil side than the one they thrashed at the last World Cup when they meet in a friendly on Tuesday. Germany inflicted a humiliating 7-1 defeat
item.content:encoded:
Germany are braced to face a much better Brazil side than the one they thrashed at the last World Cup when they meet in a friendly on Tuesday.

In 2014 Germany inflicted a humiliating 7-1 defeat to knock the hosts out of their own World Cup, a stunning result which forced a lengthy period of soul-searching for Brazil.

The change in their fortunes has impressed the German players, who know there will be no repeat of that famous scoreline when they meet again in Berlin.

Toni Kroos was amongst the scorers as Germany thrashed Brazil 7-1 at the 2014 World Cup

'Brazil today are at least two classes better than in 2014,' said Toni Kroos, who scored the third and fourth goals in Belo Horizonte.

In comments reported by Kicker, Ilkay Gundogan added: 'They now have a much better balance. The mix is right. Their development has been second to none.'

As they were four years ago, Brazil will be without the injured Neymar, but coach Tite has changed much else besides since taking over.

The remarkable result shocked football but Kroos believes Brazil are now a much better side

The defence which was so shredded by Germany is mostly gone, with David Luiz and Dante displaced by Miranda and Marquinhos, while Alisson and Ederson have improved the goalkeeping. 

Neymar may be missing, but in Philippe Coutinho, Douglas Costa, Willian and Roberto Firmino there are still plenty of attacking options.

PLAYERS FROM 2014 WORLD CUP THAT COULD FEATURE IN FRIENDLY 

Brazil: Marcelo, Fernandinho, Willian 

Germany: Boateng, Hummels, Khedira, Kroos, Draxler

Germany coach Joachim Low is likely to rotate his side after the 1-1 draw with Spain on Friday, with Gundogan among those eyeing his chance.

The Manchester City midfielder has been restricted by a miserable run of injuries in recent years, but feels he is back to his best just in time for Russia.

'It makes me happy to be at a relatively good level so close to the World Cup,' he said. 'I want to keep that up. I'm fit and healthy.

'I want to play the best possible football, and to go into the closing stages of the season taking precautions would not be the right decision. When I'm on the pitch, I'm going full throttle and I try to forget everything else.'

item.title: Former Tottenham starlet William Troost-Ekong becomes 43rd member of Common Goal with Juan Mata's initiative set to invest its £350,000
item.description: Troost-Ekong was born in Holland but began his career at Fulham and then Tottenham. However, after failing to make a breakthrough, he returned to Holland with FC Groningen.
item.content:encoded:
Former Tottenham academy graduate William Troost-Ekong is the latest footballer to commit one percent of his earnings to Common Goal.

The initiative, started by Manchester United's Juan Mata back in August, can now boast 43 players and coaches who together hope to improve the lives of underprivileged children and adults across the globe.

Troost-Ekong was born in Holland but began his football career as a trainee at Fulham and then Tottenham. However, after failing to make a breakthrough, he returned to Holland with FC Groningen.

William Troost-Ekong expressed his pride on Twitter after joining the Common Goal initiative

The 6ft 3ins centre-back now plays for Bursaspor in Turkey and is a Nigeria international. He won a bronze medal at the Rio Olympics but hopes to make a greater impression in Russia this summer.

'Winning the bronze and qualifying for the World Cup have both been massive moments for me but I'm hoping to outdo both of those this summer at the World Cup,' said 24-year-old Trost-Ekong.

Really excited to announce that @WTroostEkong has joined the team! Check out his welcome video (and some World Cup talk) below. ���� #CommonGoal #Jointheteam pic.twitter.com/GxvvFeeH5E

— Common Goal (@CommonGoalOrg) March 26, 2018

The initiative was started by Manchester United star Juan Mata and now has 43 contributors

'I'm aware that I'm a role model for children and football fans and, having travelled the world, I've seen the impact that we have on people's lives. It's our responsibility as players to use that in a positive way.' 

Over the next month, Common Goal hopes to start investing some of the £350,000 raised so far.

Proudly been wearing jerseys of Bursaspor and Naija this season, and now I’m also putting on @CommonGoalOrg ! Very happy to join the team and excited to see how we can help others together. https://t.co/TQWxyP38kJ

— William Troost-Ekong (@WTroostEkong) March 26, 2018

The Nigeria international explained he feels it's his 'responsibility' to act as a role model

item.title: George Groves shows off £250,000 Rolls-Royce Wraith received as a birthday present
item.description: For many young men a new car is the dream birthday present. And this week George Groves was the lucky recipient of a Rolls-Royce Wraith as he celebrated his big day.
item.content:encoded:
For many young men a new car is the dream birthday present.

George Groves has this week lived that dream after being the lucky recipient of a Rolls-Royce Wraith as he celebrated his birthday on Monday.

The British boxer posed in front of his new set of wheels in a picture shared on his Instagram page as he wrote: 'Happy birthday to me!'

George Groves poses in front of his new set of wheels on Instagram - a Rolls-Royce Wraith

Groves has been battling to prove his fitness in recent weeks after defeating Chris Eubank Jnr by unanimous decision to retain his world title last month.

ROLLS-ROYCE WRAITH 

RRP: From £249,240

Max speed: 155.3mph

Horsepower: 465kW 

That saw him book his spot in the World Super Series final, but at the cost of a dislocated shoulder.

Only if he proves his fitness will he be allowed to defend his world super-middleweight title.

Earlier this month Groves submitted an appeal for the final to be postponed from June 2 into July, by which time he is confident of full recovery.

Groves defeated Chris Eubank Jnr by unanimous decision in his most recent fight last month

But Groves suffered a dislocated shoulder and is fighting to prove his fitness ahead of the final

item.title: Ryan Giggs is the ninth Manchester United Treble-winner to manage... but how have the others fared? And what happened to the rest of the squad?
item.description: Ryan Giggs is the ninth member of Manchester United's Champions League winning side of 1998-99 to delve into management having taken the Wales job.
item.content:encoded:
Ryan Giggs is the ninth member of Manchester United's Champions League winning side of 1998-99 to delve into management having taken the Wales job. 

It was a successful start to life as a full-time manager for the 44-year-old - who was United's caretaker manager for four games after David Moyes' sacking in 2014 - as Wales thrashed China 6-0 on Thursday.

But history suggests that Sir Alex Ferguson's pupils do not fare well as managers, as Giggs' team-mates on that famous night in Barcelona will attest to.

Manchester United celebrate their 1999 Champions League final win in Barcelona, since when nine of them have gone on to manage. Key: 1 Henning Berg, 2 Roy Keane, 3 Gary Neville, 4 Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, 5 Teddy Sheringham, 6 Phil Neville, 7 Jordi Cruyff, 8 Jaap Stam, 9 Ryan Giggs

 

HENNING BERG 

The first of the Treble-winning squad to go into management — taking the Lyn job in his native Norway in 2005 — ex-defender Berg has taken charge of over 300 games in four countries. He won the Polish title with Legia Warsaw in 2014 but is best (or worst) remembered for a disastrous 57-day spell in charge of Blackburn in 2012-13.

Berg missed the 1999 final through injury but made five appearances in the Champions League that season and 29 in total.

Managerial record: P 319 W 144 D 78 L 97 W% 45.14 

Henning Berg barks orders from the touchline during his short spell at Blackburn in 2012

ROY KEANE 

The former United skipper needs little introduction but his managerial career has become a distant memory. 

It looked like he would fulfil the potential many saw in him as a player when he guided Sunderland to the Premier League in his first season as a boss in 2006-07 but that quickly turned sour — as did an ill-fated spell at Ipswich. Has been Republic of Ireland No 2 alongside TV punditry duties since 2013.

Keane missed the 1999 final through suspension having inspired a memorable semi-final win over Juventus with a man-of-the-match display in the second leg in Turin.

Managerial record: P 181 W 70 D 42 L 69 W% 38.7

Roy Keane walks down the Old Trafford touchline as Sunderland manager in September 2007

GARY NEVILLE

Neville has probably had the most high-profile post-playing career of any of the 1999 side. The older Neville brother has become the face of Sky Sports' football coverage having first appeared as a pundit in 2011. 

As well as being England assistant for four years under Roy Hodgson, Neville also had a stint in Spain as Valencia manager — but was sacked in March 2016 after just 10 wins in 28 games.

A stalwart of Fergie's side for nearly two decades, right back Neville played the full 90 minutes of the 1999 final. 

Managerial record: P 28 W 10 D 7 L 11 W% 35.71 

Gary Neville did not enjoy the success he was looking for as Valencia manager

OLE GUNNAR SOLSKJAER

Like fellow countryman Berg, Solskjaer endured a managerial nightmare on these shores — his coming with Cardiff in 2014. 

He couldn't save the Bluebirds from Premier League relegation and was sacked after a poor start to life in the Championship. Has enjoyed success at Molde either side of his time in Wales, winning two titles.

Famously scored the injury-time winner in the 1999 final having come on as a late substitute for Andy Cole.

Managerial record: P 233 W 120 D 43 L 70 W% 51.5 

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer applauds the Cardiff fans after they were relegated in 2014

TEDDY SHERINGHAM 

Played on until the ripe old age of 42 but didn't take his first managerial post until aged 49, having spent time as an attack coach at West Ham. 

Lasted just 33 games at Stevenage and even less time at Indian Super League side ATK, where he was sacked in January after only 10 games in charge.

Sheringham scored the other injury-time goal at the Nou Camp — equalising before setting up Solskjaer's dramatic winner.

Managerial record: P 43 W 10 D 13 L 20 W% 23.3  

Teddy Sheringham watches from the Stevenage dugout during a friendly in August 2015

PHIL NEVILLE

The younger Neville brother has just taken on his first managerial role with England's women. 

Like older brother Gary, Phil has spent time as a pundit and at Valencia — where he was an assistant — since retiring and was also first-team coach for David Moyes during his one season as United manager in 2013-14.

Utility man Neville was an unused sub in the 1999 final but a key member of Ferguson's squad, appearing in Europe six times that season.

Managerial record: P 3 W 1 D 1 L 1 W% 33.3 

Phil Neville took charge of his first England women's games in the US earlier this month

JORDI CRUYFF

Son of the legendary Johan, Jordi moved from Maccabi Tel-Aviv's board to their dugout last summer after five years as sporting director. 

Despite being knocked out of the Europa League at the group stage, Cruyff has the club fighting for the Israeli title.

He was never more than a fringe player in his four years at United and he failed to make the bench in the 1999 final, but did make three appearances in Europe that season.

Managerial record: P 44 W 27 D 9 L 8 W% 61 

Jordi Cruyff issues tactical instructions during a Europa League clash against Villarreal

JAAP STAM  

Sacked just this week by Reading — his first managerial post — with the club hovering just above the Championship relegation zone, it hadn't been all bad for Stam at the Madjeski Stadium. 

He did guide the Royals to the play-off final last season, and his coaching apprenticeship at Ajax means he shouldn't struggle to find another job.

A rock at the back for United in the final and in their Treble-winning season, Ferguson says his biggest regret as United boss was letting the Dutchman go in 2001. 

Managerial record: W 98 D 40 L 23 W% 40.8 

Dutchman Jaap Stam could not replicate the success of his first season at Reading

RYAN GIGGS

Having spent two years as Louis van Gaal's assistant and the next 18 months waiting for the right opportunity to come along, Giggs has finally take his first full-time managerial post with the country he won 64 caps for. 

Managerial record: P 5 W 3 D 1 L 1 W% 60

Ryan Giggs shares a joke with Gareth Bale after Wales won his first game in charge this week

 

PS... There are two more aspiring managers too

NICKY BUTT

Has been back at United in a coaching capacity since 2012, managing the Under 19 and reserve teams and progressing to become the head of their academy. 

Played a vital role in the heart of the midfield in Barcelona with Keane and Paul Scholes suspended. 

Nicky Butt watches Manchester United Under 19s in the UEFA Youth League in February

PAUL SCHOLES

Assisted Ryan Giggs during his spell as United caretaker in 2014. Scholes has done his coaching badges and says he wants to manage but recently missed out on the job at boyhood club Oldham.

A United legend, he was key to the 1999 Champions League win despite missing the final.

Paul Scholes has worked mainly as a pundit since retiring from football in 2013

 

PPS... And what have the rest of them done?

PETER SCHMEICHEL

Goalkeeping legend has spent his retirement doing sporadic TV work in Denmark and the UK.

RAIMOND VAN DER GOUW

Now 54, Van der Gouw has been Vitesse goalkeeping coach since 2009. 

RONNY JOHNSEN

Started alongside Stam in the final and for most of the Treble-winning season. An official Manchester United ambassador based back in his native Norway. 

WES BROWN

Still playing at 38, having joined Indian Super League side Kerala Blasters last year. 

Wes Brown was still playing in the Premier League as recently as 2016 with Sunderland

DENIS IRWIN

Starting left back in '99 has worked as pundit in his native Ireland and on MUTV since retiring in 2004. 

DAVID MAY

Famous for doing a John Terry before John Terry did it as he celebrated the 1999 victory having not played. Now a presenter for MUTV. 

JOHN CURTIS

The man in the far right of the photo, in case you were wondering. United youth product last played for Gold Coast United in Australia in 2011. 

DAVID BECKHAM

Multi-millionaire former England captain is in the process of setting up an MLS franchise in Miami after a stellar career ended in 2013. 

David Beckham at the unveiling of his new MLS franchise in Miami in January

JESPER BLOMQVIST

Winger who started in Barcelona has recently opened a pizza restaurant in Stockholm. Has worked as a pundit in Sweden. 

JONATHAN GREENING

An unused sub in the final. 39-year-old was playing for non-league Tadcaster Albion last season. 

DWIGHT YORKE

Had a brief stint as Trinidad and Tobago assistant manager in 2009-10. Another regular on TV. 

ANDY COLE

Suffered a kidney failure in 2014 but underwent a successful transplant last year.

item.title: Chelsea target Andrea Belotti not interested in bench role at a 'big club' as Italy striker says he'll only leave Torino if first-team football is on offer
item.description: Chelsea were keen on Belotti during both transfer windows in 2017, while he was also linked with Arsenal and Manchester City last summer. But the 24-year-old Italy frontman is in no rush to move on.
item.content:encoded:
Italy and Torino forward Andrea Belotti will only move to a bigger club if he can be sure he plays regularly.

Chelsea were keen on Belotti during both transfer windows in 2017, while he was also linked with Arsenal and Manchester City last summer.

But Belotti is in no rush to move on.

Italy striker Andrea Belotti will only consider leaving Torino  for a 'big club' if he is going to play

'They tell me I should go and play in a big club which plays in the big cup competitions, but I will decide what is best for me,' Belotti told state broadcaster Rai.

'I'm not interested in moving to a big club if I don't play or get stuck on the bench. If I move, it's to be a regular in the first team.'

The 24-year-old attracted attention from around Europe after he scored 26 goals for Torino in Serie A last season and also became a regular for Italy.

However, Torino president Urbano Cairo insisted he did not want to sell the player and inserted a €100million (£87.35m) buyout clause into Belotti's contract, which runs until 2021.

This season has been less successful for Belotti, who has suffered two injuries, scored a modest six league goals and was part of an Italy team which failed to qualify for the World Cup.

'I don't want to see pictures of the game at San Siro again,' he said, referring to the 0-0 playoff draw against Sweden in November which cost Italy a place in Russia.

'Personally, after the two injuries, I'm well, both physically and mentally. Fortunately, there are lots of games coming up so I can bounce back.'

Italy play England in a friendly at Wembley on Tuesday.

Belotti, seen in Italy training on Sunday, was a target for Chelsea in both 2017 transfer windows

item.title: Brazil train at the Olympic Stadium in Berlin ahead grudge match with World Cup tormentors Germany
item.description: Brazil are a day away from one of the most hotly anticipated international friendlies of recent times, and are putting the final touches on their preparations to face the world champions.
item.content:encoded:
Brazil are a day away from one of the most hotly anticipated international friendlies of recent times, and are putting the final touches on their preparations.

They face Germany in Berlin at the Olympiastadion, the first time the two countries have met since the 2014 World Cup semi-final. 

That game has gone down in infamy for Brazil, as they were dumped out of their home World Cup, suffering a 7-1 annihilation.

Brazil are a day away from one of the most anticipated international friendlies of recent times

They face Germany in Berlin, the first time the countries have met since the 2014 World Cup

That game has gone down in infamy for Brazil, as they beaten 7-1 at their home World Cup

While this friendly is hardly on the same level of importance, Brazil will still be desperate to win, and that was reflected as they trained hard on Monday. 

It also represents a chance for those on the fringes of manager Tite's squad to make a name for themselves, with the 2018 World Cup a couple of months away.

The squad which trained on Monday contained several Premier League faces, including Manchester City pair Ederson and Gabriel Jesus.

While this friendly is hardly on the same level of importance, Brazil will still be desperate to win

The squad contains several Premier League faces, including Manchester City keeper Ederson

A planned display of cards to be held by the crowd, reading 'United' can already be seen

Even without the injured Neymar, this Brazil squad has plenty of household names, including full backs Marcelo and Dani Alves.

Brazil will look to build on their victory against upcoming World Cup hosts Russia on Friday, a 3-0 win in Moscow.

The South Americans are one of the form sides in international football, with no defeats in their last 13 fixtures. 

It also represents a chance for those on the fringes of the squad to impress manager Tite

Manchester City midfielder Fernandinho heads the ball during a training drill

Tote is looking to guide his Brazil side to a 14th straight game without defeat on Tuesday

item.title: 'We cheat at cricket': Australians take aim at their ball-tampering Test team with hilarious rendition of 10cc's 'Dreadlock Holiday'
item.description: Much controversy has swirled around the ball-tampering scandal which has seen Australia captain Steve Smith, vice-captain David Warner and Cameron Bancroft come under huge scrutiny.
item.content:encoded:
If you don't laugh, you'll cry, so the old saying goes. Well this is the Australians' attempt to make us laugh – and they've not done a bad job.

Much controversy has swirled around the ball-tampering scandal which has seen Australia captain Steve Smith, vice-captain David Warner and Cameron Bancroft come under huge scrutiny.

Smith has been handed a one-Test ban by the ICC for his part while Bancroft, who was seen using the foreign object in an attempt to alter the ball's condition at Newlands, was slapped with three demerit points. Both were also heavily fined by the governing body.

Scroll down for video 

Australian radio station Triple J have taken aim at their Test team amid the ball-tampering saga

The video reenacts the sequence of events which emerged from South Africa on Sunday

They changed the lyrics of the famous song, synonymous with cricket, 'Dreadlock Holiday'

They altered 'We don't like cricket, we love it' lyric to 'We cheat at cricket, we've been caught'

They harked back to the infamous Trevor Chappell ball against New Zealand in 1981

Further sanctions from Cricket Australia are imminent, but in the meantime, Triple J, an Australian radio station, have conjured up their own version of 10cc's 'Dreadlock Holiday', altering the lyrics to take aim at the team's attempts to cheat.

The song's famous 'We don't like cricket, we love it' line is swapped out for 'We cheat at cricket, we've been caught'.

During one section of the song, two women, who are playing commentators, rib the Australian team for cheating and still losing convincingly in Cape Town. 

Full credit to Australians back in Australia. pic.twitter.com/DIhUXxuQrs

— Ben Karpinski (@followthebounce) March 26, 2018

In one rapping section they rib the Australians for cheating and still losing heavily

Other sections of the video concoct other unsportsmanlike scenarios, like bribing umpires

And another shows a fielder pushing over a batsman who is attempting to make a run

Cameron Bancroft and Steve Smith pictured as the ball-tampering scandal came to light

The hilarious video also makes a dig at another controversial moment in the team's history, the 1981 incident whereby Trevor Chappell bowled underarm to New Zealand batsman Brian McKechnie to stop him scoring the winning runs in a one-day international.

Other unsportsmanlike scenarios are also concocted, such as bribing the umpire and pushing the batsman over as he tries to scamper through for a run.

At the very least, it's a break from all the troubling news and implications which have rightly emerged from this incident.

LYRICS – 'WE CHEAT AT CRICKET'

We were walking down the street,

Wearing these Baggy Greens,

But then a dark voice in the corner of the locker room,

Said 'make sure this ball reverse swings',

Do it quickly, no dilly-dallying, if we lose it won't be nice, Garry,

Scuff it small, won't do no harm,

Just like that time we bowled underarm

 

Headed down to Bunnings, Cape Town,

Ask them for the aisle where the tape's found,

Bit of Test cricket, got 'em thinking 'let's spin it',

item.title: Daniel Sturridge back training with West Brom physios as he nears return after month out with hamstring injury
item.description: The 28-year-old England international has played just 78 minutes since joining on loan from Liverpool and limped out of action just three minutes into West Brom's 3-0 defeat to Chelsea.
item.content:encoded:
Daniel Sturridge has returned to training with West Bromwich Albion physios following his month out with a hamstring injury.

The 28-year-old England international has played just 78 minutes since joining on loan from Liverpool and limped out of action just three minutes into West Brom's 3-0 defeat to Chelsea on February 12.

He is considered doubtful to face Burnley this weekend as he steps up his recovery.

Daniel Sturridge is nearing a return to action after missing a month with a hamstring injury

However, he will have a more realistic chance of being fit to play against Swansea City on April 7. 

The 28-year-old will be desperate for no setbacks in his recovery as he looks to earn a surprise inclusion in the England squad for the World Cup this summer.

The Baggies have desperately missed the services of Sturridge in the Premier League recently, with the club seemingly destined for relegation to the Championship. 

The Hawthorns outfit are currently rooted to the bottom of the table, seven points behind 19th-placed Stoke and 10 adrift of West Ham in 17th.

Sturridge will have a realistic chance of being fit to play against Swansea on April 7

item.title: Samuel Umtiti could embarrass Manchester United like Sergio Ramos did in transfer chase... but if Barcelona do not hand 'Big Sam' a big pay rise he WILL head to Old Trafford for £53m
item.description: PETE JENSON: The news that Samuel Umtiti is stalling on a new contract and is available at £53m will have had some Manchester United supporters dreaming of an Umtiti-Bailly partnership.
item.content:encoded:
The news that Samuel Umtiti is stalling on a new contract and available at €60million (£53m) will have had some Manchester United supporters dreaming of an Umtiti-Eric Bailly partnership.

Others will have just been thinking – it's Sergio Ramos all over again.

It's certainly true that Umtiti, much like Ramos in 2015 when he looked on the verge of moving to Old Trafford, holds most of the cards.

Samuel Umtiti is demanding a new contract at Barcelona worth £8m per season

Manchester United are ready to pounce if the France defender does not agree a new deal

Barcelona players and supporters will be up in arms if he leaves this summer, and the player knows it.

That's why he is playing a patient waiting game to get the best new deal possible before next season begins.

Few signings have worked out as well for Barcelona over the last five years than their acquisition of Umtiti for just £22m from Lyon in 2016.

In the first three months of last season he looked as good as any central defender in Europe, and at a third of the price of the 'going rate' for a good centre back it was the best money Barcelona had spent in a long time.

He's loved by a dressing room that has dubbed him 'Big Sam' and hailed by supporters who waited a long time for the club to replace Javier Mascherano. Gerard Pique has not been this comfortable alongside a central defensive partner since the days of Carles Puyol. Left-footed, quick and powerful, Umititi can play to Pique's left in the middle and cover the forward runs of Jordi Alba.

His form has dipped ever so slightly since coming back from a torn thigh muscle in December but he would still be in the running if there were such a thing at the Nou Camp as fans' player of the year.

In short, the board needs to renew his deal so that his buy-out clause can be bumped up to something that will keep the likes of Jose Mourinho away. Umtiti has a deal until 2021 and he also wants a new contract that will put him on around £8m net per season. Barcelona's wage bill is constantly at bursting point and they have so far balked at those demands.

For now, Barca's general manager, Pep Segura, is not expecting the worst. The player is managed by his brother, Yannick, and there is no indication that he wants to move Samuel out at any cost. The player is happy at Barcelona and looking forward to sharing a dressing room with close pal and France team-mate Antoine Griezmann next season.

But he wants to be respected in the club's salary scale and he has sufficient confidence in his own ability to have an impressive World Cup, boosting his market value even higher, and so even further beyond that low buy-out clause.

So is this Ramos mark II for United? Ramos would have gone to United three years ago had Real Madrid not caved in to his demands. Likewise Umtiti will be wearing red next season if Barcelona don't give him the pay rise he wants.

United were embarrassed before when Sergio Ramos used them to get a big new deal at Real Madrid in 2015 - here he is sat with his family at the press conference announcing his contract

But United fans will point to a potential partnership between Umtiti and Eric Bailly at the back

They may not have to match what United could pay him but he does want a significant increase. If he is moved up to £8m then his salary will have more than doubled according to estimates of his current earnings.

The market for central defenders has changed drastically in the last two years and the price that Liverpool paid Southampton for Virgil van Dijk and Manchester City paid Athletic Bilbao for Aymeric Laporte mean various big clubs will not blink before laying down £53m for Umtiti.

Barcelona are confident that he will be going nowhere but options such as Sevilla's Clement Lenglet, who has a £26m buyout clause, have been mentioned just in case the seemingly inevitable renewal never comes to pass.

item.title: Liverpool can win Champions League under boss Jurgen Klopp, says former Germany captain Lothar Matthaus
item.description: Jurgen Klopp has stayed true to the attacking philosophy that won him admirers in Germany and has assembled a squad capable of winning the Champions League, said Lothar Matthaus.
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has stayed true to the attacking philosophy that won him admirers in Germany and has assembled a squad capable of winning the Champions League, said Lothar Matthaus.

Five-times European champions Liverpool are in the quarter-finals of this year's competition and face fellow Premier League side Manchester City in the first leg at Anfield on April 4.

Klopp led his former club Borussia Dortmund to Bundesliga titles in 2011 and in 2012, when they also won the German Cup for a domestic double, and he steered them to the 2013 Champions League final where they lost to arch-rivals Bayern Munich.

Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp is looking to win the Champions League this season 

Lothar Matthaus (R) believes Klopp has stayed true to his attacking philosophy in England 

The 50-year-old took charge of Liverpool in 2015, where he has bolstered his adventurous brand of football with a number of key signings including Premier League top-scorer Mohamed Salah and fellow forward Sadio Mane.

'He (Klopp) didn't change his style too much (from Dortmund)... he has done a very good job. I believed from the beginning that he and Liverpool have a very good relationship,' Matthaus told the club's website.

'You can see that in the good results, the good games and he has bought the right players. For me, it is a team that can win the Champions League in two months (time) in Kiev.'

Liverpool are also chasing second spot in the Premier League behind champions-elect Manchester City. The Merseysiders are in third place with 63 points from 31 games, two behind Manchester United who have a game in hand.

'He is working very hard, his team is always ready to fight for 90 minutes and they are in good condition,' Matthaus, who played in the 5-5 draw between Bayern Munich and Liverpool Legends teams at Anfield at the weekend, added.

'He finds the right players, especially in the offence, who can make the difference on the highest level.'

item.title: Anthony Joshua drowns out the negativity in new Beats By Dre advert ahead of Joseph Parker showdown
item.description: Joshua, who teamed up with Beats Electronics last April ahead of his showdown against Klitschko, starred in their latest advert and shared it on his Instagram on Monday.
item.content:encoded:
Anthony Joshua batted away all the negativity and pressures he is currently facing in the new Beats By Dr Dre advert ahead of his heavyweight unification fight with Joseph Parker.

The WBA and IBF world champion, who teamed up with Beats Electronics last April ahead of his showdown against Wladimir Klitschko, starred in their latest advert and shared it on his Instagram on Monday.

In the video Joshua is stood on a platform with the Beats headphones around his neck while a voice is repeatedly telling him 'you can't win' before he roars and begins shadow boxing.

Anthony Joshua starred in the latest Beats By Dr Dre advert and shared it on his Instagram

Joshua is stood on a platform with the headphones around his neck in the video

A voice repeatedly reminds him the pressures he is facing ahead of the Joseph Parker fight

The 28-year-old has been warned about the importance of his fight with Parker at Cardiff's Principality Stadium with a massive clash against WBC king Deontay Wilder on the cards if he wins this Saturday.

The voice continues: 'The pressures on I'm not going to lie. You better beat this guy. You can't win. To a fan you're the man until the belt drops and another man becomes the man on top.

'What then? Back to dirt bikes and being 'Fem' from the ends, you can't win and if you do it will be no surprise because the world beats you up everyday.'

Say it with your chest. #AboveTheNoise @beatsbydre

A post shared by Anthony Joshua (@anthony_joshua) on Mar 26, 2018 at 4:06am PDT

The world champions starts limbering up before shadow boxing as the voice continues

It tells him ' you can't win. The pressures on I'm not going to lie. You better beat this guy.'

At the end Joshua puts on the headphones to block out the negativity and looks focused

At this point Joshua puts the headphones on and looks focused before the voice concludes 'And every day you rise.'

Despite his New Zealand opponent already being written out of the equation before the fight has happened, Joshua is wise enough to respect Parker but remains supremely confident of victory. 

'He's talented,' said Joshua last week, 'very talented. He has his amateur pedigree and his trainer, Kevin Barry, is experienced and he was a fighter himself with two championship fights. I'm dealing with a guy who has his country on his back and that obviously gives him a little bit of fuel as well. He's a man of pride.

'They will tell him stuff. You know when they tell him, "You can hit him with a left hook" and it isn't happening. Or: "You can hit him with a right hand" and it isn't happening. Or: "He's going to gas in round six or round seven, he has stamina problems" and I'm still there. Or: "He can't take a punch" and I'm still there in round whatever. He'll soon realise he's in with a real one.'

item.title: Anthony Joshua admits he is open to UFC switch - but only after he has 'dominated his own sport': 'I have to complete the goals I have in boxing otherwise it's like a pantomime'
item.description: UFC president Dana White, who has recently expressed a desire to offer the heavyweight champion a huge promotional deal, will be ringside for the fight at the Principality Stadium in Cardiff.
item.content:encoded:
Anthony Joshua has admitted switching boxing for UFC is an option - but not until the end of his career.

The 28-year-old wants to fulfill his goals in the ring first before he moves to the octagon, starting with victory against Joseph Parker in their unification fight this Saturday.

UFC president Dana White, who has recently expressed a desire to offer the heavyweight champion a huge promotional deal, will be ringside for the fight at the Principality Stadium in Cardiff.

Anthony Joshua has admitted he would be interested in switching from boxing to the UFC

However, Joshua said he would only consider the move after accomplishing his goals in boxing

Joshua admitted he would be interested in following in Floyd Mayweather's footsteps - with the American starting MMA training amid speculation of a rematch with Conor McGregor in the octagon - but not until he has achieved everything he wants to in boxing.

'Providing I've got to the end of my career and achieved what I wanted to then yes,' Joshua said when asked about making the switch to UFC.

'Remember Mayweather did it at the end of his career, [but] he dominated the sport he loved first. 

UFC president Dana White recently expressed a desire to offer Joshua a huge promotional deal

'It would be an option because it's been done before and it's successful, so it can be done again. 

'I have to complete the goals and achievements I have in boxing otherwise it's like a pantomime. You have to dominate your own sport, and then you can look at other avenues.'

Victory against Parker this weekend could set Joshua up for a massive clash against Deontay Wilder for all the world titles in the heavyweight division.

He would like to emulate Floyd Mayweather, who's begun MMA training after his boxing career

item.title: Aviva Premiership see four injuries recorded per game… and number of concussion cases requiring three-month lay-offs increases, figures show
item.description: Aviva Premiership matches saw four injuries recorded per game on average last season as concussion and hamstring issues increase, new figures revealed.
item.content:encoded:
Aviva Premiership matches saw four injuries recorded per game on average last season as concussion and hamstring issues increase, new figures revealed. 

For the 2016-17 Premiership campaign, there were 3.8 injuries per match and 1.9 injuries per team, on average.

The average severity of match injuries (measured by the time taken to return to play) for the same season was 32 days. 

Aviva Premiership matches saw an average of four recorded injuries across last season

Elliot Daly requires an oxygen mask after dislocating his finger for Wasps in a recent match

Leicester Tigers' Jonny May was escorted off after he was knocked out on the field of play

Concussion cases requiring more than a three-month absence have increased in number and for the first time, hamstring injuries and concussion appear alongside anterior cruciate ligament knee injuries in the top three match injuries resulting in an absence of 84 days or more.

The Professional Rugby Injury Surveillance Project, jointly commissioned by the Rugby Football Union, Premiership Rugby and the Rugby Players' Association, reported injury data for the 2016-17 season on Monday.

It showed concussion was the most commonly reported match injury for a sixth successive year, contributing 22 per cent to the total.

The report attributed the increase of concussions requiring more than three months of absence to 'a trend to more conservative management of players who have sustained two or more concussions in a 12-month period'.

item.title: Liverpool defender Joe Gomez reveals he is benefiting hugely from working with January signing Virgil Van Dijk: 'It's a great opportunity to learn'
item.description: England defender Joe Gomez is delighted to have the opportunity to learn from Liverpool team mate Virgil van Dijk and sees himself as a 'sponge' soaking up lessons
item.content:encoded:
England defender Joe Gomez is delighted to have the opportunity to learn from Liverpool team mate Virgil van Dijk and sees himself as a 'sponge' soaking up lessons from the world's most expensive defender.

Van Dijk's January move for a reported £75 million from Southampton to Anfield may have hampered Gomez's long-term ambition of moving from right back to centre half.

However, the youngster insisted that he does not see the Dutch international as an obstacle.

'I didn't see it as blocking my path or anything like that. It's a great opportunity to learn from him,' the 20-year-old Gomez told British media.

Joe Gomez is benefiting hugely from working with fellow defender Virgil Van Dijk at Liverpool

'I am not overly stressing about it or paranoid about other people coming in. It's great to be in environments where I can learn from players like that. I am just trying to soak it all up and be the best sponge I can be.

'I think he has a great presence, everyone sees that. He is very dominant in the way he plays and his body language shows that he has quality on the ball.'

Van Djik has made ten appearances for Liverpool since signing from Southampton in January

LIVERPOOL'S NEXT FIVE FIXTURES 

Saturday: Crystal Palace (away) - Premier League

April 4: Manchester City (home) - Champions League

April 7: Everton (away) - Premier League

April 10: Manchester City (away) - Champions League

April 14: Bournemouth (home) - Premier League 

Gomez received his first England call-up in November and earned praise for putting a commanding display to nullify the threat of Brazil's Neymar in a 0-0 draw.

He freely admits he is still getting used to taking on the world's best forwards and is also learning from Liverpool's Mohamed Salah, who has scored 36 goals in all competitions since arriving at Anfield at the start of the campaign.

'I'm not sure (who is better), they're both world class,' Gomez added. 'They're both incredible players and it's a pleasure for me to come up against such talent.

'It has to be a balance of respecting the ability but also understanding that he's your opponent and you can't be in awe of him, otherwise that might not do you any good. I try to learn as much as I can about each opponent and study their threats.'

Gomez pulled out of the England squad for Tuesday's friendly against Italy at Wembley after suffering an ankle injury in the 1-0 win over Netherlands on Friday.

item.title: Venus Williams fights back to eliminate defending champion Jo Konta from Miami Open
item.description: MIKE DICKSON IN MIAMI: Jo Konta surrendered her biggest piece of silverware and with it a place in the world’s top twenty when she fell to Venus Williams at the Miami Open.
item.content:encoded:
Jo Konta surrendered her biggest piece of silverware and with it a place in the world’s top twenty when she fell to Venus Williams at the Miami Open fourth round on Monday night.

It was not immediately apparent how much she may have been hampered by a lower back problem which required several bouts of on court treatment, but she went down 5-7 6-1 6-2 in two hours and 19 minutes to the American veteran ranked number eight.

After this Konta will slip to around 22 thanks to an erratic display during which there were spells that she completely lost her timing, making 47 unforced errors, and wore that panicked look which she had managed to banish in the previous two rounds. She will be out of the top 20 for the first time since June 2016.

Jo Konta was defeated in her last 16 clash at the Miami Open against Venus Williams

Williams showed champion quality to find a way back into the match before dominating

The scoreline was more competitive than their Wimbledon semi-final but the lack of a Plan B was telling, and she was arguably fortunate to have won the first set.

A sultry late afternoon on Key Biscayne was a different environment to their meeting at SW19, which saw Williams emerge an eventually comfortable victor for the loss of six games after Konta had spurned a few opportunities in the first set.

The American will have remembered in that match the errors that Konta made at big moments on her forehand. It had been a different story, however, when they met in the last four on this very same stadium court a year ago when the British No 1 won 6-4 7-5 en route to the title.

Konta started well, picking up the first set but the American fought back impressiveyly

There was no sign of any forehand weakness early on as Konta broke immediately by driving the ball flat into the corners. She had four break points to take a 3-0 lead two games later, only for Williams to power down first serves approaching 120 mph to save herself.

Konta held for 3-1 despite barely landing a first serve in the court, but was then broken back and slipped to 3-4, when she summoned on her coach, Michael Joyce, from the stands.

A strong wind running down the court made control difficult at times and the British number one was hampered by a woeful service percentage.

Cheered on by her home crowd, Williams rolled back the years to advance to the next round

The British No 1 had showed improved form in the tournament before meeting Williams

She saved a set point at 4-5 and then, against the run of the match, broke for 6-5 and took the set as her backhand suddenly rediscovered a lethal range.

Williams opted to play more conservatively in the second set and it paid dividends as her opponent contributed copious errors, especially after she missed a break back point at 1-3.

At the end of the set the fading British number one called for the physio and took a medical timeout in order to have treatment on her lower back. Williams, not far off 38, had looked the more sprightly.

Konta continued to spray it everywhere as she was broken at the start of the decider although, undergoing more running repairs on her back, she managed to break for 2-2.

Williams looked weary at that point but broke to re-establish a 3-2 lead and was never seriously challenged after that. 

Williams advances and it will take a strong performance to prevent her winning

item.title: Hummel produce special edition patchwork kit made from old Denmark shirts for Christian Eriksen and co to wear against Chile
item.description: Denmark will take on Chile on Tuesday evening in a one-off patchwork kit that pays homage to the national team strips through the years.
item.content:encoded:
Denmark will take on Chile on Tuesday evening in a one-off patchwork kit that pays homage to the national team strips through the years.

Kit manufacturer Hummel released pictures of the stunning design with Danish fans hailing the memories evoked from the shirt. 

The various shirts that feature in the intricate design were donated by supporters to help take the shirt from an idea through to production.  

Denmark will wear a special patchwork kit produced by Hummel to play Chile on Tuesday

The design features shirts donated by supporters - including the Mexico 1986 World Cup shirt

As some fans called for the shirt to be worn at the World Cup in Russia this summer, hopes were quickly dashed with news the patchwork jersey was only released to be worn for the Chile match on Tuesday.

The thin red and white stripe section of the shirt harks back to the national team strip used at the 1986 Mexico World Cup.

Three group stage wins saw them top their group before a crushing 5-1 knockout defeat to Spain ended any hopes of lifting the biggest prize in international football. 

Denmark are preparing for the World Cup and will want to beat Chile to add to Panama win

Age Hareide's Danes are continuing their build up to the World Cup and will be looking to build on Friday's narrow 1-0 win over Panama.

Pione Sisto scored the only goal at the Brondby stadium as England's group opponents this summer, Panama, produced a valiant away performance before a red card handed Denmark a sizeable advantage. 

Chile will pose a far sterner test with Manchester United's Alexis Sanchez the star attraction alongside Danish talisman Christian Eriksen.

Kit manufacturer Hummel released pictures of the stunning design with Danish fans hailing the memories evoked from the shirt. The various shirts that feature in the intricate design were donated by supporters to help take the shirt from an idea through to production.

item.title: Premiership desperate to deal with injury crisis and poised to adopt 'zero tolerance' approach to high tackles
item.description: The shocking toll of the English domestic rugby season was revealed on Monday with the Aviva Premiership poised to adopt a 'zero tolerance' approach to high tackles.
item.content:encoded:
The shocking toll of the English domestic rugby season was revealed on Monday with the Aviva Premiership poised to adopt a 'zero tolerance' approach to high tackles to stem an alarming rise in concussions.

Figures released on Monday showed that concussion was the most commonly reported match injury for the sixth season in succession, making up 22 per cent of all injuries.

Injuries requiring more than a three-months' recovery time were also at an all-time high.

Manu Tuilagi was among the numerous players in the Premiership injured at the weekend

There were an average of four injuries per match last season with an average recovery time of 32 days. For the first time, hamstring injuries and concussion feature in the top three injuries reported in the league.

In January of last year, World Rugby issued new directives for punishing high tackles in a bid to combat the worrying increase in concussions.

The most high-profile recent case was Sonny Bill Williams's red card for a shoulder charge into Anthony Watson's head during the second Test of last summer's British and Irish Lions tour of New Zealand.

But that directive have not had the desired effect in the Premiership, and the rugby chiefs now want even tougher sanctions on high tackles.

The directives put in place have not had the desired effect on reducing head injuries

'From the data we've got (last season), that sanction hasn't resulted in our game in a reduction in concussion risk,' said Dr Simon Kemp, the RFU's Medical Services Director, on Monday..

'It might have been different in other unions, but in our game is hasn't yet changed anything, and that's something that we highlight in the action plan because if we are serious about zero tolerance for head injuries, we need to be confident that we can show that that is actually happening.

'And that is the aim: zero tolerance.' Monday's findings were published in the Professional Rugby Injury Surveillance Project (PRISP), jointly commissioned by the Rugby Football Union, Premiership Rugby and the Rugby Players' Association, which reported injury data for the 2016-17 season.

The Premiership is regarded as one of the most gruelling and physical leagues in the global game but the report's findings will prove a sobering read.

Billy Vunipola has suffered three serious injuries and has been one of the most affected

England and Saracens star Billy Vunipola, who has suffered three serious injuries in the past 18 months, has warned of the issue of player burnout this season.

'I didn't enjoy being on the surgery table twice in one year and that's supposed to be deemed as normal,' Vunipola told the BBC last September.

'So something probably needs to change, or the players will just burn out.' Reading Monday's findings, Vunipola's fears are well-founded.

item.title: Diego Costa and his Spain team-mates gear up for tough Argentina friendly as David de Gea admits he wants to come up against Lionel Messi in Madrid
item.description: Diego Costa, Isco and Sergio Ramos, who returned to the squad following the birth of his third child, were among the Spain stars pictured being put through their paces on Monday.
item.content:encoded:
Julen Lopetegui's Spain side have ramped up their preparations for their tough friendly against Argentina on Tuesday night in Madrid.

Diego Costa, Isco and Sergio Ramos, who returned to the squad following the birth of his third child, were among the Spain stars pictured being put through their paces on the eve of their clash with Argentina.

The Spanish camp appeared in high spirits as they got a feel for the surroundings at the Wanda Metropolitano on Monday.

Diego Costa and his Spain team-mates trained ahead of Tuesday's friendly with Argentina

Isco dribbles with the ball during training at the Wanda Metropolitano on Monday

Sergio Ramos and Gerard Pique put their rivalries aside during the session in Madrid

Real Madrid captain Ramos returned to the Spain camp after being at the birth of his third child

Spain go into the game on the back of their 1-1 draw with Germany in Dusseldorf, where Rodrigo's early goal was cancelled out by Thomas Muller in the first half.

Meanwhile, Argentina overcame Italy 2-0 last time out in Manchester thanks to goals from Ever Banega and Manuel Lanzini.

Lionel Messi sat out for Argentina at the Etihad last Friday with a hamstring injury but is expected to recover in time for the clash in Madrid.

Barcelona centre back Pique covers his mouth as he speaks to a Spanish team-mate

Bayern Munich midfielder Thiago Alcantara heads a ball at goal during a training drill 

Julen Lopetegui speaks to his Spain players in a huddle on the eve of the Argentina friendly

And speaking ahead of the friendly, Manchester United goalkeeper David de Gea has admitted he wants to come up against the five-time Ballon d'Or winner even if it means he will be kept busy.

'As a goalkeeper it is a challenge to face Messi,' De Gea said.

'But we want the best players to be on the pitch and Messi is one of them. It's always special to play against him.'

item.title: Liverpool goalkeeper Simon Mignolet vows to stay and fight for place despite losing No 1 spot to Loris Karius: 'It's never easy but all I can do is try change that and prove I'm ready'
item.description: The Belgium international has not played for Liverpool since their 3-2 defeat against West Brom in the FA Cup on January 27 and has fallen out of favour with Klopp preferring Karius.
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool goalkeeper Simon Mignolet has vowed to stay and fight for the No 1 jersey despite Jurgen Klopp preferring the option of Loris Karius.

The Belgium international has not played for Liverpool since their 3-2 defeat against West Brom in the FA Cup on January 27.

Klopp has stuck with Karius for the majority of this season but Mignolet says it has not made him feel the need to move away from Anfield and that he is committed to proving himself to the Liverpool boss.

Liverpool goalkeeper Simon Mignolet has vowed to stay and fight for the No 1 jersey

'No, always the only thing you try to do is prove every time in training you are ready for when the chance comes along,' he told Sky Sports.

'It is never easy of course because I have never in my career spent time on the bench, but it is how it is and the only thing you can do is try to change it but it is never easy.'

Mignolet, who turns 30 this month, admits he has addressed the situation with Klopp but is not considering submitting a transfer request despite speculation Liverpool are also closing in on signing Stoke shotstopper Jack Butland.

Loris Karius has been the preferred option this season with Mignolet not playing since January

He added: 'I've had a few conversations with the manager already and we have spoken about numerous things.

'I'm always open and he's always open, you know how he is, but at this time it is not the time and place to do that'.

While Mignolet has been forced to watch Karius from the bench at Liverpool, he has also had to play second fiddle to Thibaut Courtois in the Belgium national side.

Mignolet admitted he spoke with Jurgen Klopp about his situation but does not want to leave

He will however start for his country in Tuesday's international friendly against Saudi Arabia after Courtois returned to Chelsea on the weekend for treatment on a persistent muscular problem.

'You always have to be ready for when the chance comes along,' Mignolet said.

'That's the only thing I can do so I try to stay professional in training, try to work as hard as I can, show that I'm ready for whenever the chance happens.

'That's the only thing you do really, then it is up to the manager or the coach to give you the nod.'

Klopp is still keen to sign a keeper with rumours Liverpool are close to signing Jack Butland

item.title: MCC praise 'swift action' taken by ICC and Cricket Australia in ball-tampering scandal but criticise player conduct in South Africa series: 'Their behaviour has fallen well below the standard required'
item.description: South Africa took a 2-1 lead in the four-Test series in Cape Town on Sunday, thrashing the Aussies by 322 runs in a match that was overshadowed by events on the third day.
item.content:encoded:
The response to the Australian ball-tampering scandal in South Africa has been praised by the MCC, but the organisation have strongly condemned the behaviour of players during the tempestuous series.

South Africa took a 2-1 lead in the four-Test series in Cape Town on Sunday, thrashing the Aussies by 322 runs in a match that was overshadowed by events on the third day.

Steve Smith was given a one-match ban and stood down from the Australian captaincy after admitting to deliberately trying to alter the condition of the ball.

MCC have praised the 'swift action' of authorities in the wake of the ball-tampering scandal

Steve Smith (right) was handed a one-match ban after admitting to tampering with the ball 

Cameron Bancroft was caught rubbing sticky yellow tape on the ball in the latest incident of an action-packed series that has often strayed the wrong side of the line.

David Warner and Quinton De Kock had to be restrained in the players' tunnel in the first Test in Durban, while Kagiso Rabada was banned for the rest of the series for a shoulder clash with Smith in the second Test, which was then overturned on appeal.

John Stephenson, MCC assistant secretary, said: 'We welcome the swift action by the match officials, ICC and Cricket Australia in response to the admission of ball-tampering by senior Australia players.

'Changing the condition of the ball is prohibited under Law 41 concerning unfair play. Law 41 also places upon the captains of both sides the responsibility for ensuring that play is carried out in accordance with the spirit of the game as well as within the laws.'

But the MCC have heavily condemned the conduct of players during the South Africa series 

Smith was involved in an altercation with Kagiso Rabada during the second Test 

But he then criticised the conduct of both sets of players in South Africa, claiming they fell 'well below the standard required' and calling for 'a major shift in attitude and culture'. 

'The behaviour of some of the players in the current South Africa/Australia series, and other incidents in recent times in the game we all cherish, has fallen well below the standard required to inspire future generations of cricket-loving families.

'The time has come for a major shift in attitude and culture of all those with responsibility for leadership within the game, to give young players the kind of role models who will uphold standards, preserve cricket and, vitally, the spirit of cricket for future generations.' 

The MCC have called for a 'major shift in attitude and culture' across the game
