item.title: Joe Root admits England will undergo 'soul searching' after crushing defeat by New Zealand extends winless away run to 12 Tests... the worst in 80 years
item.description: PAUL NEWMAN IN AUCKLAND: Joe Root admitted England would undergo some 'soul searching' after another crushing defeat in the first Test to New Zealand.
item.content:encoded:
Joe Root admitted England would undergo some 'soul searching' after another crushing defeat in the first Test to New Zealand extended their worst run away from home in 80 years.

England are now without victory in 12 away Tests against Bangladesh, India, Australia and New Zealand in a variety of conditions after Kane Williamson's side completed an innings and 49 run victory at Eden Park.

Now England simply have to win the second and final Test at Christchurch, starting on Friday, if they are to prove they are not going backwards in the longer form of the game under captain Root and coach Trevor Bayliss.

England captain Joe Root answers questions at a press conference following an emphatic loss

Root shakes hands with Kane Williamson after losing the first Test by an innings and 49 runs

England were always up against it after their shocking collapse to 58 all out on the first day but two days of rain gave them a glimmer of hope and they took their attempt at survival into the last session before they were bowled out by New Zealand for 320.

'It was a massive task coming back from a first innings that was bitterly disappointing but the character the guys showed today was a step forward and we need to simply be better in Christchurch,' said Root. 

'It's very important we do some soul-searching and get things right.' 

Root told his players to display some pride ahead of the last day, which should be the absolute minimum required of an international player, but was satisfied with their commitment on a much better final day.

'I asked the guys at the start when we were warming up to show everyone how much it meant to them to play for England and represent your country and I thought we got that today from the guys,' said Root.

'It's not for lack of trying. We've got to continue with our work ethic and to look to improve and the first opportunity to do that is in the second Test. It's something we will continue to work with and make sure when we get an opportunity that a couple of guys really stand up.' 

Ben Stokes was the top scorer for England in the second innings with a noble effort of 66 runs

Stokes was eventually caught out for a wild swing and was also suffering from a sore back

England have another fitness worry over Ben Stokes, who top scored with 66 before giving his wicket away on the stroke of the 'dinner' break when he was bounced out by the aggression of Neil Wagner.

Stokes again suffered soreness in his back and faces a fight to be fit to play an all-round role in time for Friday's second Test in his home city of Christchruch where a large number of his family including his parents are expected to watch.

'He had some treatment and I'm not sure the extent of how bad it is,' said Root. 'It's day to day with Ben's back and making sure he's fit to play. That assessment will continue this week and if he's not fit to play he won't.

'But he showed great control and at times restraint from his natural game and I think he's growing as a player all the time. He showed a lot of maturity in the way he went about things and he'll be very disappointed with his dismissal. 

Established stars like Moeen Ali are under pressure following a series of unconvincing displays

'But I thought he played exceptionally well and I don't think the way he got out was a fair reflection of the way he got stuck in today. He put a real good shift in.' 

England also face difficult decisions over their best team for the final match of their longest winter tour since they travelled overseas by boat in 1962, with question marks over several members of their side including established players like Moeen Ali and Chris Woakes.

'There's a lot of emotional knocking around now and it's still very raw so it's very important we have some rational thinking and we sit down and make sure we go into that Test with the 11 we think will win the game,' added Root.

item.title: Elliot Daly likely to recover from dislocated finger and return to Wasps action in six weeks
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Elliot Daly is likely to return for Wasps before the end of the season and be available for England's summer tour to South Africa despite dislocating his finger on Sunday.
item.content:encoded:
Elliot Daly is likely to return for Wasps before the end of the season and be available for England's summer tour to South Africa despite dislocating his finger on Sunday.

Sportsmail understands the utility back has not broken a finger on his right hand - a far more positive injury bulletin for national head coach Eddie Jones. England play the Springboks three times in June.

After suffering a compound dislocation against Leicester Tigers, which was so painful Daly required gas and air as he went off, it was feared that the 25-year-old would be out for the season. 

Elliot Daly suffered a painful injury to his finger in the Wasps defeat against Leicester

His director of rugby Dai Young hoped that he would be only injured for 'weeks not months'.

Those hopes seem to have been realised as it is understood there is no fracture to the bone. With no complications Daly should be back within six weeks.

The Wasp, who was pictured with his middle two fingers taped together and arm in a sling post-match, jetted off to Dubai on holiday on Monday so will begin his recovery there - his club do not play again until April 6, when the Premiership returns.

Meanwhile there are lingering concerns over Manu Tuilagi - the Leicester centre underwent a scan on a pectoral injury on Monday with club and country hoping he is not seriously damaged again. 

Daly will be back in action for Wasps in six weeks if his recovery goes smoothly

item.title: England stars facing World Cup heartache as they prepare for final squad audition versus Italy at Wembley with Adam Lallana and Danny Rose among those sweating on places in Gareth Southgate's plans
item.description: England stars are facing World Cup heartache as they prepare for their final squad audition on Tuesday night. Among the players sweating on their places in Gareth Southgate's party for Russia
item.content:encoded:
England stars are facing World Cup heartache as they prepare for their final squad audition on Tuesday night.

Among the players sweating on their places in Gareth Southgate's party for Russia are Adam Lallana and Danny Rose, while Jack Wilshere is also facing a desperate battle to prove he is worthy of a slot.

Likewise, it is understood Gary Cahill and Chris Smalling - who were omitted from the latest squad - are highly unlikely to win their places back before the World Cup.

Liverpool star Adam Lallana isn't guaranteed a place in England's World Cup squad

Tottenham defender Danny Rose is trying to convince Gareth Southgate to select him

England manager Southgate wants to name his 23-man squad for the World Cup before the clash against Nigeria, first of two pre-tournament friendlies, on June 2.

That means Tuesday's clash against Italy will be the final chance for many players to convince Southgate they are worthy of a place in his World Cup squad.

Lallana's season has been wrecked by a thigh injury sustained in pre-season meaning he has not played for England since June 2017.

The Liverpool star is fit again and back in Southgate's squad, however Lallana did not train properly for the entirety of last week meaning he wasn't considered for the win in Holland on Friday.

Gary Cahill is unlikely to make England's World Cup squad after being left out of this selection

Manchester United centre-back Chris Smalling also seems set to miss out on the tournament

In usual circumstances, Lallana would be a shoo-in for Southgate's squad but concerns over his fitness are proving a concern for the England boss.

Similarly, Rose is not playing regularly at Tottenham and still needs to convince Southgate he should go to Russia.

As it stands, Ashley Young - who is expected to play against Italy tomorrow - is the leading contender to be England's left-wing back in Russia.

That means Rose and Ryan Bertrand - who pulled out of the current squad with a back injury - are locked in a straight fight for a place in Southgate's party.

As Sportmail revealed on Friday, midfielder Wilshere will not be part of England's squad to face Italy tomorrow after sustaining a knee injury in training on Thursday.

Jack Wilshere's injury troubles could count against him in his bid to make the final squad

Wilshere as due to start in Amsterdam on Friday night, but pulling out of the squad means he won't have made a single appearance for Southgate before the manager names his squad.

There is a feeling Wilshere would benefit from a full summer off ahead of next season.

Given his history of injuries, Wilshere is handled in a certain way on a day-to-day basis and the intensity of tournament football could have a strain on his body.

Ruben Loftus-Cheek could be included in the squad if the Crystal Palace midfielder is fit

Elsewhere, Ruben Loftus-Cheek remains firmly on Southgate's radar after he impressed in during the previous international break.

But Southgate wants to be sure the Crystal Palace midfielder is completely over the ankle injury that kept him sidelined for three months.

ENGLAND'S REMAINING FRIENDLIES BEFORE THE WORLD CUP 

Tuesday: Italy (home)

June 2: Nigeria (home)

June 7: Costa Rica (home, Elland Road) 

Danny Welbeck, who is back in the squad, is understood to have given himself a chance of making the travelling party after impressing Southgate in training.

Of course, Harry Kane certain to make the squad despite sustaining an ankle injury earlier this month.

Kane is targeting Tottenham's game against Brighton on April 17 to make his return. If that is the case, Kane will have up to six games at the end of the season to regain his sharpness ahead of flying to Russia.

Meanwhile, Jamie Vardy and Jack Butland are set to start against the Italians at Wembley.

item.title: Leonardo Bonucci believes Italy can take heart from England's recent resurgence: 'They are a very talented group of young players'
item.description: Italy are taking heart from the promise England have begun to demonstrate as they look to transform their fortunes following their inability to qualify for the summer's World Cup.
item.content:encoded:
Italy are taking heart from the promise England have begun to demonstrate as they look to transform their fortunes following their inability to qualify for the summer's World Cup.

The 2006 world champions are experiencing a similar decline to the one England are attempting to recover from, and which most recently meant they missed out on qualification for Russia 2018.

With that failure following elimination at the group stages in 2010 and 2014 and leading to the sacking of manager Giampiero Ventura, that they are yet to recruit a successor and lost 2-0 to Argentina on Friday means their mood remains downbeat.

Leonardo Bonucci believes Italy can take heart from England's upturn in fortunes

The veteran defender wants the Azzurri to look towards the future with a crop of young players

Carlo Ancelotti, Claudio Ranieri, Roberto Mancini, Chelsea's Antonio Conte and caretaker manager Luigi Di Biagio remain in contention to be appointed permanently - one is expected by May 20 - and England have since become an unlikely source of hope.

Gianluigi Buffon, a link to Italy's success in 2006, is also expected to soon retire in circumstances similar to those their hosts in Tuesday's friendly at Wembley experienced when moving on from their so-called 'Golden Generation'.

The World Cup hopes of Gareth Southgate's team have since become reliant on the youth and promise of Harry Kane, Raheem Sterling and Dele Alli, and the Italians' decorated defender Leonardo Bonucci, 30, said: 'We are playing against a team that managed to undergo change very well. They are a very talented group of young players who have a lot of international experience.

'We have many young players who have less international experience. Also the level of Serie A: we play less in Europe and get less experience than the Premier League.

'We need enthusiasm but we need to see things for what they are. We are undergoing a major change and we cannot be expected to start winning straight away.

'We have the possibility to create problems for this English team.

England have rebounded well since losing against Iceland at Euro 2016

'We have a much younger team with not much international experience. You cannot compare our players born in 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996, 1997 compared to the England players born in the same years.

'These friendlies are useful for the younger players to manage games. People need to understand that patience is the key. We need to let young players grow and hopefully they will take us back to the Italy we were used to.'

In a further sign of change, the 19-year-old Gianluigi Donnarumma - long considered Buffon's natural successor - will start at Wembley, and Bonucci added: 'He is very young and we need to give him space to grow. He's very good but only 19. We should just let him achieve his potential. I will do all I can to lead this group of players.'

Di Biagio, 46, encountered Southgate at the 2015 Under-21 European Championship, where Italy's 3-1 defeat of England ensured Southgate's team were eliminated at the group stage, and he added: 'England have about five top level players who can easily hurt us.

'Some players pick up knocks (against Argentina). It will be at the very least three or four changes.'

item.title: Dominic Calvert-Lewin out to catch the eye with England Under 21s after admitting frustration at lack of recent playing opportunities at Everton
item.description: The Everton striker has been in Gareth Southgate's thoughts after a bright start to the campaign but Calvert-Lewin has only played 229 minutes in the Premier League in 2018.
item.content:encoded:
Dominic Calvert-Lewin is ready to take his frustration out on Ukraine after admitting he has found limited chances in 2018 difficult to accept.

The Everton striker has been in Gareth Southgate's thoughts after a bright start to the campaign but Calvert-Lewin has only played 229 minutes in the Premier League since January 1 and he accepted it was nowhere near enough to earn him a promotion to the England senior squad.

Calvert-Lewin will instead spearhead the Under-21s attack in Tuesday evening's Euro 2019 qualifier at Bramall Lane as Aidy Boothroyd's team aim to tighten their grip on Group 4 and extend a remarkable winning sequence at home that began in June 2011 and spans 29 matches. 

Dominic Calvert-Lewin (right) has seen his opportunities limited since the turn of the year

It will be an emotional evening for Calvert-Lewin, whose career began at Sheffield United before he moved to Everton for £1.5million in August 2016, and he is determined to make the most of the opportunity to start.

'It would be nice to score in that game in front of my home city fans and family,' said Calvert-Lewin. 

'I know there was speculation (about being in the senior team) but I need to be scoring goals and affecting games and in the second half of the season I've not played as much as I'd have liked.

'I wouldn't say it has been difficult. I'm a professional, so you keep your head down. I'm still listening and learning to become a better player. 

Calvert-Lewin is in line to spearhead England's attack against Ukraine at Bramall Lane

'I've done all I can do and to come on and try to affect games. It's my dream to play for the seniors but this time it wasn't to be.' 

Aidy Boothroyd, the Under-21 head coach, has a concern over whether Dominic Solanke will have recovered from an infected toe to be ready for a game against opponents who caused England difficulties in Kiev last November before they were beaten 2-0.

'We made it a tough game over there,' said Boothroyd. 

'We've got to make sure we play a lot better. We're looking at Italy 2019 and hopefully if - and when - we get there, we can play in a way that entertains and wins.'

item.title: 'Nobody can buy a Bayern Munich player against Bayern Munich's will': Robert Lewandowski is not going to Real Madrid, warns chief Rummenigge
item.description: Bayern Munich chairman Karl-Heinz Rummenigge has revealed that the club are hopeful of keeping Robert Lewandowski in the summer transfer window.
item.content:encoded:
Bayern Munich chairman Karl-Heinz Rummenigge has revealed that the club are hopeful of keeping Robert Lewandowski in the summer transfer window despite the striker being heavily linked with a move to Real Madrid.

There have been suggestions that, while Real have yet to enter negotiations with Bayern, they have already agreed a deal worth around £87million with Lewandowski's agent Pini Zahavi.

However, Rummenigge is adamant that Bayern won't sell their best players and used the example of when the club turned down a substantial offer from Chelsea for Franck Ribery 10 years ago.

Real Madrid have been linked with Robert Lewandowski but Bayern Munich want to keep him

Rummenigge told Kicker: 'I always like to remember 2008, when we had an amazing offer from Chelsea for Franck Ribery.

'From that day on, the whole football world knew: nobody can buy a Bayern Munich player against Bayern Munich's will.

'I want to assume that Robert is 100 per cent going to play for Bayern next season.'

Lewandowski has enjoyed a prolific campaign that has seen him find the net on 32 occasions

Bayern could turn their attention to Tottenham's Harry Kane if Lewandowski does depart

Lewandowski remains one of the standout strikers in world football and has enjoyed another prolific season that has seen him score 32 goals in 37 games so far across all competitions.

BAYERN MUNICH'S TOP SCORERS THIS SEASON 

Robert Lewandowski - 32 goals

Thomas Muller - 10

Corentin Tolisso, Kingsley Coman - 7

Arturo Vidal, Arjen Robben - 6

Franck Ribery, Sandro Wagner - 5 

Real are seeking to bolster their striking options, especially with Karim Benzema having not been convincing in front of goal this season, but it remains to be seen whether they will be able to prise Lewandowski away from Bayern.

If Lewandowski does leave then Bayern could turn their attention to Tottenham's Harry Kane as a possible replacement, according to Marca.

Kane has scored 35 times in 39 appearances for Tottenham this campaign.

item.title: Arthur Masuaku and Gael Kakuta among four players to quit DR Congo camp due to poor training facilities, quality of hotels and long flight delays
item.description: Four players have walked out on the Democratic Republic of Congo's national team to protest against the poor organisation around a friendly match.
item.content:encoded:
Four players have walked out on the Democratic Republic of Congo's national team to protest against the poor organisation around a friendly match.

West Ham's Arthur Masuaku, Paul-Jose Mpoku of Belgian club Standard Liege, Jordan Ikoko from En Avant Guingamp and Gael Kakuta of Ligue 1 outfit Amiens left the camp on Monday because of repeated logistical and organisational problems as the team travelled to Dar-es-Salaam for a friendly against Tanzania on Tuesday.

'They all lamented the organisational aspects of the camp and are frustrated,' the team's media officer Jerry Angengwa said on Tuesday.

West Ham's Arthur Masuaku has walked out on DR Congo's camp due to poor organisation

The quartet headed back to their respective clubs while their team-mates – similarly angered by long flight delays, no training facilities and poor quality accommodation, agreed to stay and play the match only if the Congolese federation (Fecofa) promised to improve arrangements for their next internationals.

Poor organisation has long been an issue with the African national teams, bedevilled by a lack of resources but players rarely protest.

There have previous strike actions but almost all around the non-payment of promised money.

Last week star striker Thievy Bifouma walked out on the Congo team who have been holding a camp in France, complaining of poor arrangements and treatment of the players.

He later returned and scored on Sunday in a friendly international against Guinea Bissau in Mantes that had twice been re-arranged from last week.

'At our clubs, everything is professional but not with the national team, who only have a few games a year and have time, quite simply, to organise well. Football is made of details,' he told France Football on Tuesday.

He blamed federation officials for slack organisation and said he and his team-mates will keep pressure up for future matches.

'We will remain vigilant. We will now check a month before our next international to find out what the conditions are. I think a message has been conveyed to the country. And that the conditions will be much better in the future,' Bifouma added. 

DR Congo's stars (pictured in January 2017) are not happy with how their national team is run

item.title: Lionel Messi concedes himself and Paulo Dybala play the same and that’s why it's difficult for them to play together for Argentina
item.description: Juventus forward Dybala was left out of Jorge Sampaoli's Argentina squad for the international friendlies against Italy and Spain. 'It is complicated for Dybala to get used to our system,' Sampaoli said.
item.content:encoded:
Lionel Messi has conceded that himself and Paulo Dybala play the same which makes it difficult for them to play together for Argentina. 

Juventus forward Dybala was left out of Jorge Sampaoli's Argentina squad for the international friendlies against Italy and Spain.  

'It is complicated for Dybala to get used to our system,' Sampaoli said on Friday.  

Argentina's Lionel Messi (L) has conceded that himself and Paulo Dybala (R) play the same

'We couldn't improve his performances and we have to evaluate if the current players [in this squad] are better than Paulo or if we have to keep working with Paulo to improve his performance.' 

Dybala has previously admitted he finds it difficult playing alongside Barcelona star Messi because they both like to occupy similar positions.

And Messi accepted his fellow countryman's views on the attacking duo.

'I spoke to Paulo, what he said is the truth. I understood exactly what he meant,' Messi told Fox Sports.

'At Juventus he plays just like me, we look for the same spaces.

'Alongside me in the national team he had to play more on the left, maybe he's not so used to that.

'It is harder for us to play there, I rarely venture down the left-hand side. On the right we can cut inside and we have the whole pitch in front of us.'

Dybala (R) has previously admitted he finds it difficult playing alongside Barcelona star Messi

Dybala has scored 21 goals in 35 appearances for Juve so far this season but he is yet to bag a goal for his country and faces a challenge to represent Argentina at the 2018 World Cup in the summer.

Sampaoli's side take on Spain on Tuesday night and Messi is expected to return after missing Argentina's 2-0 win over Italy last Friday.

'Messi trained with the group normally so he is available to play,' Sampaoli said.

Messi is expected to return against Spain after missing Argentina's 2-0 win over Italy last week

item.title: Brazil are desperate to right the wrong of their 2014 World Cup humiliation at the hands of Germany... but they know victory on Tuesday can never truly atone for 7-1 horror of Belo Horizonte
item.description: KIT HOLDEN: When Germany host Brazil in Berlin this Tuesday, it will be more than just another friendly. This is a chance to take some kind of tiny revenge for the humiliation of 2014.
item.content:encoded:
Historic is an overused word in football, and eternity is a concept too great for the human mind. But sometimes, you have to give in to the hyperbole. 

If the 7-1 was not historic, if it was not a game for eternity, then there are no words for it at all. That, at least, was how Bild saw it the morning after Germany's humiliation of Brazil four years ago. 

'Without words', the headline read. Germany's loudest newspaper had been left speechless. In the Brazilian press, one word dominated the front pages: vexame. Humiliation.

Brazil were humiliated on home soil when they lost 7-1 to Germany in the World Cup semi-finals

The event was huge for the country, its significance so deeply etched into the Brazilian psyche

When Germany host Brazil in Berlin this Tuesday, it will be more than just another friendly. If you discount the Olympic Football final at Rio 2016, this will be the first time the two teams have met since that fateful night in Belo Horizonte. 

Predictably, the 7-1 is on everybody's lips. 'The result from 2014 doesn't matter anymore,' said Germany's Ilkay Gundogan on Sunday. 

'This Brazil team is a different one, and it will be a battle of equals. Brazil are among the favourites for the World Cup.' 

Gracious though he is, Gundogan is fooling nobody. Though the team has changed, there are still several Brazil players in Berlin who were there in Belo Horizonte. 

Fernandinho, for example, whose farcical loss of possession allowed Germany to sweep in their fourth goal. Or Thiago Silva, who was forced to watch from the sidelines after picking up one too many yellow cards before the semi-final. 

Germany midfielder Ilkay Gundogan tried to downplay the significance of Tuesday's friendly

BRAZIL 1-7 GERMANY — MATCH FACTS

Sportsmail's player ratings from the 2014 semi-final: 

Brazil (4-2-3-1): Cesar 3, Maicon 3, Dante 2.5, Luiz 2.5, Marcelo 2, Gustavo 3, Fernandinho 2.5 (Paulinho 46min, 3), Hulk 2 (Ramires, 46, 3), Oscar 2.5, Bernard 2, Fred 2 (Willian 69, 3).

Subs not used: Jefferson, Dani Alves, Maxwell, Henrique, Hernanes, Jo, Victor.

Scorer: Oscar 90.

Booked: Dante.

Manager: Luiz Felipe Scolari 3.

Germany (4-3-2-1): Neuer 7, Lahm 7, Hummels 6.5 (Mertesacker 46, 6), Howedes 6.5, Boateng 7, Schweinsteiger 8, Khedira 9 (Draxler 76), Kroos 8.5, Muller 8, Ozil 6.5, Klose 7 (Schurrle 58, 8)

Subs not used: Zieler, Grosskreutz, Ginter, Podolski, Durm, Gotze, Kramer, Weidenfeller.

Scorers: Muller 11, Klose 23, Kroos 24, 26, Khedira 29, Schurrle 69, 79.

Manager: Joachim Low, 9.

Man of the match: Sami Khedira.

Referee: Marco Rodriguez (Mexico) 6.5. 

For those players, this is a chance to take some kind of tiny revenge for the humiliation of 2014. Yet they know that they can never truly atone. 

The 7-1 is simply too big, its significance so deeply etched into the Brazilian psyche. It has been coined the 'Mineirazo', a reworking of the 'Maracanazo' of 1950, Brazil's other great footballing shock.

Books have been written about it, and one man even decided to make a Mineirazo-inspired beer. 'Gol da Alemanha' is allegedly a bitter-tasting IPA with an alcohol percentage of 7.1.

'Two hundred years will pass and Brazil will win the World Cup again,' Brazil's team doctor Dr Jose Runco told German magazine 11 Freunde. 'Yet the Brazilians will still be talking about the 7-1.'

Runco was the man who diagnosed Neymar with a fractured vertebrae ahead of the semi-final against Germany, and has recalled the 'waterfalls of tears' that the young superstar shed.

According to many Brazilians interviewed by German media, '7-1' has become a dark joke, a humorous by-word for anything that is wrong with Brazil, from political corruption to economic hardship. 

How much of that is hyperbole we cannot know, but nobody who witnessed the tears shed by Brazil's fans in Belo Horizonte could deny the power of that football match. So powerful are those images that much of the game is often overlooked. 

Nobody who witnessed the tears shed by fans in 2014 could deny the power of that match

One fan shows his frustration at the Estadio Mineirao as Brazil's World Cup hopes evaporate

The sight of the Brazilian team holding up Neymar's shirt, their emotional rendition of the national anthem, and the endless shots of weeping Brazilians were so instantly iconic that other aspects of the game were left almost forgotten. 

Miroslav Klose, for example, became the World Cup's record goalscorer when he slotted home Germany's second, thereby cementing his status as one of the game's unsung legends. 

And who remembers now the several magnificent saves which Manuel Neuer made with his side already 5-0 up in the second half? Who remembers that Brazil, led most notably by Willian, actually looked quite dangerous in the first five minutes? Had they snatched an opener, the excessive pre-game emotions might have been remembered very differently.

Perhaps the most remarkable thing about that game, though, is the fact that the humiliation seemed to engender more mutual respect than it did ill-feeling. Germany's brilliance, but also the manner in which they carried out the destruction, earned them plaudits. 

Other aspects of the game have been forgotten, such as Miroslav Klose's record-breaking goal

'At half-time, I said to the players: "We are 5-0 up, but I expect you to carry on playing with concentration, discipline and seriousness",' Joachim Low told Die Welt am Sonntag in 2015. 

'I didn't want my players to start making fun of the Brazilians in front of millions of viewers. 

'The respect that everyone in Brazil had shown us was huge, and it was out of the question that we would try to humiliate them or play arrogantly.' 

Somehow, even as Andre Schurrle thrashed in Germany's seventh, he did so with respect. That didn't escape the home fans, who had long since begun to applaud their opponents. 

Even Clovis Acosta Fernandes, Brazil's mustachioed super-fan whom TV cameras famously caught clutching his replica World Cup in wide-eyed trauma, was gracious in defeat. Before he left the stadium, he gave his trophy to a German fan. 'You deserve it,' he told her.

The unifying power of sport is another thing which is often subject to gross exaggeration. Yet sometimes, the game really does give us stories which nobody can write. Stories which are best remembered not in print but in myth, in emotion and in craft IPA. Sometimes, there really are no words. 

Even Clovis Acosta Fernandes, Brazil's mustachioed super-fan was gracious in defeat

item.title: Swansea 'ready to sign Andy King on a permanent deal from Leicester' if they avoid Premier League relegation
item.description: Swansea are ready to make Andy King's loan deal from Leicester a permanent one, but only if they can avoid Premier League relegation, according to reports.
item.content:encoded:
Swansea are ready to sign Andy King from Leicester on a permanent basis, but only if they can avoid Premier League relegation, it was reported.

The midfielder completed a six-month loan move to South Wales on the final day of the January transfer window after finding game-time at Leicester limited.

Making four appearances and scoring one goal at the Liberty Stadium, King has been part of a revitalisation under Carlos Carvahal, which has seen them move up to 14th in the table. 

Andy King, pictured playing for Wales against China, may be staying in Swansea for good

His performances have been enough to convince the club to make a bid to sign him permanently, but they will not begin talks with Leicester until their Premier League status is confirmed, according to The Mirror.

Swansea will need an overhaul in midfield this summer with Ki Sung-yueng set to leave when his contract expires this summer while Leroy Fer may not return from a knee injury until 2019.

King, 29, spent a decade with the Foxes and made 388 appearances across League One, the Championship and the Premier League. 

That has been enough to make him a fan-favourite but his position in the side is no long a vital one.

Leicester will want in the region of £6million for the Wales international but could get more if West Ham and Brighton spark a bidding war by renewing their interest.

Swansea are now three points clear of the relegation zone after taking 14 points from their last seven league games, including wins over Liverpool and Arsenal.  

The midfielder went from League One to Premier League title winner in 10 years at Leicester

item.title: UEFA confirm Champions League and Europa League teams can name 12 players on the bench in the final and use a fourth substitute in extra time
item.description: The new rules, which will come into action next season, also state that teams can use a fourth substitute in extra time during the knockout stages.
item.content:encoded:
UEFA have confirmed teams can name 12 substitutes on the bench in the final of Champions League and Europa League matches.

The new rules, which will come into action next season, also state that teams can use a fourth substitute in extra time during the knockout stages.

European football's governing body announced on Wednesday it would up the current quota of substitutes from seven to 11 in Champions League final, Europa League final and UEFA Super Cup.

UEFA confirm 12 substitutes can be named in Champions League and Europa League finals

The new rules also state a fourth substitute can be used in extra time during knockout stages

Champions League play-offs, group-stage games, round-of-16 matches, quarter-finals, semi-finals and the final have also been changed to 8pm GMT – 15 minutes later than it currently is.

Europa League matches from the group stage until round-of-16 matches will kick off at 5.55pm and 8pm GMT. Games from the same group will be played at the same time. Quarter-finals, semi-finals and final will all kick off at 8pm.

The UEFA Super Cup will kick-off at 8pm, which already applies to this year's final on August 15 at Tallinn's Lillekula Stadium in Estonia.

Clubs may register three new eligible players without any restrictions following the Champions League and Europa League group stages, which is in line with many current domestic league legislatures.

The Europa League will also follow in the footsteps of the Champions League, allowing teams to don a multiple-winner badge if they have won the competition (or the former UEFA Cup) three times in a row or five times in total.

As it stands, Sevilla will be the only team eligible to do so having won the competition five times.   

Teams in Europa League, like Sevilla, can wear multiple-winner badges on their jerseys

item.title: Australia call up Matt Renshaw for fourth Test against South Africa with Cameron Bancroft and David Warner under fire over ball-tampering scandal
item.description: Opening batsman Matt Renshaw has been added to Australia's squad for the fourth Test against South Africa in what could be the first of many call-ups.
item.content:encoded:
Opening batsman Matt Renshaw has been added to Australia's squad for the fourth Test against South Africa in what could be the first of many call-ups.

Australian cricket has been rocked by the ball-tampering scandal that overshadowed the heavy 322-run defeat in the third Test in South Africa.

Steve Smith has been banned for the final Test in Johannesburg after admitting to deliberately attempting to alter the condition of the ball on the third day.

Matt Renshaw has been added to Australia's squad for the fourth Test against South Africa

Cameron Bancroft was caught rubbing sticky yellow tape on the ball, with Smith admitting afterwards it was a premeditated move by 'the leadership group'.

Smith is expected to be permanently stripped of the captaincy and faces a lengthy ban from the side.

Renshaw will fly out out to Johannesburg on Tuesday evening after the completion of the Sheffield Shield final, where Queensland face Tasmania. 

Renshaw's call-up for Friday's Test match puts both Bancroft and David Warner's spots at the top of order in doubt.

The call-up puts Cameron Bancroft and David Warner's spots at the top of the order in doubt

Renshaw was dropped for Bancroft ahead of the Ashes after a lean spell on the sub-continent

Sportsmail revealed on Sunday that vice-captain Warner had emerged as the central figure in the ball-tampering scandal, and is now set to be kicked out of the side alongside Smith.

Coach Darren Lehmann's future is also under intense scrutiny.

Renshaw looks set to play in his first Test since September last year, after he was dropped in favour of Bancroft for the Ashes.

The 21-year-old from Middlesbrough has failed to pass fifty in his previous nine innings but has a healthy Test average of 36, hitting 184 against Pakistan in Sydney last January.

item.title: Alex McLeish insists he has no fears over Scott McTominay's commitment to the cause: 'He wants to give everything he can to Scotland'
item.description: Alex McLeish insists he has no fears over Scott McTominay's commitment to the Scotland cause. The Manchester United midfielder made his international debut against Costa Rica.
item.content:encoded:
Alex McLeish insists he has no fears over Scott McTominay's commitment to the Scotland cause.

The Manchester United midfielder made his international debut against Costa Rica at Hampden last Friday, but won't feature against Hungary in Budapest after hurting his calf in training.

Born in Lancaster, McTominay remains eligible to play for England until he plays a competitive international for the Scots.

Scott McTominay played his first game for Scotland in the friendly against Costa Rica

However, quashing concerns the Old Trafford player has done a runner after one game, McLeish said: 'I spoke to Scott. He was gutted he was missing the next game, he said it was disappointing.

'He was okay on Saturday and then he woke up on Sunday and felt a twinge as he went into the shower.

'He spoke to the doctor who said he was not going to make it.

'I had a ten-minute chat with him. He loved the experience (against Costa Rica).

'He was itching to be involved in the second game. He wants to give everything he can to Scotland.

'The guy I left is raring to be a part of it. He wants to improve as a player.'

The Manchester United midfielder is still eligible to play for England if he wants 

McLeish thinks there is no doubting McTominay's commitment to Scotland 

The 21-year-old is one of three call-offs this evening, Norwich defender Grant Hanley pulling out with shin splints and Newcastle's Matt Ritchie with a groin complaint.

McTominay was one of five new caps in an underwhelming defeat to Costa Rica, and McLeish fully expects to see him back in a dark blue jersey soon.

'Scott is a very receptive boy. He likes to be told what he can improve on. We showed him some video stuff and we will send some stuff down to him just to improve his overall awareness. He was delighted with that.

'It was difficult for the newcomers. They had maybe not set eyes on each other except maybe on TV and they had not played together.

'At the start of the second-half it was excellent and they maintained that throughout.

'Even Scott, just before he came off, you saw a big action from him with a run forward and a final pass and he is bursting to go again in the national jersey. The boy I spoke to is committed, yes.'

The Scotland boss is adamant the 21-year-old has a big future with his side

item.title: Real Madrid make signing Roma goalkeeper Alisson their 'plan A' as Brazil ace will cost at least £35m less than David de Gea or Thibaut Courtois and command half as much in wages
item.description: European champions Real are seeking to replace Keylor Navas as their No 1 goalkeeper and have been tracking Alisson, as well as Manchester United ace De Gea and star Chelsea stopper Courtois.
item.content:encoded:
Real Madrid's search for a new goalkeeper appears set to end with the signing of Brazil star Alisson from Roma this summer.

The European champions are seeking to replace Keylor Navas as their No 1 and have been tracking Alisson, as well as Manchester United ace David de Gea and Chelsea stopper Thibaut Courtois.

According to Marca, bringing Alisson in has become Real's 'plan A' because he will be cheaper and much easier to sign.

Brazil and Roma ace Alisson has reportedly emerged as Real Madrid's 'plan A' keeper signing

Spaniard David de Gea, 27, is also on Real's radar but he is less available and more expensive

Marca report that the Roma man — whose full name is Alisson Ramses Becker — will cost a fee between €50million (£43.90m) and €60m (£52.68m), while United and Chelsea are both demanding in excess of €100m (£87.80m) for their keepers. 

Furthermore, it is claimed that Roma are keen to cash-in on the 25-year-old, which is not the case with United or Chelsea. And wages are another factor, with Courtois and De Gea's demands said to be double what Alisson will accept.

All three candidates are likely to start at this year's World Cup for their respective countries.

Alisson kept a clean sheet as Brazil won their latest friendly 3-0 against World Cup hosts Russia in Moscow on Friday evening.

De Gea made his 26th senior appearance for Spain as they drew 1-1 with Germany on the same night, while 55-cap Courtois sat out Belgium's 1-0 win over Japan and will miss Tuesday's match against Saudi Arabia due to a short-term injury.

Alisson kept a clean sheet as Brazil beat World Cup hosts Russia 3-0 in Moscow on Friday night

De Gea was also in international action on Friday night as his Spain side drew 1-1 with Germany

item.title: Joe Root 'not aware of any ball tampering' during the Ashes but admits Australia scandal is 'disappointing for Test cricket'
item.description: Sportsmail revealed on Sunday that David Warner told England's beaten players about his methods of altering the ball's condition after Australia's 4-0 series win.
item.content:encoded:
Joe Root has denied any knowledge that Australia attempted to tamper with the ball during the Ashes earlier this winter.

Sportsmail revealed on Sunday that David Warner told England's beaten players about his methods of altering the ball's condition.

Though Root claims there was no suspicion among the England players, they were mystified as to how the home attack were able to produce reverse swing during the series.

Joe Root has denied any knowledge that Australia attempted to tamper with the ball

Root said on Monday: 'Not to my knowledge. I was not aware of any ball tampering. I have enough to worry about... but it's disappointing for Test cricket and cricket in general'. 

England were beaten 4-0 Down Under and experienced a miserable return to Test cricket in New Zealand, where they were consigned to an innings defeat in a day-night match in Auckland.

Root pointed out the responsibility of captains in Test cricket, after Steve Smith admitted Australia deliberately attempted to alter the condition of the ball to gain an advantage over South Africa. 

He said: 'As captain you're responsible for how everyone else behaves. 

'I have to look after my own group and make sure I'm happy with how they conduct themselves. As an international player you should know the rules. 

'I should not have to back that up. It's as simple as that. Every time you go out you always know that there are a load of cameras ... you are under the spotlight. 

'It's important that you give everything and you do everything to win but in the right way.' 

Root added that captains in Test cricket have responsibility over team behaviour

Nasser Hussain has called into question the future of Australia coach Darren Lehmann

Former England skipper and Sportsmail columnist Nasser Hussain called into question the future of Australia coach Darren Lehmann, who was apparently unaware of the players' plan. 

Hussain told Sky Sports: 'It doesn't look good on Lehmann either way, really. If he did know then he's in a whole heap of trouble and will not be able to hold his job down if he is condoning cheating and (the) scratching of a cricket ball.

'If he didn't know, then questions will be asked as to why senior players are going round not telling the coach exactly what is going on.

'In the dressing rooms I've played in, it is inconceivable that the coach wouldn't know something like this was being dreamt up.

'The silence has been deafening actually, not just from Lehmann and (David) Saker, the bowling coach, but also from David Warner.

'David Warner seems to have a lot to say on a cricket field; in the last 48 hours the silence from David Warner has been deafening.' 

SO WHAT WERE WARNER AND CO UP TO DURING THE ASHES? 

These pictures underline the suggestion that David Warner was involved in altering the condition of the ball during the recent Ashes series. 

Australia’s vice-captain is said to have revealed his method to England players at the end of the series. 

It revolves around the strapping he wears on the thumb and index finger of his left hand (pictured during the final Ashes Test). Abrasive substances are then attached to the tape to rough up or dull one side of the ball. 

Oddly, Warner, who says he needs the strapping to protect his injured fingers and thumb, removes the strapping while batting.

Cameron Bancroft was also implicated in Sydney. This picture appears to show the Aussie opener pocketing some sugar.

item.title: Lionel Messi set for Argentina return in Spain friendly after sitting out Italy game: 'I feel good and I hope to play'
item.description: Lionel Messi is set to return for Argentina in Tuesday's friendly showdown with Spain in Madrid. The Albiceleste captain sat out Friday's 2-0 win over Italy in Manchester.
item.content:encoded:
Lionel Messi is set to return for Argentina in Tuesday's friendly showdown with Spain in Madrid.

The Albiceleste captain sat out Friday's 2-0 win over Italy in Manchester as a precaution because of an adductor muscle injury but trained fully on Monday and has been cleared to lead his country out at the Wanda Metropolitano stadium.

Argentina coach Jorge Sampaoli said: 'Messi trained with the group normally so he is available to play.

Lionel Messi came through Argentina training on Thursday and is fit to play Spain

'Before the game against Italy Leo said he could not play. But he has trained the last two days. We will select the starting XI later.'

Speaking earlier in the day, Messi told Fox Sports Argentina: 'My idea is to play against Spain, I just need to see how I feel after the last training session.

'I trained normally on Sunday, I feel good and I hope to play.'

Argentina's all-time record goalscorer, who could come face-to-face with Barcelona team-mates Gerard Pique and Jordi Alba in the Spain defence, added: 'I'm optimistic.

After sitting out the 2-0 victory against Italy, Messi is eager to return to action 

'I'm really keen to play against Spain. Hopefully that will be the case and things turn out well.'

Sampaoli has outlined Messi's importance to Argentina - who are without knee-injury-victim Sergio Aguero - by revealing the side will be set up to get the best out of him.

'It's impossible to teach Messi anything. Leo is unreachable,' Sampaoli said. 'You cannot teach him, you have to understand him, you have to build a team around him.

Jorge Sampaoli (left) admitted he is unable to teach Messi anything to add to his game

'I think we have to learn how to accompany this type of player that only exists once in a blue moon.'

Spain drew 1-1 with Germany in Dusseldorf on Friday, extending their unbeaten record under Julen Lopetegui to 17 matches.

Rodrigo gave the 2010 World Cup winners an early lead but Thomas Muller's thunderbolt earned Germany, the current world champions, a share of the spoils.

item.title: Real Madrid star Isco's girlfriend Sara Salamo reveals death threats from fans after accusations she is responsible for his loss of form
item.description: Actress Salamo and Spain international Isco have been together for several months, going public with in October last year. However some fans have disturbingly taken against the 25-year-old.
item.content:encoded:
Sara Salamo, girlfriend of Real Madrid forward Isco, has revealed she has been the target of online death threats.

Actress Salamo and Spain international Isco have been together for several months, going public with their relationship in October last year.

However some fans have disturbingly taken against the 25-year-old, as she revealed last week.

Sara Salamo, girlfriend of Real Madrid star Isco, has been the target of online death threats

Salamo retweeted a now deleted message which told her 'your days are numbered'

Isco has struggled for form, which some in Spain have blamed on the 25-year-old actress

Salamo retweeted a threat she was sent and copied in the Spanish police, writing: 'This man who defines himself as misogynist is sending me these messages...'

The tweet, now deleted, said 'your days are numbered'. The account itself has since been suspended, while the police responded by asking Salamo to follow them so they could send her advice privately.

The abuse comes after Salamo was accused by Spanish website Don Balon of leading Isco astray on a 'vida loca' lifestyle, resulting in a loss of form on the pitch. 

Salamo appealed to the police for help, while the threatening account has been suspended

Salamo responded furiously to the accusations, tweeting: 'I would appreciate you not slandering me or my partner. Otherwise I'll have to take legal action'.

Isco, who started the Champions League final ahead of Gareth Bale last season, has not yet matched the same high standards in this campaign.

He has scored five goals and created five assists in 25 La Liga matches, but has found the net in the league once since last November.

She threatened legal action against a Spanish newspaper which criticised her relationship

item.title: England coach Trevor Bayliss 'embarrassed' by Australia's ball-tampering scandal in South Africa
item.description: England's Australian coach Trevor Bayliss admits he is embarrassed by the ball-tampering shame which has engulfed his compatriots on their Test tour of South Africa.
item.content:encoded:
England's Australian coach Trevor Bayliss admits he is embarrassed by the ball-tampering shame which has engulfed his compatriots on their Test tour of South Africa.

Bayliss, who oversaw England's 4-0 defeat in his native country this winter, has echoed the insistence of captain Joe Root and senior seamer Stuart Broad that the Ashes tourists had no reason to suspect any sharp practice from their hosts.

But as a former mentor of Steve Smith's when the Australia captain was a young New South Wales all-rounder, he has been shocked by events in Cape Town this week.

Trevor Bayliss admits he is 'as an Australian I'm embarrassed' by ball-tampering scandal

Steve Smith has been banned for one Test match and faces a lengthy ban from the side

Smith has already been banned by the International Cricket Council for the final Test in Johannesburg and fined his match fee for the third match of four at Newlands after he and batsman Cameron Bancroft confessed to a plot to alter the condition of the ball by using tape concealed in the latter's pocket during South Africa's second innings.

'I'm obviously disappointed - and as an Australian I'm embarrassed,' said Bayliss.

'Steve is a lovely young bloke who has made a terrible mistake, and I'm sure Cricket Australia (CA) will work out the course of action required.'

CA is expected to make an announcement over the next 24 hours about further punishment for Smith and his deputy David Warner, having already stood both down from their roles temporarily, while Australia coach Darren Lehmann is reportedly set to resign.

Australia admitted to deliberately attempting to alter the condition of the ball in Cape Town

Cameron Bancroft was seen running his hand over the ball, before removing a yellow object from his pocket and placing it down the front of his trousers

Bayliss, speaking after England's innings defeat in their first Test against New Zealand in Auckland, added: 'They obviously will be punished, but I've no idea how severe... we'll have to see what Cricket Australia come up with.'

Asked if England had any suspicions about Australian ball-tampering during the Ashes, however, he said: 'No. I thought we were outplayed by a much better team.

'I've got no complaints.'

item.title: Dan Evans set for comeback from cocaine ban in April as former British No 2 pencils in return at Challenger level event in Glasgow
item.description: Dan Evans is expected to make his comeback from a cocaine ban late next month at the new Challenger level event to be staged in Glasgow, provided he is given a wildcard.
item.content:encoded:
Dan Evans is expected to make his comeback from a cocaine ban late next month at the new Challenger level event to be staged in Glasgow, provided he is given a wildcard.

The former British No 2 is said to have pencilled in the qualifying rounds of the £70,000 tournament at the Scotstoun Centre to make his return just four days after his year-long suspension ends on April 23.

After that his schedule is likely to take in at least one of the outdoor hard-court bottom-tier Futures tournaments due to take place in Tunisia in May as he starts out on the long road back from testing positive at last year’s Barcelona Open.

Dan Evans is set to return to action four days after his year-long suspension ends

The 27-year-old, who reached a ranking high of No 41, has been promised assistance from the LTA providing he abides by certain criteria. 

This will involve being part of doping education programmes and it is also understood Evans will have to meet strict weight and fitness targets.

If he does so then it is likely there will be help with wildcards at tournaments run by the LTA. He is allowed to use LTA facilities for the last two months of his suspension and has been training in Bath and Birmingham and, prior to that, privately in Dubai.

The 27-year-old Evans will be given help by the LTA as long as he meets certain criteria

British No 1 Kyle Edmund is planning an unusually heavy programme of clay-court events as he tries to regain momentum after his run to the Australian Open semi-finals. 

His spring schedule will take in Marrakech, Monte Carlo, Estoril, Madrid and Rome before the French Open. 

‘I had a really good start to the year so it’s not like I have to chase anything,’ he said. 

‘On clay there are a lot more rallies, the movement is different, there are things you have to adapt to. I know I can play well on it so I look forward to that.’

item.title: Ipswich to decide future of manager Mick McCarthy before the end of the season, says owner Marcus Evans
item.description: Reports have suggested the 59-year-old's six-year spell in charge at Portman Road could end this summer. McCarthy took over a Town side bottom of the Championship in 2012.
item.content:encoded:
Ipswich Town will clarify the future of manager Mick McCarthy before the end of next month, the Championship club have announced.

Reports have suggested the 59-year-old's six-year spell in charge at Portman Road could end this summer when his contract expires.

McCarthy took over a Town side which was bottom of the Championship in 2012 and led them to the play-offs two seasons later.

Ipswich Town will clarify the future of manager Mick McCarthy before the end of next month

However the Ipswich fans have become increasingly frustrated in recent campaigns and, with the club currently 10 points off the top six in 12th place with eight matches remaining, speculation about McCarthy's future has increased.

The club have said McCarthy's position will be resolved before the early-bird season-ticket deadline on April 30.

Ipswich owner Marcus Evans said: 'As I'm sure you are aware, Mick's contract is up at the end of the season and I'm fully aware that there will be supporters who will be waiting to see how that situation develops.

'I continue to have a very good relationship with Mick. We talk regularly and we will sit down and discuss the best way forward for this football club in the next few weeks. And that is the sole concern for me - what is best for Ipswich Town.

'Supporters will know the result of that conversation in due course but it will be made public well in advance of the early-bird deadline.'

item.description: Johnny Sexton wants Leinster to emulate ruthless rivals Saracens in their quest for a record-equalling fourth European crown. The Irish province face the back-to-back champions on Sunday.
item.content:encoded:
Johnny Sexton wants Leinster to emulate ruthless rivals Saracens in their quest for a record-equalling fourth European crown.

The Irish province face the back-to-back champions in Dublin on Sunday with many of their number buoyed by a Six Nations Grand Slam with the national team.

Leinster won a trio of titles themselves in 2009, 2011 and 2012 - a fourth would see them sit alongside Toulouse as the most successful side in European rugby history.

Johnny Sexton (pictured) wants Leinster to emulate this weekend's opponents, Saracens

But their star fly-half Sexton knows if they are to do that they need to discover some typical Sarries grit in this quarter-final, as the English have become the masters of winning huge games away from home.

The north Londoners have beaten Toulon at the Stade Mayol and Munster in Dublin in recent seasons - results that only add to their legend.

'It is going to be a huge challenge,' said Sexton.

'If you want to win the European Cup again you are going to have to beat Saracens at some stage so there is no better time than to get them at home in the quarter-final.

Sarries have dominated the Champions Cup in recent seasons, winning back-to-back titles

'They are back-to-back champions and we are striving to get back to where we were and become that champion team ourselves.

'We came close last year. We weren't quite good enough. We are hoping to take that experience and put it into our lessons for this week.

'I still think it is an advantage playing at home. We are going to have a crowd of 50,000 apparently and that's a big factor, a big motivating factor, you don't want to let those people down so I don't think it is negated fully but I do think they will have no fear.

'They sort of thrive off these atmospheres, it is that 'against the world' (attitude) and they seem to play their best under those circumstances.

'You saw it last year when the Aviva (Stadium) was red and they produced a brilliant performance to beat Munster.' 

Owen Farrell (left) is a doubt, but Sexton says Alex Lozowski (right) is a worthy replacement

Saracens are sweating on the fitness of Owen Farrell - Sexton's foil and friend on the Lions tour, but foe when England and Ireland meet.

The fly-half has a quad injury and is touch-and-go to be fit for the quarter-final.

But Sexton reckons his understudy, 24-year-old Alex Lozowski, is a fine second option.

'They have an outstanding backup in Lozowski,' he added.

'He has played for England himself numerous times and impressed when he has played. He did pretty well against Harlequins last week.

'Look, any team in the world would miss Owen, whether it is at 10 or 12. You don't get nominated for world player of the year for nothing. He has been outstanding for the last 24 months and I'm sure they are desperate to have him back.

Former England coach Stuart Lancaster, now at Leinster, is plotting the downfall of Farrell & Co

Leinster are aiming for a record-equalling fourth European title after last winning it in 2011-12

'If we get a win on Sunday we don't mind who we are playing.' 

Another fascinating sub-plot to the Easter Sunday egg-hunt is the fact that Stuart Lancaster, the former England head-coach will be plotting to undo his old players as he coaches Leinster.

Sexton was integral in Lancaster's appointment as head coach after he flopped at the World Cup as England boss.

Sexton famously texted Lancaster asking him to consider coaching Leinster after that tournament - and yesterday he revealed Owen and Andy Farrell - the latter now Ireland defence coach - had a huge influence too.

'Leo (Cullen) had been talking to him and I had spoken to a few of the English boys and the Farrells about him really.

'They spoke very highly of him and it was something we needed at the time, someone to come in and help and he has been brilliant since.'

item.title: Manuel Neuer celebrates his 32nd birthday by returning to Bayern Munich training after lengthy spell out
item.description: Bayern were all too happy to see their No 1 return to action and Tweeted: ' Happy birthday to our #1 and only Manuel Neuer. Our captain is back on the training pitch.'
item.content:encoded:
Manuel Neuer celebrated his 32nd birthday by joining his Bayern Munich team-mates on the training pitch after a lengthy spell on the sidelines.

The German goalkeeper, who has not played since September after fracturing his metatarsal in his left foot, returned to full first-team training on Tuesday.

Bayern were all too happy to see their No 1 return to action and tweeted: 'Happy birthday to our #1 and only Manuel Neuer.  Our captain is back on the training pitch.'

Manuel Neuer celebrated turning 32 by returning to training after a lengthy spell out

The injury kept Neuer out of Germany's latest squad for their friendlies with Spain and Brazil and also cast doubt over his World Cup place.

However, Joachim Low is confident Neuer will get minutes under his belt before the season ends - something he admits is pivotal in deciding who makes the plane to Russia this summer.

'If a player plays no role in the preparation, it is difficult to nominate him,' Low told reporters last week.

Our captain is back on the training pitch 👍 #MiaSanMia pic.twitter.com/IlTOaVXYL6

— FC Bayern English (@FCBayernEN) March 27, 2018

Happy birthday to our #️⃣1️⃣ and only @Manuel_Neuer! 🙌 #MiaSanMia pic.twitter.com/HIrsqCsuii

— FC Bayern English (@FCBayernEN) March 27, 2018

Neuer, who has not played since September after braking his foot, trained on Tuesday

'When Manuel came to us on Tuesday, together with Andy Kopke [coach] and Dr [Hans-Wilhelm] Muller-Wohlfahrt [we] had a long conversation with him. Manuel is absolutely on schedule. It is planned that he will still play at Bayern this season.

'The doctor has assured me that the condition of his scar and the growing together of the bones are absolutely fine and look very good. 

'However, at the current stage he is not allowed to [train] at maximum, he is currently training at 90 per cent and wants to increase to 100 per cent this week so that he is fully resilient.

'Then he can still get the necessary security in the training sessions. I assume and am very optimistic that Manuel will be present at the World Cup.' 

Germany boss Joachim Low is confident Neuer will be fit in time to play before the World Cup

item.title: Dillian Whyte has now won seven fights since losing to Anthony Joshua in 2015... but only now does it feel like his career might be back on track
item.description: DANIEL MATTHEWS AT THE O2 ARENA: Dillian Whyte has been in big fights before. He has been in good fights before. But this felt different. At long, long last, this felt like the night his career begun.
item.content:encoded:
Dillian Whyte has been in big fights before. He has been in good fights before. But this felt different.

At long, long last, this felt like the night his top-level career really began.

'I've been swimming against the wave my whole career,' he said in the build-up. Finally the tide seems to have turned.

Let's not kid ourselves. Lucas Browne came into this fight unbeaten in 25 professional contests. But for all the Australian's toughness and bravery, he showed himself to be very limited. 

Dillian Whyte may have changed the tide on a declining career by knocking out Lucas Browne

For five-and-a-half rounds he was pummelled and pounded into a bloody mess and if this felt like the true beginning of Whyte's life at the top table, it could well spell the end for a man who once held the WBA 'regular' world title, for a few days at least.

The disparity in skills was obvious from the first bell, as Whyte regularly punished Browne, the challenger who made ever more crude attempts to set up his hammer right hand.

By the second round, the hometown fighter had opened up a nasty cut above his opponent's left eye. By round three a number of big right hands had rendered the Australian's face crimson. Shortly after the start of the sixth, it was lights out.

The celebrations inside the O2 may have been tempered by the legitimate concerns for the loser's safety.

But make no mistake, this was the win — and the performance — Whyte has waited for since the last time he headlined at this arena against Anthony Joshua.

For five-and-a-half rounds Browne was pummelled and pounded into a bloody mess by Whyte 

Browne receives a blow to the face following a brilliant right hook from Whyte on Saturday in the English capital

That defeat in December 2015 will never be erased from his record. But it may no longer be his defining night.

He is fighter who has risen from abject poverty in Jamaica to forge a life for himself and his family on these shores. Shot and stabbed on the way, Whyte has a story to rival many of boxing's many rags to riches tales.

Browne, meanwhile, is a former bouncer from Sydney who came to boxing via MMA and claims to have had his world title dreams ripped from him by a Chechnyan conspiracy. Oh, and he failed two drugs tests within a year in 2016.

This fight should have sold itself.

But it is perhaps fitting that its significance was instead being measured by its supporting role in the wider heavyweight battle for supremacy.

It's no coincidence either that it was scheduled a week before Joshua takes on Joseph Parker.

Since his scrap with AJ, Whyte has begrudgingly played the role of understudy. He had become - unfairly but perhaps inevitably - a fighter best known for the one he lost.

Whyte looks down at blood-soaked Browne after landing the winning blow in the sixth round

Since that night, AJ has gone on to sell-out Wembley and the Principality Stadium, twice.

Next weekend, the WBA and IBF champion takes on the best fighter from Down Under in front of 80,000 fans.

On Saturday, his one-time rival drew 8,000 fans for a clash with the man hoping to steal Parker's crown.

AJ has talked up the possibility of a rematch between the British pair. Whyte was only too happy to return the favour at the O2.

But the uncomfortable truth is that their careers had been moving at different trajectories – if not in opposing directions.

The Brixton heavyweight has now won seven fights since that defeat in 2015, but until Saturday night none had fully allowed him to step out of the shadow cast over his career that night.

It's not been for want of trying. Since Whyte became the No 1 contender to Deontay Wilder's WBC title, Eddie Hearn has made seven-figure offers to the Alabama banger. But the American has so far been happier to offer convicted drug cheat Luis Ortiz two bites at the cherry than take any British bait. 

Whyte believes this is because he presents too big a risk to the champion's hopes of cashing in against Joshua. Others suggested he simply offered the American too little reward.

After his left-hook laid out Browne in chilling fashion, maybe he was right all along.

Promoter Eddie Hearn watched the emphatic victory for Whyte alongside boxer Kell Brook

item.title: Alex McLeish puts Scotland through their paces ahead of Hungary clash as he targets win to ignite reign: 'It can start with one big performance'
item.description: Alex McLeish holds precious few regrets from a 40-year career as player and manager. Few beyond his first visit to Hungary when he blew the opportunity to create some celluloid gold-dust.
item.content:encoded:
Alex McLeish holds precious few regrets from a 40-year career as player and manager. Few beyond his first visit to Hungary when he blew the opportunity to create some celluloid gold-dust alongside Pele and Sylvester Stallone.

'In 1980, the year Aberdeen won the league, we embarked on an Iron Curtain trip to Poland and Hungary with the national team. Jock (Stein) was the boss and I recall going on the bus and sitting with Danny McGrain up the back.

'That was the year Escape to Victory was made. We were in the hotel and I met Warky (John Wark) and a few of the Ipswich boys that were in it,' he reflected.

Alex McLeish is desperate for a big performance and victory against Hungary in Budapest

Scotland trained ahead of their friendly, having lost to Costa Rica in McLeish's first game back

MTK Hungaria's stadium in Budapest - now demolished - was the scene for the fateful game against Nazi Germany and Pele's iconic overhead kick.

'Big Jock had said to us: "If anyone wants to stay on and be extras...",' McLeish recalled ruefully. 'I always regret that film never had a ginger-headed Scotsman in it...' One regret from Hungary is more than most men will ever acquire.

And Big Eck has no desire to add a second by becoming the first Scotland boss since Berti Vogts to lose his opening two games in charge of the national team.

The criticism which followed Friday's uninspiring, experimental defeat to Costa Rica has been prolonged and sometimes fierce.

Failure to beat a Hungary team 50th in the FIFA rankings after a 3-2 home defeat to Kazakhstan on Friday would be unlikely to improve the negativity and indifference surrounding Scotland's national team.

'I have to get a result,' McLeish admitted. 'We have to change the culture and get a winning mentality. The evidence has to be there for the players but it will only be there if they win.

'It can start with one big performance and result. We've got to believe that. This game takes on more importance after the defeat to Costa Rica. I guess if we don't get the right result then I'm a bigger dud than I was on Friday.

'I'm going to have to have rhinoceros skin but I'm pleased with the players and the way they've adjusted. The second half was better on Friday and they were happy with what we showed them on Sunday. Now it's about taking it to the next stage.' By his own admission, McLeish found himself in no-win territory against Costa Rica.

Sticking with a Gordon Strachan team offered no guarantees of victory and would have brought criticism from those who think the national team desperately needs new blood. Yet, by fielding five new caps, McLeish always risked a performance lacking fluency.

'I've not read all the critiques,' he insisted. 'I've only seen one or two things. But I tend not to get my knickers in a twist over something like that. I'm on a kind of pathway here where I feel I am doing the right thing and at the end of it I believe it was the right thing to do. I am sticking to that.

'It's not good to lose your first home game, especially at Hampden.

'We made enough chances in the second half to at least get something from it.' The concern is obvious. Scotland's next three friendlies are away from home in Budapest, Peru and Mexico before a Nations League warm-up against Belgium in September. None can be considered a gimme.

The Scots are looking to rebuild having failed to qualify for this summer's World Cup

McLeish insists he's not read the criticism levelled at him after losing the first game

Lose and the pressure for a win will only increase.

'A win gets some of the negativity away,' he conceded. 'But I'm not focused on the negativity.

'I am thinking about the team and what they can do and the performance level they bring.

'We are going to try to be more of a goal threat. We had some chances the other night and didn't take them. There is a wee bit of street-wise nous required, so again all these little things I will be reminding the guys of.' Changes will be necessary after Scott McTominay, Grant Hanley and Matt Ritchie returned to their clubs injured.

Celtic's Jack Hendry is likely to start in defence. The midfield three is also likely to feature Stuart Armstrong, Callum McGregor and John McGinn of Hibs. It's the one area of the pitch where Scotland's manager has options.

'John is in there with guys like Kenny McLean who I have seen in really good form as an aggressive midfielder over the last few weeks,' the Scotland manager continued.

'There are similarities between them and with the cut and thrust of Stuart Armstrong.' The withdrawal of Hanley - and Russell Martin from the original squad - leaves central defence and right-back desperately short.

The Scotland boss chats to Liverpool defender Andy Robertson during training 

The pressure on Scotland would mount if they don't win, with tricky fixtures coming up

Ruling out a call to Alan Hutton after the former Rangers player retired from international duty, Hendry has played on the right side for Celtic in recent weeks, yet McLeish admitted: 'He is not really a right back. He is a young centre half who is a great prospect.' 

Attacking options are also thin on the ground. McLeish believes Oli McBurnie had a 'smashing' debut, yet the lack of strikers in the squad shows how little he has to work with. Stick with Strachan's old guard and he's damned if he does. Fail to try out new players and he's damned if he doesn't.

'If I continue with things and we get a reverse it's even worse,' he said. 'You have got to take a punch in the chin to go forward. You have to take a step back to go two forward.

'Under Gordon they had a defeat-free season and it would have been nice to continue the unbeaten run. But I felt it in my bones to do what I did and I don't regret it.' Eck-scape to Victory would have looked good on a poster.

Having forged one regret in Hungary 38 years ago, Scotland's manager doesn't intend to create another by wasting the chance to try new players.

item.title: Alex Cuthbert rules himself out of Wales selection by signing for Exeter Chiefs on three-year deal
item.description: Aviva Premiership champions Exeter Chiefs have announced the signing of Wales wing Alex Cuthbert on a three-year deal. Cuthbert, will complete his move at the end of the season.
item.content:encoded:
Alex Cuthbert is on the move from Cardiff to Exeter at the end of the season

Aviva Premiership champions Exeter Chiefs have announced the signing of Wales wing Alex Cuthbert on a three-year deal.

Cuthbert, who toured Australia with the British and Irish Lions in 2013, will complete his move to Sandy Park from Cardiff Blues at the end of the season.

The move means the 27-year-old will no longer be available for Wales selection due to new rules announced last year.

Cuthbert has 47 caps for his country, 13 short of the 60 needed to keep him eligible following his move away from Wales.

After seven years with the Blues, Cuthbert is looking forward to a new challenge.

He said: 'I'm very excited about the move. I've played all of my rugby in Wales and I've enjoyed some fantastic times over the years but I feel I'm at a stage in my career where I have to try something different.

'And the challenge of going to Exeter and trying to prove myself in a new environment at the Chiefs is something that really appeals to me.

'Sitting down with Rob (Baxter) and Ali (Hepher), I liked what they had to say and where they said the club was looking to go in the future.

'Like a lot of people, I've watched how the Chiefs have not only developed into a force within the English game, but also in Europe as well over the last few years.

'They are champions of England at the moment, they are going very well again this season, and when you look at the squad they have down there, you can see it's got a lot of talent within it and one which wants to really achieve things together.'

Cuthbert becomes Exeter rugby director Rob Baxter's first signing for the 2018/19 campaign.

Cuthbert will aim to help the Chiefs continue their rise to the top of the English game

Baxter said: 'We have actually been looking at Alex for a few years. Initially we looked at him when he was first breaking into top-flight rugby and he's someone who we have been tracking for some time.

'At this stage, he is a player who is looking for a new challenge and that's the important thing to us.'
